<h1>The iEconomy</h1>
</div><!--close .storyHeader -->
<div class="storySummary">
<span class="summary">Articles in this series examine challenges posed by increasingly globalized high-tech industries. The series won a <a href="http://www.pulitzer.org/citation/2013-Explanatory-Reporting">Pulitzer Prize</a> for explanatory reporting on April 15, 2013.</span>
</div><!--close .storySummary -->

<div class="update updateFirst"> 
<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_1:_An_Empire_Built_Abroad">Part 1: An Empire Built Abroad</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull contentFirst"> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html">
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/01/22/business/apple/apple-custom1.jpg"/> 
</div>
</a>
<p class="credit">Donald Chan/Reuters</p>
<p class="caption">People flooded Foxconn Technology with r&eacute;sum&eacute;s at a 2010 job fair.</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html">How the U.S. Lost Out on iPhone Work</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span><a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/d/charles_duhigg/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by Charles Duhigg" class="meta-per">CHARLES DUHIGG</a> and <a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/keith_bradsher/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by Keith Bradsher" class="meta-per">KEITH BRADSHER</a></span></p>
<p class="lead">Apple has become one of the most admired companies on earth, but Apple and many of its high-technology peers are not nearly as avid in creating American jobs as other companies were in their heydays.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/23/charles-duhigg-responds-to-readers-on-apple-and-the-ieconomy/">
Charles Duhigg Responds to Readers on Apple and the iEconomy										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/01/20/business/the-iphone-economy.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/01/20/business/video-apple-motion-graphic/video-apple-motion-graphic-thumbWide.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit"></p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/01/20/business/the-iphone-economy.html">Motion Graphic: The iPhone Economy</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span>AMANDA COX, CHARLES DUHIGG, XAQU&Iacute;N G.V., MIKA GR&Ouml;NDAHL, HAEYOUN PARK, GRAHAM ROBERTS, KARL RUSSELL</span></p>
<p class="lead">Apple&rsquo;s iPhone is a model of American ingenuity, but most of its components are manufactured somewhere else. The decline of manufacturing can lead to the loss of other kinds of jobs.</p>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div> 
</div>
<div class="update "> 
<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_2:_A_Punishing_System">Part 2: A Punishing System</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull contentFirst"> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/01/26/business/26appletwo_337/26appletwo_337-custom1.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">Color China Photo, via Associated Press</p>
<p class="caption">An explosion last May at a Foxconn factory in Chengdu, China, killed four people and injured 18. It built iPads.</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html">In China, Human Costs Are Built Into an iPad</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span><a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/d/charles_duhigg/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by Charles Duhigg" class="meta-per">CHARLES DUHIGG</a> and <a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/david_barboza/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by David Barboza" class="meta-per">DAVID BARBOZA</a></span></p>
<p class="lead">The workers assembling iPhones, iPads and other devices often labor in harsh conditions, according to employees inside those plants, worker advocates and documents published by companies themselves.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/facebook-chat-about-the-ieconomy-series/">
Facebook Chat About the &lsquo;iEconomy&rsquo; Series										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/video/business/100000001313019/made-in-china.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/01/25/business/video-bdl-foxconn/video-bdl-foxconn-thumbWide.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit"></p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/video/business/100000001313019/made-in-china.html">Video: Made in China</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span>Jonah M. Kessel</span> and <span>Mac William Bishop </span></p>
<p class="lead">Workers assembling iPads, iPhones and other products often work in abusive, sometimes deadly conditions. Employees of Foxconn offered a glimpse inside their factory in Chengdu.</p>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/chinese-readers-on-the-ieconomy/"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/01/25/business/caixin-1/caixin-1-articleInline.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit"></p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/chinese-readers-on-the-ieconomy/">Chinese Readers on the &lsquo;iEconomy&rsquo;</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span>THE NEW YORK TIMES</span></p>
<p class="lead">The Times joined with Caixin, a Chinese business magazine, to publish this article in Chinese. Here are translations of some Chinese readers' responses.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/27/voices-of-chinese-workers-in-the-ieconomy/">
Listening to the Voices of Foxconn Workers										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div>

<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_3:_Protecting_Profits">Part 3: Protecting Profits</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/04/29/business/29appletax/29appletax-articleInline.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">David Calvert for The New York Times</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html">How Apple Sidesteps Billions in Global Taxes</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span><a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/d/charles_duhigg/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by Charles Duhigg" class="meta-per">CHARLES DUHIGG</a> and <a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/david_kocieniewski/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by David Kocieniewski" class="meta-per">DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI</a></span></p>
<p class="lead">Apple serves as a window on how technology giants have taken advantage of tax codes written for an industrial age and ill-suited to today&rsquo;s digital economy.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-response-on-its-tax-practices.html">
Apple&rsquo;s Response on Its Tax Practices										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/04/28/business/Shrinking-Corporate-Tax-Rates.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/graphic_icon.gif" />
Graphic: Shrinking Corporate Tax Rates										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/04/28/business/Double-Irish-With-A-Dutch-Sandwich.html?ref=business">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/graphic_icon.gif" />
Graphic: One Technique Apple Pioneered										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://video.nytimes.com/video/2012/04/30/business/100000001518212/business-day-live-april-30-2012.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/video_icon.gif" />
Video: Charles Duhigg and David Kocieniewski Respond to Reader Questions and Comments										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>

<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_4:_Retailing's_King">Part 4: Retailing's King</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/06/24/business/24retail-ss-slide-XFD8/24retail-ss-slide-XFD8-thumbWide.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">Richard Drew/Associated Press</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html">Apple&rsquo;s Retail Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span><a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/topics/reference/timestopics/people/s/david_segal/index.html" title="More Articles by David Segal" class="meta-per">DAVID SEGAL</a></span></p>
<p class="lead">While consumers tend to think of Apple&rsquo;s headquarters as the company&rsquo;s heart and soul, a majority of its employees in the United States work at its retail stores.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://video.nytimes.com/video/2012/06/25/business/100000001626958/business-day-live-apple-stores.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/video_icon.gif" />
Video: David Segal Responds to Reader Questions and Comments										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div>

<div class="clear"></div>

<div class="update "> 
<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_5:_The_Impossible_Made_Possible">Part 5: The Impossible Made Possible</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/05/business/the-ieconomy-nissans-move-to-us-offers-lessons-for-tech-industry.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/08/05/business/05transplant-span/05transplant-span-thumbWide.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">Josh Anderson for The New York Times</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/05/business/the-ieconomy-nissans-move-to-us-offers-lessons-for-tech-industry.html">In Wooing of Nissan, a Lesson for Tech Jobs?</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span><a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/topics/reference/timestopics/people/v/bill_vlasic/index.html" title="More Articles by Bill Vlasic" class="meta-per">BILL VLASIC</a> and <a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/topics/reference/timestopics/people/t/hiroko_tabuchi/index.html" title="More Articles by Hiroko Tabuchi" class="meta-per">HIROKO TABUCHI</a> and <a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/d/charles_duhigg/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by Charles Duhigg" class="meta-per">CHARLES DUHIGG</a></span></p>
<p class="lead">Although the car and technology industries are different, the resurgence of American auto manufacturing in the 1980s is an example of how one industry created tens of thousands of good jobs.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/08/05/business/evolution-of-a-manufacturing-supply-chain.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/graphic_icon.gif" />
Graphic: Evolution of a Manufacturing Supply Chain										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2012/07/22/technology/05transplants-slide.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/slideshow_icon.gif" />
Slide Show: An Automaker Migrates to Tennessee										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2012/08/05/should-the-us-seek-more-tech-manufacturing/">
Room for Debate: Should the U.S. Seek More Tech Manufacturing?										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div> 
</div>

<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_6:_Artificial_Competence">Part 6: Artificial Competence</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/19/business/new-wave-of-adept-robots-is-changing-global-industry.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/08/19/business/robot/robot-thumbWide.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">Lianne Milton for The New York Times</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/19/business/new-wave-of-adept-robots-is-changing-global-industry.html">New Wave of Adept Robots Is Changing Global Industry</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span><a rel="author" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/john_markoff/index.html" title="More Articles by John Markoff" class="meta-per">JOHN MARKOFF</a></span></p>
<p class="lead">Robots far more adept than those now commonly used by automakers and other industries are replacing workers in both manufacturing and distribution.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/video/2012/08/18/business/100000001728117/the-robot-factory-future.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/video_icon.gif" />
Video: The Robot Factory Future										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>

<div class="update "> 
<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_7:_A_System_in_Disarray">Part 7: A System in Disarray</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/08/technology/patent-wars-among-tech-giants-can-stifle-competition.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/10/08/technology/PATENTS/PATENTS-articleInline.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">J. Emilio Flores for The New York Times</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/08/technology/patent-wars-among-tech-giants-can-stifle-competition.html">The Patent, Mighty as a Sword</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span>CHARLES DUHIGG and STEVE LOHR</span></p>
<p class="lead">Alongside the impressive technological advances of the last two decades, software patents started to be used as destructive weapons, stifling competition.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/10/07/business/patents.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/interactive_icon.gif" />
For Software, Cracks in the Patent System										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/10/08/business/Fighters-in-a-Patent-War.html">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/interactive_icon.gif" />
Fighters in a Patent War										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div> 
</div>
<div class="update "> 
<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_8:_Writing_the_Software">Part 8: Writing the Software</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/18/business/as-boom-lures-app-creators-tough-part-is-making-a-living.html?hp"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/11/18/us/jp-apps-3/jp-apps-3-articleInline.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">Daniel Rosenbaum for The New York Times</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/18/business/as-boom-lures-app-creators-tough-part-is-making-a-living.html?hp">As Boom Lures App Creators, Tough Part Is Making a Living</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span>DAVID STREITFELD</span></p>
<p class="lead">App developers have turned cellphones and tablets into powerful tools, spawning a multibillion-dollar industry but making huge sacrifices in the process.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/11/18/business/App-Writing-A-Good-Job-Prospect-This-Decade.html?ref=business">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/graphic_icon.gif" />
Job Prospects for App Writers										</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/18/business/what-it-takes-to-be-an-app-developer.html?ref=business">
What It Takes to Be an App Developer										</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div>

<div class="update "> 
<p class="updateLabel"> 
<a name="Part_9:_The_Road_to_Reform">Part 9: The Road to Reform</a> 
</p>
<div class="block blockFull"> 
<div class="contentColumn contentColumnLast"> 
<div class="contentFull "> 
<div class="content">
<div class="imgWrapper">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/27/business/signs-of-changes-taking-hold-in-electronics-factories-in-china.html"> 
<div class="imgCtnt">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/28/business/video-ieconomy-factory/video-ieconomy-factory-thumbWide.jpg"/> 
</div> 
</a>
<p class="credit">Jonah M. Kessel</p>
</div>
<h3>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/27/business/signs-of-changes-taking-hold-in-electronics-factories-in-china.html">Signs of Changes Taking Hold in Electronics Factories in China</a>
</h3>
<p class="byline">By <span>KEITH BRADSHER and CHARLES DUHIGG</span></p>
<p class="lead">After the hardships of workers in China&rsquo;s electronics factories were exposed to a global audience, working conditions have started to changed.</p>
<ul class="headlinesOnly">
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/video/business/100000001974026/the-ieconomy-factory-upgrade.html?ref=business"> <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/interactive_icon.gif" /> Video: Factory Upgrade</a>
</h5>
</li>
<li>
<h5>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/12/27/business/Improving-Working-Conditions-at-Foxconn.html?ref=business"> <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/multimedia/icons/interactive_icon.gif" /> Graphic: Improving Working Conditions at Foxconn</a>
</h5>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div>
<div class="clear"></div> 
</div> 
</div>
</div>
<div class="topicUpdateDigestSideBar">
<div class="sideBarCtnt">
<div class="freeform">
<p class="intro">Comments</p>				<div class="story comment">
<p class="lead">Apple's purpose is not to create jobs. No company's purpose is to create jobs. The purpose of a company is to make money. The fact that so many people and politicians can't grasp this is at the root of our economic problems.
</p>
<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=11"> Tyrone &middot; NYC </a>
</h5>
</div>
<div class="story comment">
<p class="lead">Many consumers do not know where their smartphones are made, but they should definitely care. A weak manufacturing sector is a drag on the entire economy and all Americans. Manufacturing jobs used to provide work for many middle class Americans, especially workers with limited education.
</p>
<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=11"> pjd &middot; Westford </a>
</h5>
</div>
<div class="story comment">
<p class="lead">Much of the activity inside the Nissan Smyrna plant is simply assembly from parts shipped from Canada, Mexico and Asia. What we need to do is mandate a greater percentage of American parts be used in automobiles manufactured here. That would be a way of creating more good paying jobs here.
</p>
<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=11"> clydemallory &middot; St Albans, VT </a>
</h5>
</div>
<div class="story comment">
<p class="lead">American (and European and Asian) companies have aggressively sought to move jobs to low wage countries like China, opening factories there, training workers, and transferring technology. The supply chain Apple so admires in China wasn't home-grown, it was built by outside companies.
</p>
<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=11">John K &middot; Durham </a>
</h5>
</div>
<div class="story comment">	<p class="lead">The products sell themselves. Being an order taker is not the same as being a salesperson. Most of the Apple stores' sales staff are little more than mobile cashiers.	</p>		<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=11">Carlos &middot; Astoria, NY</a>		</h5></div><div class="story comment">	<p class="lead">Apple is taking advantage of the economic mess and enjoying extra profit on the backs of its lowest employees.	</p>		<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=53">Jud Lohmeyer &middot; San Miguel Allende, Guanajuato, Mexico</a>		</h5></div><div class="story comment">	<p class="lead">Apple employees shouldn't be paid significantly more than other floor workers at other retail stores just because Apple products are expensive and desirable and bring in a lot of revenue.	</p>		<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=374">Nicole &middot; Stanford, Calif.</a>		</h5></div><div class="story comment">	<p class="lead">Until those employees unionize, they'll continue to get the smallest crumbs possible.	</p>		<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=12">A. &middot; NY</a>		</h5></div><div class="story comment">	<p class="lead">Henry Ford realized many years ago that in order for his company to succeed his workers had to be paid wages high enough in order for them to purchase the products the company produced.	</p>		<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=461">Red &middot; Central Pennsylvania</a>		</h5></div><div class="story comment">	<p class="lead">Apple is able to do this because Apple can recruit employees from its cult-like user base. They have users who would work for free because of their religious devotion to Apple products.	</p>		<h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/business/apple-store-workers-loyal-but-short-on-pay.html?comments#permid=47">TB &middot; Philadelphia</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Anyone who doesn't take advantage of the tax laws is negligent. If we don't like it, simplify the tax code. .</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html?comments#permid=386">Tim &middot; Chicago</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">These profits are possible because of the infrastructure and society that the US uniquely provides. If not Apple would be a company that originated in another country.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html?comments#permid=457">JKvam &middot; Minneapolis, Minn.</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Apple employees add a great deal to California's and local Bay Area community tax base with the taxes they pay. How to split taxes between companies that create jobs like Apple and the employees who are also tax paying citizens of the communities they live in is a problem much bigger than Apple.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html?comments#permid=50">JL &middot; Bay Area, Calif.</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Apple isn't doing anything different than we individual Americans would do. When it comes to paying Uncle Sam, the strategy for the vast majority, is to pay as little as is legally possible. And why not - the government's greatest talent is wasting taxpayer dollars. Hopefully, Apple contributes generously to US charities, benefiting Americans in ways the government does not.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html?comments#permid=6">FJM &middot;NYC</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">The fundamental flaw is that all federal corporate tax returns of public corporations should be made public. And those returns should be reconciled with all SEC filings. The interested public has a right to know since only public charters allow the corporate form.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html?comments#permid=21">William R. Cumming &middot;Reedville, VA 22539</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">I expect better of Apple. But I guess that they are no different than all the other large corporations paying 19th Century taxes in the 21st Century. What a bunch of incompetents and sell-outs we have in our Congress!</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/business/apples-tax-strategy-aims-at-low-tax-states-and-nations.html?comments#permid=1">Harveydad &middot;Melbourne Florida</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">What responsibility does the consumer bear to 1) inquire about who makes their silly gadgets and 2) the human cost?</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=59:20">Erika &middot; NYC</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Wouldn't it be wonderful if Apple could change the world again?-- this time on the production side of things?</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=148">VA &middot; Fairfax, CA</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">It is unreasonable to single out Apple, as opposed to any other company which manufacturers products in countries without adequate labor protection laws.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=159">Shiroto &middot; San Francisco</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Perhaps Apple should start asking themselves if it may be worth just charging the extra $65 for the Ipad -- the extra amount they say it would cost to have it made in the U.S.A.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=171">eb &middot; Miami Beach</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Since 40% of the world's electronics come from Foxconn, all the companies involved could agree to better working conditions for their suppliers' workers, but Apple is probably the only company positioned to lead such an effort.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=196">Midnight Mail &middot; Hell's Kitchen NYC</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">It's time for more personally valued, fulfilling, and life affirming work for workers&ndash; not soul deadening mass production work.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=148:158">    s3adog &middot; Madison, WI</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Apple is a trans-national corporation; it does NOT owe any allegiance to the United States or any other nation; it owes its only allegiance to itself.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html?comments#permid=31">Jack Weiss &middot; Shrub Oak, NY</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Because of overseas manufacturing, the California schoolteacher who buys an iPhone has an extra $30 in her wallet, and an extra $10 or $20 in her 401K.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html?comments#permid=57">Luke McCormick &middot; Oakland, CA</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Consumers (mostly) look for the cheapest price to pay and companies will chose labor which is willing to work at a cheaper rate and less cost to the company.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html?comments#permid=239">Lisa &middot; New York</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Apple has created an amazing amount of software development jobs in the US.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html?comments#permid=264">CaliforniaBusinessOwner &middot; Orange County, Ca</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Wages are going up very rapidly across China and particularly at factories such as Foxconn's. The increases would be breathtaking from a Western perspective.</p><h5><a href="http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/chinese-readers-on-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=11">Nathan an Expat &middot; China</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">We need to remind these companies that there's marketable value in doing the right things.</p><h5><a href="http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/chinese-readers-on-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=22">CTRose &middot; CT, USA</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">This article ignores a living standard common to hundreds of millions of workers, and instead solely focuses on Foxconn and the large shadow it casts.</p><h5><a href="http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/chinese-readers-on-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=25">CT &middot; California</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">I would be willing to pay a premium to know my purchase was going to support more jobs in the US.</p><h5><a href="http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/23/charles-duhigg-responds-to-readers-on-apple-and-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=3">Aspen &middot; New York City</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">Apple is kidding itself if it believes it can blame their decision to outsource assembly on the fact the American workers aren't "skilled" enough. It comes down to cold efficiency.</p><h5><a href="http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/23/charles-duhigg-responds-to-readers-on-apple-and-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=97">Alyssa Sittig &middot; San Francisco, CA</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">China is simply like the United States and England were during the Industrial Revolution. </p><h5><a href="http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/23/charles-duhigg-responds-to-readers-on-apple-and-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=57">Jake &middot; Texas</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">What I don't understand is why these companies assume there is only a market for the lowest priced product and not also one for customers who want to pay more for a product made in the USA.</p><h5><a href="http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/23/charles-duhigg-responds-to-readers-on-apple-and-the-ieconomy/?comments#permid=61">Diana Stark &middot; California</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">We need a global movement so that long term public well-being is served by business, not destroyed by it.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=214">Cassandra &middot; Boston</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">What happens to these Chinese workers if, as some suggest, the world was to shut down the 'evil empire' known as Apple?</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/business/ieconomy-apples-ipad-and-the-human-costs-for-workers-in-china.html?comments#permid=172">EZ &middot; Sacramento, CA</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">It's one thing to maximize profits; it's another thing entirely to make so much money at the expense of exploiting workers in China.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html?comments#permid=1">Charley James &middot; Minneapolis MN</a></h5></div><div class="story comment"><p class="lead">You can't really blame companies like Apple, which have to compete on price and features. It's the government that's let us down.</p><h5><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/22/business/apple-america-and-a-squeezed-middle-class.html?comments#permid=4">Josh Hill &middot; New London</a></h5></div>					</div>
<div class="freeform">

var blacklist = '123 123 123';
// Leave the rest as is: //

if(f&&f.className&&f.className.indexOf('freeform')>-1){

}
}

<script type="text/javascript">
var PREBID_TIMEOUT = 300;
var googletag = googletag || {};
googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error
    var mnSrc = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https:' : 'http:') + '//contextual.media.net/bidexchange.js?cid=8CU2553YN';
    document.write('<scr' + 'ipt type="text/javascript" src="' + mnSrc + '"></scr' + 'ipt>');
})();
</script>

<article id="story" class="story theme-main">

        
    <header id="story-header" class="story-header">
        
                <div id="story-meta" class="story-meta ">
                            <div class="ad sponsortile-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
                    <div class="caption">Supported by</div>
                    <div id="sponsortile" class="ad sponsortile-ad-creative"></div>
                </div>
                                        <h3 class="kicker">
                        <span class="kicker-label"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/books/review/index.html">Sunday Book Review</a></span>                                                                </h3>
                        			<h2 id="story-heading" class="story-heading">Seat of Power</h2>
		<h1 itemprop="headline" id="story-deck" class="deck">‘The Passage of Power,’ Robert Caro’s New L.B.J. Book</h1>
                            <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">
                                                                                    

<p class="byline-dateline"><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" >By <span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="BILL CLINTON" itemprop="name">BILL CLINTON</span></span><time class="dateline" datetime="2012-05-02" itemprop="datePublished" content="2012-05-02">MAY 2, 2012</time>
</p>
                                    <div class="inside-story">
                        <span class="menu-label">Inside</span>
                        <ul class="inside-story-menu"></ul>
                    </div>
                                                    <button class="button comments-button  theme-kicker" data-skip-to-para-id="">
</button>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->
        </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </header>

    <div id="story-body" class="story-body">

        
        
        <div class="lede-container">
                        <div class="lede-container-ads">
                                                    <div id="lede-ad" class="ad lede-ad marginalia-anchor-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
                                                            </div>
        </div>

        <div id="byline-sharetools-container" class="byline-sharetools-container">
                                                    <div id="sharetools-story" aria-label="tools" role="group" class="sharetools theme-classic  sharetools-story  "
data-shares="email,facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet,pinterest|Pin,save,show-all|more,ad"
data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/06/books/review/the-passage-of-power-robert-caros-new-lbj-book.html"
data-title="‘The Passage of Power,’ Robert Caro’s New L.B.J. Book"
data-author="By BILL CLINTON"
data-media="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/05/06/books/review/0506-CLINTON-cover/0506-CLINTON-cover-jumbo.jpg"
data-description="The fourth volume of Robert Caro’s series on Lyndon Johnson starts shortly before the 1960 presidential election and ends a few months after John F. Kennedy’s assassination."
	data-publish-date="May 2, 2012"
>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
<span class="sharetools-label visually-hidden">Share This Page</span>
<div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
<div id="MiddleLeft" class="ad middle-left-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
</div><!-- close shareTools -->
                    </div>


                
        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="386" data-total-count="386" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-1">“The Passage of Power,” the fourth installment of Robert Caro’s brilliant series on Lyndon Johnson, spans roughly five years, beginning shortly before the 1960 presidential contest, including the Bay of Pigs, the Cuban missile crisis and other seminal events of the Kennedy years, and ending a few months after the awful afternoon in Dallas that elevated L.B.J. to the presidency.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="283" data-total-count="669" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-2">Among the most interesting and important episodes Caro chronicles are those involving the new president’s ability to maneuver bills out of legislative committees and onto the floor of the House and Senate for a vote. One of those bills would later become the 1964 Civil Rights Act.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

                <header>
        <h2 class="module-heading">
                            Related Coverage
                    </h2>
    </header>

                <div class="media-action-overlay"><i class="icon sprite-icon slideshow-icon"></i>

                        <span class="story-heading-text">Seat of Power</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2012-05-01" itemprop="datePublished" content="2012-05-01">MAY 1, 2012</time>

                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/05/06/nyregion/06ROUTINE2_SPAN/06ROUTINE2_SPAN-thumbStandard.jpg" alt="Robert A. Caro and his wife, Ina, walk through Central Park on their way to the Metropolitan Museum of Art." />

        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">Sunday Routine: On Sundays, Robert A. Caro Writes, Always Dressed Up</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2012-05-04" itemprop="datePublished" content="2012-05-04">MAY 4, 2012</time>

        </div><!-- close nocontent -->
    </aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="531" data-total-count="1200" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-3">You don’t have to be a policy wonk to marvel at the political skill L.B.J. wielded to resuscitate a bill that seemed doomed to never get a vote on the floor of either chamber. Southern Democrats were masters at bottling up legislation they hated, particularly bills expanding civil rights for black Americans. Their skills at obstruction were so admired that the newly sworn-in Johnson was firmly counseled by an ally against using the political capital he’d inherited as a result of the assassination on such a hopeless cause.</p><figure id="media-100000001500911" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency has-lede-adjacency layout-large-vertical media-100000001500911" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/05/06/books/review/0506-CLINTON-cover/0506-CLINTON-cover-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/05/06/books/review/0506-CLINTON-cover/0506-CLINTON-cover-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/05/06/books/review/0506-CLINTON-cover/0506-CLINTON-cover-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="" data-mediaviewer-credit="Illustration by David Plunkert"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/05/06/books/review/0506-CLINTON-cover/0506-CLINTON-cover-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="500" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="435" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Illustration by David Plunkert        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="87" data-total-count="1287" itemprop="reviewBody">According to Caro, Johnson responded, “Well, what the hell’s the presidency for?”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="492" data-total-count="1779" itemprop="reviewBody">This is the question every president must ask and answer. For Lyndon Johnson in the final weeks of 1963, the presidency was <em>for</em> two things: passing a civil rights bill with teeth, to replace the much weaker 1957 law he’d helped to pass as Senate majority leader, and launching the War on Poverty. That neither of these causes was in fact hopeless was clear possibly only to him, as few Americans in our history have matched Johnson’s knowledge of how to move legislation, and legislators.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="607" data-total-count="2386" itemprop="reviewBody">It’s wonderful to watch Johnson’s confidence catch fire and spread to the shellshocked survivors of the Kennedy administration as it dawned on them that the man who was once Master of the Senate would now be a chief executive with more ability to move legislation through the House and Senate than just about any other president in history. Johnson’s fire spread outward until it touched the entire country during his first State of the Union address. The words were written by Kennedy’s speechwriter Ted Sorensen, but their impact would be felt in the magic L.B.J. worked over the next seven weeks.</p><div id="Moses" class="ad moses-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="194" data-total-count="2580" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-4">Exactly how L.B.J. did it was perfectly captured later by Hubert Humphrey — the man the president chose as his vote counter for the civil rights bill and his Senate proxy to carve its passage.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-5">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="55" data-total-count="2635" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-5">Humphrey said Johnson “knew just how to get to me.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="767" data-total-count="3402" itemprop="reviewBody">In sparkling detail, Caro shows the new president’s genius for getting to people — friends, foes and everyone in between — and how he used it to achieve his goals. We’ve all seen the iconic photos of L.B.J. leaning into a conversation, poking his thick finger into a confidant’s chest or wrapping his long arm around a shoulder. At 6 foot 4, he towered over most men, but even seated Johnson commanded from on high. Caro relates how during a conversation about civil rights, he placed Roy Wilkins and his N.A.A.C.P. entourage on one of the couches in the Oval Office, yet still towered over them as he sat up close in his rocking chair. And he didn’t need to be in the same room — he was great at manipulating, cajoling and even bullying over the phone.</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="66" data-total-count="3468" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-6">He knew just how to get to you, and he was relentless in doing it.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="472" data-total-count="3940" itemprop="reviewBody">If you were a partisan, he’d call on your patriotism; if a traditionalist, he’d make his proposal seem to be the Establishment choice. His flattery was minutely detailed, finely tuned and perfectly modulated. So was his bombast — whatever worked. L.B.J. didn’t kiss Sam Rayburn’s ring, but his lips did press against his bald head. Harry Byrd received deference and attention. When L.B.J. became president, he finally had the power to match his political skills.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="575" data-total-count="4515" itemprop="reviewBody">The other remarkable part of this volume covers the tribulation before the triumphs: the lost campaign and the interminable years as vice president, in which L.B.J.’s skills were stymied and his power was negligible. He had little to do, less to say, and no defense against the indignities the Kennedys’ inner circle heaped on him. The Master of the Senate may have become its president, but in title only. He might have agreed with his fellow Texan John Nance Garner, F.D.R.’s vice president, who famously described the office as “not worth a bucket of warm spit.”</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-7">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="687" data-total-count="5202" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-7">Caro paints a vivid picture of L.B.J.’s misery. We can feel Johnson’s ambition ebb, and believe with him that his political life was over, as he was shut out of meetings, unwelcome on Air Force One, mistrusted and despised by Robert Kennedy. While in Congress he may not have been universally admired among the Washington elite, and was even mocked by them as a bit of a rube. But he had certainly never been <em>pitied</em>. In the White House, he invented reasons to come to the outskirts of the Oval Office in the mornings, where he was rarely welcome, and made sure his presence was noted by Kennedy’s staff. Even if they did not respect him, he wasn’t going to let anyone forget him.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="544" data-total-count="5746" itemprop="reviewBody">Then tragedy changed everything. Within hours of President Kennedy’s assassination, Johnson was sworn in as president, without the pomp of an inauguration, but with all the powers of the office. At first he was careful in wielding them. He didn’t move into the Oval Office for days, running the executive branch from Room 274 in the Executive Office Building. The family didn’t move into the White House residence until Dec. 7. But soon enough, it would become clear that the power Johnson had grasped for his entire life was finally his.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-8">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="376" data-total-count="6122" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-8">As Caro shows in this and his preceding volumes, power ultimately reveals character. For L.B.J., becoming president freed him to embrace parts of his past that, for political or other reasons, had remained under wraps. Suddenly there was no longer a reason to dissociate himself from the poverty and failure of his childhood. Power released the source of Johnson’s humanity.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="428" data-total-count="6550" itemprop="reviewBody">Last year I was privileged to speak at the funeral of Sargent Shriver — a man who served L.B.J. but who in many ways was his temperamental opposite. I said then that too many of us spend too much time worrying about advancement or personal gain at the expense of effort. We might fail, but we need to get caught <em>trying</em>. That was Shriver’s great virtue. With Johnson’s election he actually had the chance to try and to win.</p><div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="534" data-total-count="7084" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-9">Even as Barry Goldwater was midwifing the antigovernment movement that would grow to such dominance decades later, L.B.J., Shriver and other giants of the civil rights and anti­poverty movements seemed to rise all around me as I was beginning my political involvement. They believed government had an essential part to play in expanding civil rights and reducing poverty and inequality. It soon became clear that <em>hearts</em> needed to be changed, along with laws. Not just Congress, but the American people themselves needed to be <em>got to</em>.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="462" data-total-count="7546" itemprop="reviewBody">It was hard to do, absent a crisis like the losses of President Kennedy, Martin Luther King and Robert Kennedy. By the late 1960s, America’s increasing involvement and frustration in Vietnam, the rise of more militant civil rights leaders and riots in many cities, and the end of broad-based economic growth that had indeed “lifted all boats” in the early ’60s, made it harder and harder to win more converts to the civil rights and anti­poverty causes.</p><button class="button comments-button  theme-speech-bubble" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-10">
</button>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="622" data-total-count="8168" itemprop="reviewBody" id="story-continues-10">But for a few brief years, Lyndon Johnson, once a fairly conventional Southern Democrat, constrained by his constituents and his overriding hunger for power, rose above his political past and personal limitations, to embrace and promote his boyhood dreams of opportunity and equality for all Americans. After all the years of striving for power, once he had it, he said to the American people, “I’ll let you in on a secret — I mean to use it.” And use it he did to pass the Civil Rights Act, the Voting Rights Act, the open housing law, the antipoverty legislation, Medicare and Medicaid, Head Start and much more.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="174" data-total-count="8342" itemprop="reviewBody">He knew what the presidency was for: to get to people — to members of Congress, often with tricks up his sleeve; to the American people, by wearing his heart on his sleeve.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="427" data-total-count="8769" itemprop="reviewBody">Even when we parted company over the Vietnam War, I never hated L.B.J. the way many young people of my generation came to. I couldn’t. What he did to advance civil rights and equal opportunity was too important. I remain grateful to him. L.B.J. got to me, and after all these years, he still does. With this fascinating and meticulous account of how and why he did it, Robert Caro has once again done America a great service.</p>
        
        <div class="story-body-text story-content book-review-information"><div class="story">
<h4><p class="nitf">THE PASSAGE OF POWER</p></h4>
<h5><p class="nitf">The Years of Lyndon Johnson</p></h5>
<p class="summary">By Robert A. Caro</p>
<p class="summary">Illustrated. 712 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.</p>
</div>
</div>
                                <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
                <div class="story-notes"><p>Bill Clinton was the 42nd president of the United States.</p></div>
        
        
        <p class="story-print-citation">A version of this review appears in print on May 6, 2012, on page BR1 of the <span itemprop="printEdition">Sunday Book Review</span> with the headline: Seat of Power. <span class="story-footer-links">  <span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/todayspaper/index.html" target="_blank">Today's Paper</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span><span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/subscriptions/Multiproduct/lp839RF.html?campaignId=48JQY" target="_blank">Subscribe</a></span>
</span>
</p>
    </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </footer>

        
                    <nav id="next-in"></nav><!-- close next-in -->
            </div><!-- close story-body -->
</article>

                                    <li>
                                        <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/store/?&t=qry542&utm_source=nytimes&utm_medium=HPB&utm_content=hp_browsetree&utm_campaign=NYT-HP&module=SectionsNav&action=click&region=TopBar&version=BrowseTree&contentCollection=NYT%20Store&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=Homepage">NYT Store</a>
                                    </li>

                                                                                            
                                    <li>

<script type="text/javascript">
var PREBID_TIMEOUT = 300;
var googletag = googletag || {};
googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error

})();
