<article id="story" class="story theme-main">

        
    <header id="story-header" class="story-header">
        
                <div id="story-meta" class="story-meta ">
                            <div class="ad sponsortile-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
                    <div class="caption">Supported by</div>
                    <div id="sponsortile" class="ad sponsortile-ad-creative"></div>
                </div>
                                        <h3 class="kicker">
                        <span class="kicker-label"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/nyregion/index.html">N.Y. / Region</a></span>                                                                </h3>
                        	<h1 itemprop="headline" id="story-heading" class="story-heading">How a Beach Community Became a Deathtrap</h1>
                        <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">
                                                                                    

<p class="byline-dateline"><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/kirk_semple/index.html">By <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/kirk_semple/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by KIRK SEMPLE"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="KIRK SEMPLE" itemprop="name" data-twitter-handle="KirkSemple">KIRK SEMPLE</span></a> and </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/g/joseph_goldstein/index.html"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/g/joseph_goldstein/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN" itemprop="name" data-twitter-handle="JoeKGoldstein">JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN</span></a></span><time class="dateline" datetime="2012-11-10" itemprop="datePublished" content="2012-11-10">NOV. 10, 2012</time>
</p>
                                    <div class="inside-story">
                        <span class="menu-label">Inside</span>
                        <ul class="inside-story-menu"></ul>
                    </div>
                                                    <button class="button comments-button  theme-kicker" data-skip-to-para-id="">
</button>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->
        </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </header>

    <div id="story-body" class="story-body">

        
        
        <div class="lede-container">
            <figure id="media-100000001896239" class="media photo lede layout-large-horizontal" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/staten-island/staten-island-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/staten-island/staten-island-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/staten-island/staten-island-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Hugo Cuem mourning his brother-in-law Eugene Contrubis, who drowned in his Staten Island home." data-mediaviewer-credit="Todd Heisler/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/staten-island/staten-island-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="330" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Hugo Cuem mourning his brother-in-law Eugene Contrubis, who drowned in his Staten Island home.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Todd Heisler/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
            <div class="lede-container-ads">
                                                    <div id="lede-ad" class="ad lede-ad marginalia-anchor-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
                                                            </div>
        </div>

        <div id="byline-sharetools-container" class="byline-sharetools-container">
                                                    <div id="sharetools-story" aria-label="tools" role="group" class="sharetools theme-classic  sharetools-story  "
data-shares="email,facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet,save,show-all|more,ad"
data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/11/nyregion/how-a-staten-island-community-became-a-deathtrap.html"
data-title="How a Staten Island Community Became a Deathtrap"
data-author="By KIRK SEMPLE and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN"
data-media="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/10/nyregion/StatenIsland-ss-slide-RU1T/StatenIsland-ss-slide-RU1T-jumbo.jpg"
data-description="Eight deaths in a Staten Island enclave during Hurricane Sandy have raised questions about why the victims were in their homes when the storm hit and whether the city bore some responsibility for their failure to evacuate."
	data-publish-date="November 10, 2012"
>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
<span class="sharetools-label visually-hidden">Share This Page</span>
<div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
<div id="MiddleLeft" class="ad middle-left-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
</div><!-- close shareTools -->
                    </div>


                
        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="385" data-total-count="385" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1">Eugene Contrubis heard the many warnings about <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/h/hurricanes_and_tropical_storms/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier" title="More articles about Hurricane Sandy." class="meta-classifier">Hurricane Sandy</a> but decided to ride it out in his drafty, one-story bungalow at 162 Kiswick Street, near the beach on Staten Island. Soft-spoken and frail, he was a retired Police Department clerk who wrote poetry, enjoyed chess and adored his nieces. When they were children, he hung a swing from a tree in his yard for them to play on.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="138" data-total-count="523" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">Mr. Contrubis had lived alone since his mother’s death a few years ago. He had outlasted storms before. This one would be no different.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="155" data-total-count="678" itemprop="articleBody">As night fell on Monday, Oct. 29, Mr. Contrubis, 67, talked by phone with his brother-in-law. The wind had felled some branches, he reported, nothing more.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="188" data-total-count="866" itemprop="articleBody">But around 6:45 p.m., water from Lower New York Bay breached the beachfront road and poured into Mr. Contrubis’s neighborhood, knocking out power and eventually swallowing entire blocks.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="98" data-total-count="964" itemprop="articleBody">At some point, Mr. Contrubis left a message on the voice mail of his sister, Christina Contrubis.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

                <header>
        <h2 class="module-heading">
                            Related Coverage
                    </h2>
    </header>

            <ul>
                                                            <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2012/11/10/nyregion/StatenIsland-ss.html">

                    <div class="thumb">
                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/10/nyregion/StatenIsland-ss-slide-RU1T/StatenIsland-ss-slide-RU1T-thumbStandard.jpg" alt="" />
                <div class="media-action-overlay"><i class="icon sprite-icon slideshow-icon"></i>
<span class="visually-hidden">slideshow</span>
</div>
            </div>
        
        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">One Neighborhood, Unimaginable Loss</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2012-11-10" itemprop="datePublished" content="2012-11-10">NOV. 10, 2012</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
</article>
</li>
                                                </ul>
        </div><!-- close nocontent -->
    </aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="46" data-total-count="1010" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">“The water’s coming in,” he said softly.</p><figure id="media-100000001896553" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency layout-large-horizontal media-100000001896553 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN1/jpSTATEN1-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN1/jpSTATEN1-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN1/jpSTATEN1-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Kris Elvine, a resident of Midland Beach on Staten Island, reaching for a cord from his father, Peter, after they borrowed power from a neighbor&amp;rsquo;s generator." data-mediaviewer-credit="Todd Heisler/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN1/jpSTATEN1-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="414" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="650" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Kris Elvine, a resident of Midland Beach on Staten Island, reaching for a cord from his father, Peter, after they borrowed power from a neighbor&rsquo;s generator.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Todd Heisler/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="45" data-total-count="1055" itemprop="articleBody">His body was found in his house the next day.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="397" data-total-count="1452" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Contrubis was one of eight people who drowned during Hurricane Sandy in Midland Beach, a small, low-slung neighborhood of one-story bungalows and newer two- and three-story houses. The eight lived within about eight short blocks of one another — apparently the highest concentration of deaths in the United States attributable to the storm, which killed more than 100 people in this country.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="484" data-total-count="1936" itemprop="articleBody">One of the bodies was discovered only on Friday, nearly two weeks after the storm. The deaths have raised unsettling questions about why the victims were in their homes when the storm hit and whether the city bore some responsibility for their failure to evacuate. Relatives, friends and officials have replayed the events of that night, pondering whether they should have done something different — and whether the city needs to improve its evacuation procedures for future storms.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="184" data-total-count="2120" itemprop="articleBody">Midland Beach is part of Zone A, a collection of neighborhoods in the city deemed most at risk of flooding. The city declared a mandatory evacuation of the zone before Hurricane Sandy.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="160" data-total-count="2280" itemprop="articleBody">Last year, in the days before Tropical Storm Irene, city workers visited the neighborhood, broadcasting evacuation warnings by loudspeaker, residents recalled.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="207" data-total-count="2487" itemprop="articleBody">This time, officials said, city workers were sent once again to Staten Island’s evacuation zones to issue warnings, some using loudspeakers. But many residents of Midland Beach said they did not hear them.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="302" data-total-count="2789" itemprop="articleBody">Still, it is not at all certain that such a measure, or even the police’s going door to door, would have made a difference. Like most of the neighborhood’s residents, the victims ignored numerous orders to evacuate, a decision that underscores an independent streak that runs deep on Staten Island.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="320" data-total-count="3109" itemprop="articleBody">“I tried very hard,” Ms. Contrubis said through sobs at her brother’s funeral on Monday. “Before the storm I called him up and said, ‘Gene, the storm, it looks bad!’ And he said, ‘Everybody’s staying; nobody’s leaving.’ He just told me: ‘I’m not going to leave. I’m not going to leave.’ ”</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="291" data-total-count="3400" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">The eight victims were mostly elderly — the youngest was 59. Most lived alone, and one was legally blind, paraplegic and had cerebral palsy. On that night, the neighborhood turned into a lake that was more than nine feet deep in some places — nearly enough to fill the victims’ homes.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="126" data-total-count="3526" itemprop="articleBody">Councilman <a href="http://council.nyc.gov/d50/html/members/home.shtml">James Oddo</a>, a Republican who represents the area, said he was distressed that a cluster of such deaths could occur.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="111" data-total-count="3637" itemprop="articleBody">“It weighs heavily on me,” Mr. Oddo said. “It means to a certain degree that we in government failed.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="24" data-total-count="3661" itemprop="articleBody"><strong> Lulled Into Complacency</strong></p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="336" data-total-count="3997" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Contrubis’s parents bought the bungalow at 162 Kiswick Street in the 1960s as a summer cottage. At the time, they lived in Manhattan, but Mr. Contrubis’s mother loved the beach and she eventually moved to Staten Island full time. When Mr. Contrubis returned home from the military after serving in the Vietnam War, he moved in.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="114" data-total-count="4111" itemprop="articleBody">People have long been drawn to Midland Beach for the quietude, affordable real estate and proximity to the water.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="318" data-total-count="4429" itemprop="articleBody">The neighborhood had once been largely Irish-American, but in the past few decades, it has grown more diverse, as Italian-Americans arrived, followed by Latinos and, most recently, an influx of immigrants from the former Soviet Union, some of whom had been priced out of Eastern European enclaves in southern Brooklyn.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="76" data-total-count="4505" itemprop="articleBody">For all its attractions, Midland Beach suffers a chronic problem: flooding.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="244" data-total-count="4749" itemprop="articleBody">Keri Mullen, whose family has lived for six generations in a house on Moreland Street, said she remembered when water reached her porch during a storm in the 1970s. Her parents and grandparents told her about flooding in the ’50s and ’60s.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="294" data-total-count="5043" itemprop="articleBody">In the late ’70s, the city built a storm sewer system down Greeley Avenue, on the western side of the neighborhood, which helped relieve flooding during heavy rains. More recently, the city began work on a system of wetlands on the north side of the neighborhood to help address the problem.</p><figure id="media-100000001897411" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000001897411 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/11staten-map/11staten-map-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/11staten-map/11staten-map-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/11staten-map/11staten-map-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Officials said half the residents in Zone A around the city evacuated. In Midland Beach, residents said they believed that a smaller percentage did so." data-mediaviewer-credit="The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/11staten-map/11staten-map-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="424" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="650" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Officials said half the residents in Zone A around the city evacuated. In Midland Beach, residents said they believed that a smaller percentage did so.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="281" data-total-count="5324" itemprop="articleBody">But few residents had any memory of water rising high enough to threaten homes, let alone lives. Councilman Oddo said the last time bay water crossed the neighborhood’s beachfront roadway, Father Capodanno Boulevard, was in 1992. But even then it caused relatively little damage.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="281" data-total-count="5605" itemprop="articleBody">As Hurricane Sandy approached, residents’ thoughts turned to Tropical Storm Irene. In August 2011, many, including Mr. Contrubis, had been alarmed enough by the authorities’ warnings to evacuate in advance of that storm, only to find afterward that their homes were unscathed.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="55" data-total-count="5660" itemprop="articleBody">As a result, many viewed evacuation as a waste of time.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="118" data-total-count="5778" itemprop="articleBody">“They’ve warned us so many times before and nothing happened,” said Graceanna Paterno, 45, a lifelong resident.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="146" data-total-count="5924" itemprop="articleBody">John Prisinzano, 64, who has lived on Grimsby Street for 32 years, recalled the brief conversations he had with neighbors before Hurricane Sandy.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="81" data-total-count="6005" itemprop="articleBody">“ ‘Hey, how are you doing? Are you going to stay?’ ” someone would say.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="61" data-total-count="6066" itemprop="articleBody">“ ‘Yeah, we’re going to stay,’ ” came the reply.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="60" data-total-count="6126" itemprop="articleBody">“I’m here 32 years, never had a flood,” he explained.</p><div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-5">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="250" data-total-count="6376" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-5">And so as the wind picked up on the afternoon of Oct. 29, and a light rain began to fall, many residents went inside their homes, turned on computers and television sets, fired up video games and opened books, and waited for the storm to come and go.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="17" data-total-count="6393" itemprop="articleBody"><strong>Panic in the Dark</strong></p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="117" data-total-count="6510" itemprop="articleBody">It was already dark when Laurajean Sammarco, 48, ventured to the doorstep of her house on Father Capodanno Boulevard.</p><div id="Moses" class="ad moses-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="114" data-total-count="6624" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-6">She was startled to see a surge of bay water tumbling over a barrier near the beach and rushing toward her house.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="135" data-total-count="6759" itemprop="articleBody">“I said, ‘That can’t be water!’ ” she remembered. “It wasn’t like ‘Hawaii Five-0.’ It was like ‘The Blob.’ ”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="212" data-total-count="6971" itemprop="articleBody">She started calling relatives. “I’m screaming: ‘Get out! Get out!’ ” She jumped in her car with her husband, daughter and dog and raced through the neighborhood trying to pick up relatives and friends.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="162" data-total-count="7133" itemprop="articleBody">Panic began to seize household after household in Midland Beach as water pushed relentlessly into the neighborhood, slowly in some places, more quickly in others.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="179" data-total-count="7312" itemprop="articleBody">“Calls were coming in: somebody’s calling somebody, who’s calling somebody,” said Bill Owens, a retired police officer, whose family has lived in Midland Beach since 1928.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="187" data-total-count="7499" itemprop="articleBody">Residents reported water coming not just from the direction of the bay but, in some areas, from Hylan Boulevard to the west, or pushing south from the wetlands or north from Miller Field.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="104" data-total-count="7603" itemprop="articleBody">As water arrived on his street, Mr. Owens stepped outside to move his truck from a space on the corner.</p><figure id="media-100000001896558" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000001896558 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN2/jpSTATEN2-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN2/jpSTATEN2-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN2/jpSTATEN2-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Debbie Piergiovanni with George Tormo, who evacuated Ms. Piergiovanni the day after the storm with a small boat, which he paddled using a snow shovel." data-mediaviewer-credit="Todd Heisler/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN2/jpSTATEN2-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="409" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="650" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Debbie Piergiovanni with George Tormo, who evacuated Ms. Piergiovanni the day after the storm with a small boat, which he paddled using a snow shovel.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Todd Heisler/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-7">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="23" data-total-count="7626" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-7">But he never got there.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="94" data-total-count="7720" itemprop="articleBody">Within minutes, he was swimming frantically to get to the high stoop of a neighbor’s house.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="169" data-total-count="7889" itemprop="articleBody">Some residents who lived in two- and three-story houses grabbed children and pets and ran to upper floors. But for those in bungalows, higher ground was harder to reach.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="114" data-total-count="8003" itemprop="articleBody">“All these poor old-timers,” Mr. Owens said. “They must’ve been sleeping in their beds or watching TV.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="170" data-total-count="8173" itemprop="articleBody">Two blocks east of Mr. Contrubis’s bungalow, water began seeping into the one-story bungalow on Grimsby Street where Lucy Spagnuolo and her mother, Beatrice, 79, lived.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="206" data-total-count="8379" itemprop="articleBody">The elder Ms. Spagnuolo, a widow with a heart ailment, had moved to the neighborhood more than 40 years ago with her husband, a truck driver. She had raised four sons and two daughters in their small home.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="174" data-total-count="8553" itemprop="articleBody">The younger Ms. Spagnuolo went outside to start the car, but the water had risen so fast that the engine would not work. She got out and was in waist-deep, fast-rising water.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="101" data-total-count="8654" itemprop="articleBody">She waded up the block, desperately yelling for help in the darkness. “I panicked,” she recalled.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="116" data-total-count="8770" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Prisinzano and his wife, who live across the street, were fleeing in their sedan and saw Ms. Spagnuolo shouting.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="51" data-total-count="8821" itemprop="articleBody">But they kept going. They had no choice, they said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="189" data-total-count="9010" itemprop="articleBody">“I just got to the corner and I couldn’t make out what she was saying and the water was up to the windows,” Mr. Prisinzano said. “We couldn’t get back anyway. We just got out.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="155" data-total-count="9165" itemprop="articleBody">Within minutes, the water had topped the white fence in front of the Spagnuolos’ home, and the younger Ms. Spagnuolo was unable to return to her mother.</p><div id="MiddleRight3" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-8">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="79" data-total-count="9244" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-8">Throughout the pitch-black neighborhood, people were fighting for their lives.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="228" data-total-count="9472" itemprop="articleBody">Once Ms. Sammarco warned her relatives of rising waters, two of her brothers, Angelo and Frankie Paterno, raced in their vehicles to rescue a cousin who lived alone in a bungalow on Nugent Avenue, a block west of Grimsby Street.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="125" data-total-count="9597" itemprop="articleBody">The cousin, John Paterno, 65, had cerebral palsy and, paralyzed from the waist down and legally blind, was largely bedridden.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="169" data-total-count="9766" itemprop="articleBody">He received regular visits from a home health aide, and for more than two decades, his cousins had been feeding him, washing him and, at various times, living with him.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="90" data-total-count="9856" itemprop="articleBody">But as floodwaters climbed, he was alone with his pet cockatoo and a pit bull named Bear.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="237" data-total-count="10093" itemprop="articleBody">Frankie Paterno said he was able to drive within a block of his cousin’s house and dived into the water, ignoring the danger from a downed power line nearby. But the surging waves kept knocking him back, and he finally had to give up.</p><figure id="media-100000001896574" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000001896574 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/JPSTATEN3-sub/JPSTATEN3-sub-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/JPSTATEN3-sub/JPSTATEN3-sub-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/JPSTATEN3-sub/JPSTATEN3-sub-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="John Prisinzano, center in hat, whose father fled the floodwaters, waited with relatives for federal officials to arrive at his father&amp;rsquo;s house." data-mediaviewer-credit="Todd Heisler/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/JPSTATEN3-sub/JPSTATEN3-sub-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="439" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="650" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">John Prisinzano, center in hat, whose father fled the floodwaters, waited with relatives for federal officials to arrive at his father&rsquo;s house.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Todd Heisler/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="188" data-total-count="10281" itemprop="articleBody">“He was our responsibility, and we couldn’t get him,” said Ms. Paterno, another cousin. “We tried. We really did. He died a horrible death. And we didn’t get the help for him.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="163" data-total-count="10444" itemprop="articleBody">A block farther west, on Kiswick Street, a boat loaded with evacuees passed in front of the house of Mr. Contrubis, the 67-year-old former Police Department clerk.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="144" data-total-count="10588" itemprop="articleBody">He signaled to them, a neighbor later told his relatives, but the boat’s pilot told him there was no room and they would come back to get him.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="16" data-total-count="10604" itemprop="articleBody">They never did.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="23" data-total-count="10627" itemprop="articleBody"><strong>HUDDLED ON THE ROOFTOPS</strong></p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="77" data-total-count="10704" itemprop="articleBody">After the storm surge, only a few small boats plied the flooded neighborhood.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="413" data-total-count="11117" itemprop="articleBody">The most substantial was an inflatable rescue boat with three firefighters. Other firefighters were in a rowboat commandeered in the neighborhood. Anthony Guida, one of the firefighters, said there were also civilians in boats, including two men in a canoe. Another man, he recalled, was piloting a bright yellow-and-blue craft that resembled “an inflatable pool toy.” He was using a plastic shovel as an oar.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="62" data-total-count="11179" itemprop="articleBody">“That’s all that was out there,” Firefighter Guida said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="220" data-total-count="11399" itemprop="articleBody">He described a landscape of floating debris and families huddled on rooftops, the arcing beams of their flashlights slicing the dark. “There was nothing between us and Portugal, which was kind of daunting,” he said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="127" data-total-count="11526" itemprop="articleBody">The firefighters heard cries for help from rooftops, though many of the stranded summoned help silently by waving flashlights.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="135" data-total-count="11661" itemprop="articleBody">“From nowhere, we’d get a beam of light and we’d have to track where that light was coming from,” Firefighter Guida, 52, said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="143" data-total-count="11804" itemprop="articleBody">“Covering the entire Midland Beach area was impossible for one boat, or three,” he said. “It would have been impossible for 10 boats.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="132" data-total-count="11936" itemprop="articleBody">On Kiswick Street, where Mr. Contrubis drowned, Firefighter Guida came across four members of a stranded family and their large dog.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="185" data-total-count="12121" itemprop="articleBody">“We couldn’t get them in the boat with the dog,” he said. “They made a heart-wrenching decision to stay with the dog, and they gave us their children.” (The parents survived.)</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="302" data-total-count="12423" itemprop="articleBody">Firefighter Guida’s unit worked in Midland Beach for five hours, making about 20 trips and rescuing scores of people. At 3 a.m., the unit had to relocate to the south for another emergency. Across the borough, the Fire Department rescued about 200 people over the course of the night, officials said.</p><div id="MiddleRight4" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="179" data-total-count="12602" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-9">Though the waters in Midland Beach began to recede in the early morning, they remained several feet high in parts of the neighborhood for much of Tuesday, the day after the storm.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="134" data-total-count="12736" itemprop="articleBody">Most residents were able to return to their homes by Wednesday, but even as late as Thursday, some roads remained impassable for cars.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="49" data-total-count="12785" itemprop="articleBody">As water retreated, a pattern of deaths emerged.</p><figure id="media-100000001896585" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency layout-large-horizontal media-100000001896585 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEn6/jpSTATEn6-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEn6/jpSTATEn6-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEn6/jpSTATEn6-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="John Paterno, 65, died in his bungalow in the Midland Beach neighborhood of Staten Island. Mr. Paterno had cerebral palsy and was legally blind and paralyzed from the waist down." data-mediaviewer-credit="Todd Heisler/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEn6/jpSTATEn6-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="418" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="650" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">John Paterno, 65, died in his bungalow in the Midland Beach neighborhood of Staten Island. Mr. Paterno had cerebral palsy and was legally blind and paralyzed from the waist down.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Todd Heisler/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="191" data-total-count="12976" itemprop="articleBody">The bodies of Mr. Contrubis and the elder Ms. Spagnuolo were pulled from their bungalows on Tuesday. So was the body of Ms. Spagnuolo’s next-door neighbor and friend, Anastasia Rispoli, 73.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-10">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="199" data-total-count="13175" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-10">One of John Paterno’s nephews, using a small boat, reached his uncle’s bungalow Tuesday morning and discovered Mr. Paterno’s pit bull alive, on top of the cockatoo’s bird cage. The bird died.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-11">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="160" data-total-count="13335" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-11">When the nephew emerged with the dog, neighbors still trapped in their homes — but watching the rescue from high stoops and upper-story windows — applauded.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="92" data-total-count="13427" itemprop="articleBody">The nephew saw no trace of Mr. Paterno inside, and the family assumed he had been evacuated.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="141" data-total-count="13568" itemprop="articleBody">In the afternoon, however, divers in scuba gear returned to the bungalow and found Mr. Paterno’s submerged body beneath his overturned bed.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="104" data-total-count="13672" itemprop="articleBody">Daniel Walsh lives across the street, and spent the storm on the upper floors of his three-story house.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="100" data-total-count="13772" itemprop="articleBody">“We never heard anything, no cry for help,” Mr. Walsh said. “The dog didn’t bark at all.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="189" data-total-count="13961" itemprop="articleBody">On Wednesday, rescuers discovered the body of Patricia Bevan, 59, in her bungalow on Hunter Avenue. The storm surge had turned the interior into a jumble of furniture, kitchenware and mud.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="255" data-total-count="14216" itemprop="articleBody">Her next-door neighbor, Abner Santiago, 64, said Ms. Bevan moved onto the block last spring and would walk her Pekingese every day. He had last seen her about 4 p.m. on the day of the storm, standing in front of her home. She was not planning to evacuate.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="89" data-total-count="14305" itemprop="articleBody">“She said: ‘I have no place to go. I have no place to go,’ ” Mr. Santiago said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="85" data-total-count="14390" itemprop="articleBody">The authorities are still searching for the next of kin of Ms. Bevan and Ms. Rispoli.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="20" data-total-count="14410" itemprop="articleBody"><strong>Evacuation Questions</strong></p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="54" data-total-count="14464" itemprop="articleBody">Could the eight dead in Midland Beach have been saved?</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="274" data-total-count="14738" itemprop="articleBody">Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ordered a mandatory evacuation of Zone A — which includes neighborhoods in all five boroughs — at 11:30 a.m. on Sunday, Oct. 28, the day before the storm hit. About 375,000 people are believed to live in Zone A around the city, officials said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="177" data-total-count="14915" itemprop="articleBody">In interviews, Bloomberg aides said the city had clearly succeeded in alerting the city’s residents to the storm’s dangers and offering safe passage to the most vulnerable.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="285" data-total-count="15200" itemprop="articleBody">For several years, the authorities have conducted a campaign to inform people in the most flood-prone areas about preparing for hurricanes. The effort included making presentations at community boards and senior centers, holding news conferences and distributing millions of pamphlets.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="124" data-total-count="15324" itemprop="articleBody">After Tropical Storm Irene, the city stepped up this program, according to Caswell F. Holloway, deputy mayor for operations.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="171" data-total-count="15495" itemprop="articleBody">“For the entire 14 months leading up to Hurricane Sandy, we were engaged in a continuous effort aimed at people who live in Zone A,” Mr. Holloway said in an interview.</p><figure id="media-100000001896582" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000001896582" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN7/jpSTATEN7-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN7/jpSTATEN7-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN7/jpSTATEN7-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Yolanda Concepcion with her husband, Willie, at St. Margaret Mary Catholic Church. The couple live opposite the home of Beatrice Spagnuolo, who died during the storm." data-mediaviewer-credit="Todd Heisler/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/11/11/nyregion/jpSTATEN7/jpSTATEN7-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="397" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="650" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Yolanda Concepcion with her husband, Willie, at St. Margaret Mary Catholic Church. The couple live opposite the home of Beatrice Spagnuolo, who died during the storm.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Todd Heisler/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<div id="MiddleRight5" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-12">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-12">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="173" data-total-count="15668" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-12">Before Hurricane Sandy’s arrival, Mr. Bloomberg held news conferences and the city sent alerts via text message, e-mail and social media to residents in flood-prone areas.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="294" data-total-count="15962" itemprop="articleBody">The city also deployed police officers, as well as groups of volunteers known as Community Emergency Response Teams, to inform people about the evacuation. One of these groups passed through Midland Beach, officials said, with the mission of knocking on doors and warning people in the streets.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="282" data-total-count="16244" itemprop="articleBody">But the campaigns in residential neighborhoods appear to have been more modest than those in the city’s public housing projects in Zone A, where Housing Authority workers knocked on every apartment door and made repeat visits to the homes of the most infirm, city officials said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="268" data-total-count="16512" itemprop="articleBody">Linda Gibbs, the deputy mayor for health and human services, said the city works with nonprofit groups to coordinate the evacuation of homebound older residents. But if people are not in facilities like hospitals, she said, getting them to evacuate can be challenging.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="88" data-total-count="16600" itemprop="articleBody">“If a person does not want to leave their own home, we cannot force them,” she said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="207" data-total-count="16807" itemprop="articleBody">In the end, only about half of the residents in Zone A around the city evacuated, officials estimated. In Midland Beach, residents said they believed that an even smaller percentage left their neighborhood.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="154" data-total-count="16961" itemprop="articleBody">Refusal to obey a mandatory evacuation order is a misdemeanor, punishable by up to 90 days in jail. Yet the authorities rarely make arrests in such cases.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="91" data-total-count="17052" itemprop="articleBody">Officials now say they plan to conduct a thorough review of the Hurricane Sandy evacuation.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="135" data-total-count="17187" itemprop="articleBody">“We are going to look at people who left and people who didn’t, and we’re going to talk to them about why,” Mr. Holloway said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="292" data-total-count="17479" itemprop="articleBody">Asked if the deaths in Midland Beach reflected a failure of the city’s evacuation efforts, he responded that the term “failure” might apply “if the city didn’t have a plan and this came upon us and we were going on the fly.” But he added: “A hurricane is a foreseeable thing.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="67" data-total-count="17546" itemprop="articleBody">“We have a plan for that,” he said, “and we’ve done it.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="20" data-total-count="17566" itemprop="articleBody"><strong>Decisions to Be Made</strong></p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="260" data-total-count="17826" itemprop="articleBody">Since the storm passed, residents have re-entered their homes and sorted through their mud-caked belongings. They have hauled sodden possessions — furniture, appliances, clothes, heirlooms, photo albums — to the curb for the sanitation trucks to cart away.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="130" data-total-count="17956" itemprop="articleBody">Many are vowing to rebuild. Others, even those whose families have lived in Midland Beach for generations, are considering moving.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="111" data-total-count="18067" itemprop="articleBody">“This is the first time water has ever come into the house, ” Mr. Owens, the retired police officer, said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="219" data-total-count="18286" itemprop="articleBody">He was standing in front of the two homes his great-grandfather, an immigrant from France, built on Olympia Boulevard. He and family members were tearing down the walls and gutting the first floor of the two structures.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="121" data-total-count="18407" itemprop="articleBody">“Eighty-four years we’ve been here,” he said. He shook his head: “Now, I’ve got to stop and think about it.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="166" data-total-count="18573" itemprop="articleBody">Ms. Sammarco, who sounded the early warning on Father Capodanno Boulevard, said she might abandon not only the waterfront blocks, but also the neighborhood entirely.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="146" data-total-count="18719" itemprop="articleBody">“For the first time in my life, it crossed my mind,” she said. “Am I going to be all right? With every rainstorm, are we going to panic?”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="64" data-total-count="18783" itemprop="articleBody">The trauma has only deepened as more discoveries have been made.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="309" data-total-count="19092" itemprop="articleBody">Nearly four days after the storm, police officers emerged from a bungalow on Olympia Boulevard carrying two corpses in body bags. Officials were trying to confirm the victims’ full names, but their landlord said they were siblings. The brother, David, was 65, and the sister, Charlotte, was in her mid-70s.</p><button class="button comments-button  theme-speech-bubble" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-13">
</button>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="181" data-total-count="19273" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-13">They had died with their dogs, cats, birds, a rabbit and a hamster. If they were unable to evacuate their entire menagerie, they had told the landlord, they were going to stay home.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="147" data-total-count="19420" itemprop="articleBody">On Friday, long after the floodwaters had drained, police officers on patrol were flagged down and asked to check on a bungalow on Mapleton Avenue.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="146" data-total-count="19566" itemprop="articleBody">Building inspectors had already come by, but they had apparently not gone inside. When the officers did, they found the body of a 64-year-old man.</p>
        
                                        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
                <div class="story-notes"><p>Alain Delaquérière contributed research.</p></div>

<script type="text/javascript">

		var QueryString = function () {
		  var query_string = {};
		  var query = window.location.hash.substring(1);
		  var vars = query.split("&");
		  for (var i=0;i<vars.length;i++) {
		    var pair = vars[i].split("=");
		    if (typeof query_string[pair[0]] === "undefined") {
		      query_string[pair[0]] = pair[1];
		    } else if (typeof query_string[pair[0]] === "string") {
		      var arr = [ query_string[pair[0]], pair[1] ];
		      query_string[pair[0]] = arr;
		    } else {
		      query_string[pair[0]].push(pair[1]);
		    }
		  }
		    return query_string;
		} ();

		var addUrlParam = function(search, key, val){
		  var newParam = key + '=' + val,
		      params = '?' + newParam;

		  if (search) {
		    params = search.replace(new RegExp('[\?&]' + key + '[^&]*'), '$1' + newParam);
		    if (params === search) {
		      params += '&' + newParam;
		    }
		  }
		  return params;
		};

		if (window.location.protocol == 'https:' && QueryString.forceredirect !== 'yes'){
			 window.location.href = 'http:' + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length) + addUrlParam(window.location.hash, 'forceredirect', 'yes');
		}
	</script>
<style type="text/css" media="screen">
html{
height:100%;
}
/*! normalize.css v2.0.1 | MIT License | git.io/normalize */
/* ==========================================================================
HTML5 display definitions
========================================================================== */
/*
* Corrects `block` display not defined in IE 8/9.
*/
article,
aside,
details,
figcaption,
figure,
footer,
header,
hgroup,
nav,
section,
summary {
display: block;
}
/*
* Corrects `inline-block` display not defined in IE 8/9.
*/
audio,
canvas,
video {
display: inline-block;
}
/*
* Prevents modern browsers from displaying `audio` without controls.
* Remove excess height in iOS 5 devices.
*/
audio:not([controls]) {
display: none;
height: 0;
}
/*
* Addresses styling for `hidden` attribute not present in IE 8/9.
*/
[hidden] {
display: none;
}
/* ==========================================================================
Base
========================================================================== */
/*
* 1. Sets default font family to sans-serif.
* 2. Prevents iOS text size adjust after orientation change, without disabling
*    user zoom.
*/
html {
font-family: sans-serif; /* 1 */
-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%; /* 2 */
-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%; /* 2 */
/*			-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;*/
}
/*
* Removes default margin.
*/
body {
margin: 0;
}
/* ==========================================================================
Links
========================================================================== */
/*
* Addresses `outline` inconsistency between Chrome and other browsers.
*/
a:focus {
outline: 0;
}
/*
* Improves readability when focused and also mouse hovered in all browsers.
*/
a:active,
a:hover {
outline: 0;
}
html *{
outline:0;
}
/* ==========================================================================
Typography
========================================================================== */
/*
* Addresses `h1` font sizes within `section` and `article` in Firefox 4+,
* Safari 5, and Chrome.
*/
h1 {
font-size: 2em;
}
/*
* Addresses styling not present in IE 8/9, Safari 5, and Chrome.
*/
abbr[title] {
border-bottom: 1px dotted;
}
/*
* Addresses style set to `bolder` in Firefox 4+, Safari 5, and Chrome.
*/
b,
strong {
font-weight: bold;
}
/*
* Addresses styling not present in Safari 5 and Chrome.
*/
dfn {
font-style: italic;
}
/*
* Addresses styling not present in IE 8/9.
*/
mark {
background: #ff0;
color: #000;
}
/*
* Corrects font family set oddly in Safari 5 and Chrome.
*/
code,
kbd,
pre,
samp {
font-family: monospace, serif;
font-size: 1em;
}
/*
* Improves readability of pre-formatted text in all browsers.
*/
pre {
white-space: pre;
white-space: pre-wrap;
word-wrap: break-word;
}
/*
* Sets consistent quote types.
*/
q {
quotes: "\201C" "\201D" "\2018" "\2019";
}
/*
* Addresses inconsistent and variable font size in all browsers.
*/
small {
font-size: 80%;
}
/*
* Prevents `sub` and `sup` affecting `line-height` in all browsers.
*/
sub,
sup {
font-size: 75%;
line-height: 0;
position: relative;
vertical-align: baseline;
}
sup {
top: -0.5em;
}
sub {
bottom: -0.25em;
}
/* ==========================================================================
Embedded content
========================================================================== */
/*
* Removes border when inside `a` element in IE 8/9.
*/
img {
border: 0;
}
/*
* Corrects overflow displayed oddly in IE 9.
*/
svg:not(:root) {
overflow: hidden;
}
/* ==========================================================================
Figures
========================================================================== */
/*
* Addresses margin not present in IE 8/9 and Safari 5.
*/
figure {
margin: 0;
}
/* ==========================================================================
Forms
========================================================================== */
/*
* Define consistent border, margin, and padding.
*/
fieldset {
border: 1px solid #c0c0c0;
margin: 0 2px;
padding: 0.35em 0.625em 0.75em;
}
/*
* 1. Corrects color not being inherited in IE 8/9.
* 2. Remove padding so people aren't caught out if they zero out fieldsets.
*/
legend {
border: 0; /* 1 */
padding: 0; /* 2 */
}
/*
* 1. Corrects font family not being inherited in all browsers.
* 2. Corrects font size not being inherited in all browsers.
* 3. Addresses margins set differently in Firefox 4+, Safari 5, and Chrome
*/
button,
input,
select,
textarea {
font-family: inherit; /* 1 */
font-size: 100%; /* 2 */
margin: 0; /* 3 */
}
/*
* Addresses Firefox 4+ setting `line-height` on `input` using `!important` in
* the UA stylesheet.
*/
button,
input {
line-height: normal;
}
/*
* 1. Avoid the WebKit bug in Android 4.0.* where (2) destroys native `audio`
*    and `video` controls.
* 2. Corrects inability to style clickable `input` types in iOS.
* 3. Improves usability and consistency of cursor style between image-type
*    `input` and others.
*/
button,
html input[type="button"], /* 1 */
input[type="reset"],
input[type="submit"] {
-webkit-appearance: button; /* 2 */
cursor: pointer; /* 3 */
}
/*
* Re-set default cursor for disabled elements.
*/
button[disabled],
input[disabled] {
cursor: default;
}
/*
* 1. Addresses box sizing set to `content-box` in IE 8/9.
* 2. Removes excess padding in IE 8/9.
*/
input[type="checkbox"],
input[type="radio"] {
box-sizing: border-box; /* 1 */
padding: 0; /* 2 */
}
/*
* 1. Addresses `appearance` set to `searchfield` in Safari 5 and Chrome.
* 2. Addresses `box-sizing` set to `border-box` in Safari 5 and Chrome
*    (include `-moz` to future-proof).
*/
input[type="search"] {
-webkit-appearance: textfield; /* 1 */
-moz-box-sizing: content-box;
-webkit-box-sizing: content-box; /* 2 */
box-sizing: content-box;
}
/*
* Removes inner padding and search cancel button in Safari 5 and Chrome
* on OS X.
*/
input[type="search"]::-webkit-search-cancel-button,
input[type="search"]::-webkit-search-decoration {
-webkit-appearance: none;
}
/*
* Removes inner padding and border in Firefox 4+.
*/
button::-moz-focus-inner,
input::-moz-focus-inner {
border: 0;
padding: 0;
}
/*
* 1. Removes default vertical scrollbar in IE 8/9.
* 2. Improves readability and alignment in all browsers.
*/
textarea {
overflow: auto; /* 1 */
vertical-align: top; /* 2 */
}
/* ==========================================================================
Tables
========================================================================== */
/*
* Remove most spacing between table cells.
*/
table {
border-collapse: collapse;
border-spacing: 0;
}
/* end normalize*/
/* nyt styles*/
body{
font-family:georgia, "times new roman", times, serif;
color:#333;
}
p, ul, ol, dl, dd {
margin: 0 0 1em 0;
}
ul {
list-style: none;
padding-left: 0;
}
/* shrinkwrap floats */
.wideA:after,

}

<style>

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com"><img alt="New York Times" title="New York Times" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/misc/nytlogo153x23.gif" class="logo" width="153" height="23"></a>

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com"><img alt="New York Times" title="New York Times" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/nyt_logo.gif" width="15" height="20" class="logo"></a>
<h3>Snow Fall</h3>
</div>
<div id="nytmm_sidenav">
<ul class="nytmm-menu">
<li class="selected"><a data-section="0" class="nytmm-menu-section-link" href="#tunnel-creek">Tunnel Creek</a></li>
<li class=""><a data-section="1" class="nytmm-menu-section-link" href="#to-the-peak">To the Peak</a></li>
<li class=""><a data-section="2" class="nytmm-menu-section-link" href="#descent-begins">Descent Begins</a></li>
<li class=""><a data-section="3" class="nytmm-menu-section-link" href="#blur-of-white">Blur of White</a></li>
<li class=""><a data-section="4" class="nytmm-menu-section-link" href="#discovery">Discovery</a></li>
<li class=""><a data-section="5" class="nytmm-menu-section-link" href="#word-spreads">Word Spreads</a></li>
