<!--articles// content -->
<div class="inner_mask" id="nytmm_main_mask"></div>
<div id="nytmm_articles">
<!--section 1 //-->
<div class="nytmm_section" name="tunnel-creek" data-label="Tunnel Creek">
<div class="nytmm_article video_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_leadphotoseq nytmm_ie_static" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter1_new.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter1_new.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter1.jpg" data-loop="true"></div>
<div class="nytmm_title_head">
<div class="nytmm_inner_head">
<h1>Snow <span>F</span>all</h1>
<h2>The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek</h2>
<div class="nytmm_divider"></div>
<div class="byline">By <span>John Branch</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_arrow"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/us/20121012_ELYRIA/arrow.png" width="43" height="71" /></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article //-->
<div class="nytmm_article top">
<div class="inner_article">
<div class="left">
<p><span class="dropcap">T</span>he snow burst through the trees with no warning but a last-second whoosh of sound, a two-story wall of white and Chris Rudolph&rsquo;s piercing cry: &ldquo;Avalanche! Elyse!&rdquo;</p>
<p>The very thing the 16 skiers and snowboarders had sought &mdash; fresh, soft snow &mdash; instantly became the enemy. Somewhere above, a pristine meadow cracked in the shape of a lightning bolt, slicing a slab nearly 200 feet across and 3 feet deep. Gravity did the rest.</p>
<p>Snow shattered and spilled down the slope. Within seconds, the avalanche was the size of more than a thousand cars barreling down the mountain and weighed millions of pounds. Moving about 7o miles per hour, it crashed through the sturdy old-growth trees, snapping their limbs and shredding bark from their trunks. </p>
<p>The avalanche, in Washington&rsquo;s Cascades in February, slid past some trees and rocks, like ocean swells around a ship&rsquo;s prow. Others it captured and added to its violent load. </p>
<p>Somewhere inside, it also carried people. How many, no one knew.</p>
<p>The slope of the terrain, shaped like a funnel, squeezed the growing swell of churning snow into a steep, twisting gorge. It moved in surges, like a roller coaster on a series of drops and high-banked turns. It accelerated as the slope steepened and the weight of the slide pushed from behind. It slithered through shallower pitches. The energy raised the temperature of the snow a couple of degrees, and the friction carved striations high in the icy sides of the canyon walls.</p>
<p>Elyse Saugstad, a professional skier, wore a backpack equipped with an air bag, a relatively new and expensive part of the arsenal that backcountry users increasingly carry to ease their minds and increase survival odds in case of an avalanche. About to be overtaken, she pulled a cord near her chest. She was knocked down before she knew if the canister of compressed air inflated winged pillows behind her head. </p>
<p>She had no control of her body as she tumbled downhill. She did not know up from down. It was not unlike being cartwheeled in a relentlessly crashing wave. But snow does not recede. It swallows its victims. It does not spit them out.</p>
<p>Snow filled her mouth. She caromed off things she never saw, tumbling through a cluttered canyon like a steel marble falling through pins in a pachinko machine. </p>
<p>At first she thought she would be embarrassed that she had deployed her air bag, that the other expert skiers she was with, more than a dozen of them, would have a good laugh at her panicked overreaction. Seconds later, tumbling uncontrollably inside a ribbon of speeding snow, she was sure this was how she was going to die.</p>
<p>Moving, roiling snow turns into something closer to liquid, thick like lava. But when it stops, it instantly freezes solid. The laws of physics and chemistry transform a meadow of fine powder into a wreckage of icy chunks. Saugstad&rsquo;s pinwheeling body would freeze into whatever position it was in the moment the snow stopped. </p>
<p>After about a minute, the creek bed vomited the debris into a gently sloped meadow. Saugstad felt the snow slow and tried to keep her hands in front of her. She knew from avalanche safety courses that outstretched hands might puncture the ice surface and alert rescuers. She knew that if victims ended up buried under the snow, cupped hands in front of the face could provide a small pocket of air for the mouth and nose. Without it, the first breaths could create a suffocating ice mask. </p>
<p>The avalanche spread and stopped, locking everything it carried into an icy cocoon. It was now a jagged, virtually impenetrable pile of ice, longer than a football field and nearly as wide. As if newly plowed, it rose in rugged contrast to the surrounding fields of undisturbed snow, 20 feet tall in spots. </p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-elyse/video-avalanche-elyse-custom1-v2.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">&lsquo;I Couldn&rsquo;t Breathe&rsquo;</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001935971" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19222_1_avalanche-elyse_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-width="348" data-height="196" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-elyse/video-avalanche-elyse-custom1-v2.jpg"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><span class="nytmm_video_trigger">Saugstad was mummified</span>. She was on her back, her head pointed downhill. Her goggles were off. Her nose ring had been ripped away. She felt the crushing weight of snow on her chest. She could not move her legs. One boot still had a ski attached to it. She could not lift her head because it was locked into the ice. </p>
<p>But she could see the sky. Her face was covered only with loose snow. Her hands, too, stuck out of the snow, one still covered by a pink mitten. </p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_tofixie" id="nytmm_instruction_container">
<div class="nytmm_instruction">A narrative of interwoven words and multimedia.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article//-->
<div class="nytmm_article nytmm_colorchange last" id="nytmm_pewter" data-colorchrome="#a8a7b0" data-colorff="#aaa7b0" data-color="#b2b1b7">
<div class="inner_article">
<div class="left">
<p>Using her hands like windshield wipers, she tried to flick snow away from her mouth. When she clawed at her chest and neck, the crumbs maddeningly slid back onto her face. She grew claustrophobic. </p>
<p>Breathe easy, she told herself. Do not panic. Help will come. She stared at the low, gray clouds. She had not noticed the noise as she hurtled down the mountain. Now, she was suddenly struck by the silence.</p>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3>Tunnel Creek</h3>
<p>The Cascades are among the craggiest of American mountain ranges, roughly cut, as if carved with a chain saw. In summer, the gray peaks are sprinkled with glaciers. In winter, they are smothered in some of North America&rsquo;s deepest snowpack.</p>
<p>The top of Cowboy Mountain, about 75 miles east of Seattle, rises to 5,853 feet &mdash; about half the height of the tallest Cascades, but higher than its nearest neighbors, enough to provide 360-degree views. It feels more like a long fin than a summit, a few feet wide in parts. Locals call it Cowboy Ridge.</p>
<p>To one side, down steep chutes, is Stevens Pass ski area, which receives about 400,000 visitors each winter. To the other, outside the ski area&rsquo;s boundary to what is considered the back of Cowboy Mountain, is an unmonitored play area of reliably deep snow, a &ldquo;powder stash,&rdquo; known as Tunnel Creek.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article//-->
<div class="nytmm_article graphic_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_video_graphic nytmm_ie_mp4" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/flyover_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/flyover_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/flyover.jpg" data-touch-media="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/flyover_1218_1518_iPad.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/flyover_poster.jpg" data-loop="false" data-touch-controls="true"></div>
</div>
<!--end article//-->
<div class="nytmm_article top">
<div class="inner_article">
<div class="left">
<p>It is a term with broad meaning. The name is derived from the Cascade Tunnel, originally a 2.6-mile railroad tube completed in 1900 that connected the east and west sides of the Cascades, a boon for the growth of Seattle and Puget Sound. The mountain pass that it burrowed beneath was named for the project&rsquo;s engineer, John Frank Stevens, who later helped build the Panama Canal.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float nytmm_photo_wide clearfix no_phone">
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_1910Avalanche-slide-K909/AVIE_1910Avalanche-slide-K909-custom3.jpg" width="365" height="256" />
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_1910Avalanche-slide-7MXU/AVIE_1910Avalanche-slide-7MXU-custom1.jpg" width="365" height="256" />
</div>
<div class="caption">Wreckage after the Wellington, Wash., avalanche in 1910, which buried two passenger trains marooned by snowstorms outside the Cascade Tunnel and killed 96 people. Rescue workers transported bodies from the scene on sleds. <span class="credit">Museum of History &amp; Industry</span></div>
</div>
<p>In late February 1910, ceaseless snowstorms over several days marooned two passenger trains just outside the tunnel&rsquo;s west portal. Before the tracks could be cleared, the trains were buried by what still stands as the nation&rsquo;s deadliest avalanche. It killed 96 people.</p>
<p>Bodies were extricated and wrapped in blankets from the Great Northern Railway, then hauled away on sleds. Some were not found until the snow melted many months later. </p>
<p>To skiers and snowboarders today, Tunnel Creek is a serendipitous junction of place and powder. It features nearly 3,000 vertical feet &mdash; a rarely matched descent &mdash; of open meadows framed by thick stands of trees. Steep gullies drain each spring&rsquo;s runoff to the valley floor and into a small, short gorge called Tunnel Creek.</p>
<p>The area has all of the alluring qualities of the backcountry &mdash; fresh snow, expert terrain and relative solitude &mdash; but few of the customary inconveniences. Reaching Tunnel Creek from Stevens Pass ski area requires a ride of just more than five minutes up SkyLine Express, a high-speed four-person chairlift, followed by a shorter ride up Seventh Heaven, a steep two-person lift. Slip through the open boundary gate, with its &ldquo;continue at your own risk&rdquo; warning signs, and hike 10 minutes to the top of Cowboy Mountain. </p>
<p>When snow conditions are right, the preferred method of descent used by those experienced in Tunnel Creek, based on the shared wisdom passed over generations, is to hopscotch down the mountain through a series of long meadows. Weave down the first meadow, maybe punctuate the run with a jump off a rock outcropping near the bottom, then veer hard left, up and out of the narrowing gully and into the next open glade.</p>
<p>Another powder-filled drop ends with another hard left, into another meadow that leads to the valley floor.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player nytmm_theme_video">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster">
<div class="nytmm_triggered_video" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/lure_intro_new.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/lure_intro_new.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/lure-intro.jpg" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-loop="false" data-trigger="theme_video"></div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title nytmm_info_el">Allure of <span>the Backcountry</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay nytmm_info_el"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001936005" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19224_1_avalanche-allure_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-touch-width="500" data-touch-height="281" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/lure-intro.jpg"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Tunnel Creek is, in the vernacular of locals, a &ldquo;hippie pow run&rdquo; &mdash; breezy and unobstructed, the kind that <span class="nytmm_video_trigger" data-trigger="theme_video">makes skiers giggle in glee</span> as they descend through a billowing cloud of their own soft powder and emerge at the bottom coated in white frosting.</p>
<p>Despite trends toward extreme skiing (now called freeskiing), with improbable descents over cliffs and down chutes that test the guile of even the fiercest daredevils, the ageless lure of fresh, smooth powder endures.</p>
<p>But powder and people are key ingredients for avalanches. And the worry among avalanche forecasters, snow-science experts and search-and-rescue leaders is that the number of fatalities &mdash; roughly 200 around the world each year &mdash; will keep rising as the rush to the backcountry continues among skiers, snowboarders, climbers and snowmobilers. </p>
<p>The backcountry represents the fastest-growing segment of the ski industry. More than ever, people are looking for fresh descents accessible by helicopters, hiking or even the simple ride up a chairlift.</p>
<p>Before 1980, it was unusual to have more than 10 avalanche deaths in the United States each winter. There were 34 last season, including 20 skiers and snowboarders. Eight victims were skiing out of bounds, legally, with a lift ticket. And many of the dead were backcountry experts intimate with the terrain that killed them.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s a cultural shift, where more skiers are going farther, faster, bigger,&rdquo; said John Stifter, the editor of Powder magazine, who was a part of the group at Tunnel Creek in February. &ldquo;Which is tending to push your pro skiers or other experienced, elite-level backcountry skiers that much farther, faster and bigger, to the point where there&rsquo;s no margin for error.&rdquo;</p>
<p>No one knows how many avalanches occur. Most naturally triggered slides are never seen. Those set off by humans are rarely reported unless they cause fatalities or property damage. </p>
<p>But avalanches occur in Tunnel Creek regularly. Its slopes, mostly from 40 to 45 degrees, are optimal for avalanches &mdash; flat enough to hold deep reservoirs of snow, yet steep enough for the snow to slide long distances when prompted. The long elevation drop means snow can be fluffy at the top and slushy at the bottom. Temperatures, wind and precipitation change quickly, and something as welcome as a burst of sunshine can alter the crystallized bonds deep inside the snow. And because Tunnel Creek is outside the ski area, it is not patrolled or specifically assessed for danger.</p>
<p>In March 2011, a University of Washington student was caught in an avalanche in Tunnel Creek. Having been carried into a stand of trees, he was unburied by friends within minutes and found dead. Three others were partially buried about an hour later when the ski patrol&rsquo;s arrival set off a second avalanche. </p>
<p>Many of the most experienced locals view Tunnel Creek with a mix of awe and fear. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;ve always been a naysayer of Tunnel Creek,&rdquo; the snowboarder Tim Wesley said. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ve seen a big avalanche back there before. It has about 2,600 vertical feet. Not typical. The snow changes a lot in that distance. That&rsquo;s the reason I always have a second thought about Tunnel Creek. In Washington, there&rsquo;s a saying: If you don&rsquo;t like the weather, wait five minutes. And it&rsquo;s true. You&rsquo;ll be on the chair and it&rsquo;ll be freezing, and then all of a sudden there&rsquo;s a warm breeze that smells like the ocean.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Even those who are not leery of Tunnel Creek on the best days heed the pass-it-on warning of the experienced: stay left.</p>
<p>To head straight down to the bottom is to enter what experts call a terrain trap: a funnel of trouble and clumsy skiing, clogged with trees and rocks and confined by high walls. Few go that way intentionally.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_ad">
<div class="inner_ad">
<h3>Advertisement</h3>
<iframe class="nytmm-enterprise-ads-leaderboard" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" border="0" src=""></iframe>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article">
<div class="left">
<p>Chris Rudolph, the effervescent 30-year-old marketing manager for Stevens Pass, knew the preferred route down. Tunnel Creek was his favorite at-work diversion. Earlier that weekend, he mentioned plans for a field trip to Tunnel Creek to a select group of high-powered guests and close friends.</p>
<p>The operations manager for Stevens Pass agreed to pick up the group in one of the ski area&rsquo;s trucks at the end of its descent. From the bottom of Tunnel Creek, it is about a half-mile trek through deep snow to U.S. 2, then a four-mile ride back to Stevens Pass.</p>
<p>At 11:32 a.m. on Sunday, Feb. 19, heading up the mountain, Rudolph sent a text message to the operations manager. </p>
<p>&ldquo;A big posse,&rdquo; Rudolph wrote.</p>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3>A Plan in Motion</h3>
<p>Like many ideas that sound good at the time, skiing Tunnel Creek was an idea hatched in a bar. </p>
<p>It was Saturday, Feb. 18, the afternoon light fading to dusk. Outside the Foggy Goggle, a bar at the base of the ski area, the snow continued to fall, roughly an inch an hour. By morning, there would be 32 inches of fresh snow at Stevens Pass, 21 of them in a 24-hour period of Saturday and Saturday night.</p>
<p>That was cause for celebration. It had been more than two weeks since the last decent snowfall. Finally, the tired layer of hard, crusty snow was gone, buried deep under powder.</p>
<p><span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="rudolph">Rudolph</span> promoted Stevens Pass with restless zeal. In seven years there, he helped turn a relatively small, roadside ski area into a hip destination. </p>
<p>He unabashedly courted ski journalists and filmmakers to take a look. They, in turn, gave Stevens Pass star turns in magazines and popular ski movies, raising the area&rsquo;s cool quotient. </p>
<p>Rudolph was the oldest of three children raised in California&rsquo;s Bay Area by outdoors-minded parents. The young family pulled a pop-up Coleman camper around the West and skied at the areas around Lake Tahoe. The grown siblings continued to vacation with their parents, climbing peaks like Mount Whitney in California and Mount Rainier in Washington. </p>
<p>Rudolph peppered his language with words like &ldquo;rad&rdquo; and &ldquo;stoked.&rdquo; But he was no simple-minded ski bum. He was an Eagle Scout with a marketing degree. When he applied at Stevens Pass years earlier, he sent a video of himself speaking, skiing and mountain biking. He included a bag of popcorn for the viewer. He got the job. </p>
<p>Children knew Rudolph because he kept his pockets full of Stevens Pass stickers. He starred in self-deprecating Webcasts promoting Stevens Pass. He wrote poetry on his blog and strummed a guitar. He drank Pabst Blue Ribbon, the unofficial beer of irony and the hipster generation. </p>
<p>Tunnel Creek was where he took special guests. And it is where he wanted to take the tangled assortment of high-caliber skiers and industry insiders who, as if carried by the latest storm, had blown into Stevens Pass that weekend.</p>
<p>Many of them happened into the Foggy Goggle on Saturday night.</p>
<p>Among them were professional skiers like <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="saugstad">Saugstad</span>, 33, a former champion of the Freeride World Tour. There were reporters and editors from Powder magazine and ESPN. There were executives from ski equipment and apparel companies. There were Stevens Pass regulars, some with broad reputations in the niche world of skiing, glad to spend time with the assortment of guests.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It was a very, very deep, heavy, powerful, strong group of pro skiers and ski industry people,&rdquo; said <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="carlsen">Keith Carlsen</span>, a photographer and former editor of Powder.</p>
<p>Rudolph was the connecting thread. Some visitors, like Saugstad, were at Stevens Pass for a promotional event aimed at expert female skiers, sponsored by Salomon, the ski equipment maker. Rudolph skied with the group all day Saturday. He organized and hosted a catered dinner for the women later that night in Leavenworth, a serious outdoors town dressed as a Bavarian village, 35 miles downhill to the east.</p>
<p>Powder had come to spotlight Stevens Pass for a feature article on night skiing. When the magazine&rsquo;s editor, <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" title="John Stifter"  data-tag="stifter">John Stifter</span>, arrived by train to Leavenworth two days earlier, he found Rudolph&rsquo;s car waiting for him. Inside were keys to the car, keys to a slope-side cabin and two Pabst Blue Ribbons in the cup holders.</p>
<p>At the bar, Rudolph mentioned an idea to a few people: Tunnel Creek on Sunday. Invitations traveled in whispers and text messages, through a knot of friendships and slight acquaintances. </p>
<p>Meet at the fire pit, on the stone deck at Granite Peaks Lodge, at 11. Rudolph thought his Sunday morning staff meeting would end by then.</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="rudolph">
<div class="profile_img rudolph"></div>
<h4>Chris Rudolph</h4>
<p>30, Director of marketing at Stevens Pass</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="saugstad">
<div class="profile_img saugstad"></div>
<h4>Elyse Saugstad</h4>
<p>33, Professional freeskier</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="carlsen">
<div class="profile_img carlsen"></div>
<h4>Keith Carlsen</h4>
<p>38, Photographer and former editor of Powder</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="stifter">
<div class="profile_img stifter"></div>
<h4>John Stifter</h4>
<p>29, Editor of Powder magazine</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article last">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>As darkness enveloped Stevens Pass on Saturday night, stadium-style lights flooded the slopes in white light, and snowflakes fell in cotton-ball clumps.</p>
<p>Rudolph and those with the Salomon event left for dinner in Leavenworth. Stifter, 29, and Carlsen, 38, headed outside to work on their article for Powder.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float phone-nofloat phone-photo-fullspan">
<div class="nytmm_slideshow_poster nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="nightski">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_NightSki-slide-87OV/AVIE_NightSki-slide-87OV-custom2.jpg" width="640" height="426" />
<div class="nytmm_play"></div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Several of those with plans to ski Tunnel Creek the next day huddled around a fire in front of Tim Wangen&rsquo;s trailer. Among the assembled were Jim Jack, in red pants, and Tiffany Abraham, in red jacket. <span class="credit">Keith Carlsen</span></div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;I skied just off the trail, not out of bounds, but in the ski resort, to shoot some of these night shots I took,&rdquo; Carlsen said. &ldquo;And in tree wells I was, like, neck deep &mdash; easily nipple deep, wading around in snow, trying to get my angle. There was so much new snow.&rdquo;</p>
<p>With the daytime crowds gone, the nighttime atmosphere was festive and the faces were familiar. Families played in the deepening snow. More serious skiers and snowboarders sought the freshest powder. </p>
<p>There are no public accommodations at Stevens Pass, only a parking lot available to a few dozen campers and recreational vehicles. As the evening wound down, several of those with loose plans to ski Tunnel Creek the next morning huddled in the R.V. lot around a fire. Carlsen continued taking photographs. Stifter and others ducked inside one camper to watch homemade videos of others skiing Tunnel Creek over the past couple of decades.</p>
<p>&ldquo;So it&rsquo;s something they skied often,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;Not something like, &lsquo;We&rsquo;re going to go ski Tunnel!&rsquo; Not like a once-a-year deal.&rdquo; </p>
<p>The flames in the fire died to orange embers. The last beers were sipped empty, and people slipped into the night. The campers were blanketed with snow.</p>
<p>Beyond the lights glowing from the ski area, snow still fell over the ridge, too, in the vast darkness of steep meadows and narrow gullies just past the western edge of Stevens Pass. </p>
<p>Each snowflake added to the depth, and each snowflake added to the weight. It might take a million snowflakes for a skier to notice the difference. It might take just one for a mountain to move. </p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article //-->
<div class="nytmm_article graphic_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_video_graphic nytmm_ie_mp4" id="weather_graphic" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/weather_new.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/weather_new.webm" data-touch-media="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/weather_1024.mp4" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/weather.jpg" data-loop="false" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/weather_1024.jpg" data-touch-controls="true">
<div class="nytmm_graphiccover_label">
<div id="nytmm_weather_label1">A large storm produced 32 inches of snow at Stevens Pass in the three days before the avalanche.</div>
<div id="nytmm_weather_label2">The new snow put an increasing load on a fragile crust.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article //-->
</div>
<!--end superpart //-->
<!--section 2 //-->
<div class="nytmm_section" name="to-the-peak" data-label="To the Peak">
<div class="nytmm_article image_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_img"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter2_flat.jpg" /></div>
<div class="nytmm_chapter_head light" id="nytmm_head_1">
<div class="nytmm_inner_head">
<span>Part Two</span>
<h2>To the Peak</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article top last">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p><span class="dropcap">D</span>awn cracked with the intermittent sound of explosives near the top of Cowboy Mountain. Stevens Pass ski patrollers, called to duty whenever more than a few inches of snow fell, had arrived to check and control the ski area&rsquo;s 200 inbounds avalanche zones.</p>
<p>After getting the latest assessment from the area&rsquo;s full-time avalanche forecaster, more than a dozen patrollers filled their backpacks with 2.2-pound emulsion charges, shaped like cartoon dynamite. Chairlifts rumbled to life, ferrying the crews up the dark mountain. </p>
<p>Three two-person teams assigned to Cowboy Ridge removed their skis and filed through the boundary gate. They took turns plowing a path through the fresh snow with their bodies. Their boots forged an icy stairway to the top of the skinny ridge.</p>
<p>Back on their skis, facing down into the ski area and with their backs to Tunnel Creek, they spread across the ridge to stamp and destroy wind-swept cornices, small balconies of crusty snow. </p>
<p>They removed the charges from their packs. Like party poppers that spew confetti, charges have a pull-wire, an ignition that lights a 90-second fuse. The patrollers lobbed the lighted charges into the many steep chutes below them. With muffled booms, heavy waves of snow tumbled harmlessly into the recesses of the empty slopes below, clearing danger for the day&rsquo;s thousands of inbounds customers.</p>
<p>The lines for the ski lifts began forming about 7, two hours before they were to open. When the gathering skiers and snowboarders heard the explosions echo down the mountain, they cheered. It signaled a powder day.</p>
<p>In Leavenworth, Chris Rudolph awoke in his two-bedroom house on Ash Street, the one that he and his girlfriend, Anne Hessburg, painted a rich blue and accented with a garden out front.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Chris was so mad that he had a meeting,&rdquo; Hessburg said. &ldquo;It was a pow day, and you couldn&rsquo;t tie him to his desk on pow days.&rdquo;</p>
<p>But he thought the meeting would end by 11.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He said: &lsquo;It&rsquo;s going to be so good, babe. I&rsquo;m going to take some folks up to Tunnel Creek,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Hessburg said. &ldquo;Tunnel Creek, it was kind of like the holy grail for Chris. It was where he wanted to show off for friends.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Among those who joined the 45-minute parade from Leavenworth, through tight Tumwater Canyon, past the Lake Wenatchee turnoff and up to Stevens Pass, were <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="abrams">Dan Abrams</span> and <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="michelson">Megan Michelson</span>. They planned to marry in March.</p>
<p>Michelson, 30, was the freeskiing editor for ESPN.com. Abrams, 34, was a founder and the president of Flylow, maker of apparel marketed to backcountry users.</p>
<p>The couple lived in Seattle, but had come to Stevens Pass on Saturday for the Salomon promotional event. Michelson and the other women stayed at a Leavenworth hotel. Abrams slept in a spare bedroom at Rudolph&rsquo;s house. He and Michelson drove to Stevens Pass together.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I said to Dan, &lsquo;Do you think Tunnel will be safe today?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Michelson said. &ldquo;He said something along the lines of, &lsquo;Yeah, those guys know the best route down.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>There were similar conversations elsewhere. In the slope-side cabin at Stevens Pass that Rudolph arranged &mdash; he cleaned it on Friday as he spoke to his mother on the phone &mdash; the journalists from Powder magazine, Stifter and Carlsen, contemplated the day&rsquo;s plans.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We started asking questions,&rdquo; Carlsen said. &ldquo;<span class="nytmm_single_quote left">&lsquo;</span>Where are we going? Out of bounds? Didn&rsquo;t it just snow nonstop for two days? How much snow?&rsquo; That&rsquo;s when John pulled up the avalanche report, and he read it aloud.&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster" id="moore_video">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-predicting/video-avalanche-predicting-custom1.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">Predicting Avalanches</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001936102" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19225_1_avalanche-predicting_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-width="348" data-height="196" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-predicting/video-avalanche-predicting-articleLarge.jpg"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><span class="nytmm_video_trigger">Mark Moore, director and lead meteorologist</span> of the Northwest Weather and Avalanche Center, had set that day&rsquo;s forecast on Saturday afternoon. A 64-year-old with graying hair pulled into a short ponytail, Moore had a feeling it could be a busy weekend.</p>
<p>The avalanche center, based in Seattle, is one of about 20 regional avalanche forecasting centers in the United States, most run by the Forest Service. During the winter, one of its three employees arrives in the middle of the night, analyzes weather maps and computer models, and examines data &mdash; snowfall, temperatures, wind, humidity and so on &mdash; from 47 remote weather stations scattered across the mountains, including five in the vicinity of Stevens Pass. They take calls from ski patrollers and highway crews.</p>
<p>The biggest storm of the season increased avalanche concerns. But it was not just the new snow that concerned Moore. It was what lay nearly three feet beneath &mdash; a thin layer of perfectly preserved frost called surface hoar. The frozen equivalent of dew, created on crisp, clear nights, it features fragile, featherlike crystals that grow skyward. </p>
<p>On the surface, they glimmer like a million tiny diamonds. When frosted and protected by soft blankets of fluffy snow, they are weak stilts supporting all that falls on top. When they finally give way, falling like microscopic dominoes on a steep slope, they provide an icy flume for the snow above.</p>
<p>A shot of rain or above-freezing temperatures, both common in Cascade winters, usually destroy the fragile crystals, melding them into the snowpack. But five days of dry, cold weather, from Feb. 3 to 7, created a perfect, sparkly layer of surface hoar. Sporadic light snow, never more than an inch or two a day, delicately shrouded it over the next 10 days.</p>
<p>By the weekend, as snow fell heavily over the Cascades and powder-hungry hordes took to the slopes, the old layer was long out of sight, and mostly out of mind.</p>
<p>Not to Moore.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Snowpack is never static,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s changing, even once it&rsquo;s buried.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Changes in temperatures, precipitation, humidity and wind can turn a benign snowpack into a deadly one, and vice versa. Sometimes weather is enough to start an avalanche. But &ldquo;natural&rdquo; avalanches rarely kill. The majority of avalanche fatalities are in human-triggered slides &mdash; usually of the victims&rsquo; own making.</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="abrams">
<div class="profile_img abrams"></div>
<h4>Dan Abrams</h4>
<p>34, Co-founder, Flylow ski apparel, fianc&eacute; of Megan Michelson</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="michelson">
<div class="profile_img michelson"></div>
<h4>Megan Michelson</h4>
<p>30, Freeskiing editor, ESPN.com, fianc&eacute;e of Dan Abrams</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article graphic_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touchstepper nytmm_ie_mp4" id="nytmm_snowpack_animation" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/layers_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/layers_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/layers.jpg" data-loop="false" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/snowpack_poster.jpg" data-slideshow="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2012/12/19/sports/skiing/Avalanche-Snowpack.slideshow.jsonp" data-vidwidth="1280" data-vidheight="600" data-touch-width="1024" data-touch-height="536" data-preroll="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/layers.mp4">
</div>
<div id="nytmm_touchstepper_instructions" style="display:none">
<p class="caption"><span class="nytmm_instructions_play">Play</span> or swipe through</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>&ldquo;Every skier, everyone who hits the slope, changes the structure of the snowpack,&rdquo; Moore said. &ldquo;Even though they don&rsquo;t know it.&rdquo;</p>
<p>In the rugged area of the Cascades that includes Stevens Pass, Moore deemed the avalanche danger &ldquo;high&rdquo; &mdash; the fourth degree out of five &mdash; for slopes above 5,000 feet in elevation, facing north to southeast.</p>
<p>For everything else, the danger level was deemed &ldquo;considerable,&rdquo; defined as &ldquo;dangerous avalanche conditions&rdquo; with &ldquo;human-triggered avalanches likely.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The top of Cowboy Mountain is nearly 6,000 feet. The Tunnel Creek terrain descends off its southwest side to roughly 3,000 feet. Officially, the danger was &ldquo;considerable.&rdquo;</p>
<p>&ldquo;In avalanche forecasting terms, &lsquo;considerable&rsquo; is a really weird forecast,&rdquo; Saugstad said. &ldquo;Because it&rsquo;s this gray area. It&rsquo;s a hard one to predict. It can mean, well, you&rsquo;re not going to see any activity. Or, if something goes, you&rsquo;re going to be screwed. It&rsquo;s hard to work with that one.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Moore&rsquo;s forecast offered more specifics.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Although decreasing light showers and decreasing winds are expected Sunday, cold temperatures should slow stabilization of existing wind slabs and help maintain the threat of further human-triggered avalanche activity, especially on previously wind-loaded terrain showing no evidence of recent avalanche activity,&rdquo; Moore wrote. </p>
<p>Spotty afternoon sunshine, he added, could raise the danger, especially on south-facing slopes.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_ad">
<div class="inner_ad">
<h3>Advertisement</h3>
<iframe class="nytmm-enterprise-ads-bigad" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" border="0" src=""></iframe>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>The snow had stopped at Stevens Pass by the time the lifts opened Sunday morning. The runs were quickly doodled with curvy lines. </p>
<p>Stifter sat in the cabin and examined the forecast on his laptop.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I have this image burned in my head,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;I had a coffee cup in my right hand, I was reading e-mails, and I read the Northwest Avalanche Center report. And it said &lsquo;considerable to high&rsquo; was the avalanche danger. And I read it out loud to Keith. And he listened, and I read it again &mdash; I read it twice &mdash; and looked at it. Huh. I&rsquo;ve skied enough to know that when it snows a lot, which it did, up to two feet, there&rsquo;s always going to be instability, with that much weight on an older snowpack.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Stifter left Carlsen behind and headed to the lifts. He found <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="jack">Jim Jack</span>. If anyone could judge terrain and snow in the backcountry, it was Jim Jack.</p>
<p>The license plate on Jack&rsquo;s Subaru Brat as a teenager read &ldquo;IM JIM.&rdquo; To family and his closest friends, he was Jimmy, sometimes J.J. To most everyone else, he was Jim Jack, blended into one name, accent on the first syllable: JIM-jack. </p>
<p>Jack was the head judge and former president of the International Freeskiers Association, which oversaw a world tour of competitions. At 46, he was a sort of Peter Pan of the ski world, a charismatic, carefree boy who never grew up, beloved by like-minded skiers and snowboarders half his age. </p>
<p>He spent winters traveling the world, spreading the gospel of freeskiing, professing the beauty of finding improbable ways down precarious slopes with grace, nerve and flair. He had been a competitor on the tour, distinguishable from great distances by the silkiness of his loose form, until he landed hard and took his own knee to his face, shattering the bones around his right eye. You could feel the screws when you touched his face.</p>
<p>He was a party accelerator with a penchant for streaking. He did drama in high school and never declined the stage as an adult. On Halloween, his costumes played off his name: Jack on the Rocks, Jim Jack in the Box, Cracker Jack, Jack Frost.</p>
<p>Wearing lederhosen, Jack starred in a cheeky promotional video for Leavenworth. He was a sure-handed shortstop for the team from Uncle Uli&rsquo;s, a bar and restaurant in the heart of town. A grilled chicken sandwich on the menu, smothered in spicy sauce, is named the Napkin&rsquo; Slappin&rsquo; Jim Jack.</p>
<p>Jack shared a bungalow off the highway, near the Howard Johnson, with his longtime girlfriend, Tiffany Abraham. They danced late at night in the kitchen and built bonfires in the backyard. The covered front porch held a pile of ski gear and a futon couch, perfect for watching the world go by, beer in hand. </p>
<p>Jack drove a 1994 Chevy pickup with 216,000 miles on it, topped by a Wilderness camper that he added for $350. Widely recognized on the highways and in ski area parking lots around the West, it was held together largely by duct tape and bungee cords. The radio&rsquo;s volume was stuck on high. If it is too loud, Jack told passengers, just roll down the window.</p>
<p>Jack and his camper rolled into the R.V. parking lot at Stevens Pass on Friday night. On weekends, when the snow was good, the lot filled with dozens of pickup campers and motor homes. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I woke up on Saturday in my R.V.,&rdquo; said <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="wangen">Tim Wangen</span>, a 53-year-old former commercial diver who lived in a cabin at nearby Lake Wenatchee. &ldquo;When I wake up, I look outside to see who is next to me. I saw that Jim Jack was next to me. I thought, cool, I got a great neighbor this week.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Jack and Wangen had skied a couple of runs Sunday morning by the time Stifter caught up to them. Wangen knew Tunnel Creek as well as anyone, having skied it since he was a boy. Jack traveled the world, scouting courses for extreme skiing. He knew how to avoid danger.</p>
<p>Stifter asked Jack about the avalanche report.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He&rsquo;s like: &lsquo;Yeah, not to worry,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;<span class="nytmm_single_quote left">&lsquo;</span>We&rsquo;ll just do it slowly and safely and just stay in the trees.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<!--subhead //-->
<h3 class="nytmm_left_margin">&lsquo;Gear Up?&rsquo;</h3>
<p>The fire pit sits at the center of the bustle on busy days. At the corner of the patio, in front of the lodge, it is a crossroads for people coming and going. Some pull up chairs and relax, facing the bowl of ski runs strung before them. When the clouds lift, Cowboy Mountain dominates the view high to the right. It can feel close enough to reach and touch. </p>
<p>By midmorning, the fire pit began attracting a growing but confused band of expert skiers. Some were local, some were visitors. Some knew others, some did not, but most knew either Chris Rudolph or Jim Jack. They traded nods and handshakes, unsure if others were headed to Tunnel Creek, too.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We didn&rsquo;t know why everyone was there,&rdquo; said Dan Abrams, there with Megan Michelson. &ldquo;We wondered if everyone was meeting up for the same reason. But it&rsquo;s like when you find out where the extra keg is at the party. You don&rsquo;t go tell everybody.&rdquo;</p>
<p><span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="hammond">Joel Hammond</span>, the 37-year-old regional sales representative for Salomon, had teamed with Rudolph to organize the previous day&rsquo;s women&rsquo;s event. He did not intend to ski Sunday until he awoke in Leavenworth and could not resist the lure of the fresh snow. He drove to Stevens Pass and sent a text message to Rudolph, still in a staff meeting.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Chris was like: &lsquo;Meet at the fire pit, where everybody meets. Then we&rsquo;re going to rally up,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Hammond said.</p>
<p>Hammond told Jack that he had the latest model of skis in his truck, then left to retrieve a pair for him to try. Stifter bought coffee, a couple of Americanos, from the stand for himself and Jack. </p>
<p><span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="carlson">Tim Carlson</span> and <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="pankey">Ron Pankey</span>, both 37 and childhood friends from Vermont, had spent the morning on the inbounds side of Cowboy Mountain, navigating near-vertical chutes and rock outcroppings. During a break, they spotted familiar faces near the fire pit. </p>
<p>Pankey was a former competitor on the Freeskiing World Tour, so he had known Jack since the mid-1990s. Like Jack, he eventually worked competitions around the world, including the X Games. </p>
<p>Carlson was a snowboarder, not a skier, and a regular at Stevens Pass. Earlier that week, he competed at Washington&rsquo;s Crystal Mountain. Jack worked the event, and Carlson slept several nights in Jack&rsquo;s camper.</p>
<p>When Carlson and Pankey arrived at Stevens Pass that Sunday, they joined <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="wesley">Tim Wesley</span>, known to most as Tall Tim &mdash; a lanky 39-year-old snowboarder from Leavenworth. The three merged with those waiting for Rudolph.</p>
<p>Another arrival was <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="peikert">Wenzel Peikert</span>, 29, an off-duty Stevens Pass ski instructor from Seattle. Skiing over the weekend without his wife and infant daughter, he hung around the Foggy Goggle and the R.V. lot on Saturday night. He, too, sent a message to Rudolph on Sunday, confirming the plan.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I wrote, &lsquo;Gear up?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;And he wrote, &lsquo;Yeah, for sure.&rsquo; So I went into the ski school and grabbed my pack, with my beacon, probe and shovel. I went to the fire pit and I met the whole group. You could tell they were a different level of skier by how they acted and how they dressed.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Among the strangers he saw was <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="castillo">Rob Castillo</span>, a 40-year-old father of two and former competitive skier. He had exchanged text messages with Jack. </p>
<p>Castillo and Jack lived together in Alta, Utah, for several years in the 1990s. They went helicopter skiing in Alaska and skied down mountains they had climbed in Washington. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Tunnel Creek at 11,&rdquo; Jack wrote. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Perfect,&rdquo; Castillo thought. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s just what I wanted to do.&rdquo; </p>
<p>At the fire pit, Castillo considered the others. </p>
<div class="nytmm_divider light no-phone"></div>
<div class="nytmm_photolayout no-phone clearfix">
<div class="nytmm_photolayout_left">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_TWesley-slide-XG4P/AVIE_TWesley-slide-XG4P-custom1.jpg" width="490" height="325" />
<div class="caption first">Tim Wesley, a snowboarder known as Tall Tim, at his house in Leavenworth, Wash. <span class="credit">Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></div>
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_MeganDan-slide-SWYR/AVIE_MeganDan-slide-SWYR-custom1.jpg" width="490" height="323" />
<div class="caption">Megan Michelson, freeskiing editor at ESPN.com, with Dan Abrams, a founder of Flylow, a maker of apparel marketed to backcountry skiers. <span class="credit">Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_photolayout_right">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_JJack-slide-12UY/AVIE_JJack-slide-12UY-custom1.jpg"  width="385" height="578" />
<div class="caption">Jim Jack, the head judge and former president of the International Freeskiers Association. <span class="credit">Michael Hanson/Aurora Photos, via Getty Images</span></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_divider light"></div>
<p>&ldquo;It was kind of like, &lsquo;All right, this group is getting bigger,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I wouldn&rsquo;t pop in with a bunch of no-names, necessarily, and trust any of them, but the ones I knew were definitely qualified to go. And they&rsquo;re not going to bring people out who aren&rsquo;t.&rdquo;</p>
<p>More than anything, Castillo wanted to ski for the first time all season with his two best friends at Stevens Pass &ndash; Jack and <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="brenan">Johnny Brenan</span>. </p>
<p>In the R.V. parking lot, a few hundred yards away, Johnny and Laurie Brenan convened in their motor home for an early lunch with their daughters, Josie, 10, and Nina, 7, part of the Stevens Pass ski teams. </p>
<p>Brenan, 41, grew up comfortably in the Seattle suburbs, not far from Jack. He followed his passion for skiing to Breckenridge, Colo., working as a ski patroller in the winter and a carpenter in the summer. A burly man whose five o&rsquo;clock shadow arrived by noon each day, he eventually opened a business that he named for home: Cascade Contracting. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I met Johnny at the Gold Pan in Breckenridge,&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;It was Thursday night, 25-cent beer night. He was sitting on the pool table, and he had an open spot next to him. And I said, &lsquo;I&rsquo;m going to go sit next to that cute guy.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>They married in 1997 and moved to Leavenworth. Brenan worked as a cabinetmaker, then resurrected Cascade Contracting. On the strength of Brenan&rsquo;s amicable personality and no-fear creativity, it blossomed with custom homes and expansive remodels.</p>
<p>The Brenans bought a deteriorated 100-year-old farmhouse on a hill in an apple orchard. Johnny Brenan lifted the structure on jacks, rebuilt the foundation and gutted the inside, intending to resell it as a bed-and-breakfast. The Brenans kept it for themselves to raise their family. </p>
<p>Brenan zipped from one construction site to another in his truck. He coached soccer teams. He held Monday night poker games in the garage, which Nina always helped prepare. He built a chicken coop in the yard.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Johnny and Josie bought five chickens, and they called the business Eggs, Ink,&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;They had signs and business cards. Then they bought 30 more chickens. It&rsquo;s like, she&rsquo;s 5 years old. But the more the merrier for Johnny, even with chickens.&rdquo;</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="jack">
<div class="profile_img jack"></div>
<h4>Jim Jack</h4>
<p>46, Head judge of the Freeskiing World Tour</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="wangen">
<div class="profile_img wangen"></div>
<h4>Tim Wangen</h4>
<p>53, Lifelong backcountry skier in Stevens Pass area</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="hammond">
<div class="profile_img hammond"></div>
<h4>Joel Hammond</h4>
<p>37, Regional sales representative, Salomon ski equipment</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="carlson">
<div class="profile_img carlson"></div>
<h4>Tim Carlson</h4>
<p>37, Competitive snowboarder, childhood friend of Ron Pankey</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="pankey">
<div class="profile_img pankey"></div>
<h4>Ron Pankey</h4>
<p>37, Competition director for Freeskiing World Tour, childhood friend of Tim Carlson</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="wesley">
<div class="profile_img wesley"></div>
<h4>Tim Wesley (Tall Tim)</h4>
<p>39, Owner of Shark Snowsurf snowboards</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer"  data-tag="peikert">
<div class="profile_img peikert"></div>
<h4>Wenzel Peikert</h4>
<p>29, Part-time ski instructor from Seattle</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="castillo">
<div class="profile_img castillo"></div>
<h4>Rob Castillo</h4>
<p>40, Former competitive skier, longtime friend of Jack and Brenan</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="brenan">
<div class="profile_img brenan"></div>
<h4>Johnny Brenan</h4>
<p>41, Home builder, married father of two</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_ad">
<div class="inner_ad">
<h3>Advertisement</h3>
<iframe class="nytmm-enterprise-ads-leaderboard" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" border="0" src=""></iframe>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>Sunday began perfectly for Brenan. The family R.V. was parked in space No. 3, where the satellite dish picked up the best television reception. Brenan was at the front of the lift line at dawn. </p>
<p>He offered to fetch coffee for those behind him, a trick he used to keep his place while he helped Laurie get their daughters fed and dressed. He returned to the line, excited for an increasingly rare chance to ski with old friends like Jack. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I dropped the kids off for ski team about 8:45,&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;I remember looking down and Johnny was yelling at Jim Jack, doing something with his hands, something crazy. They were like little boys in a candy store. They were so excited.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Back with his family for lunch, Brenan ate an egg sandwich and discussed a business deal on the phone. It was after 11, and he was afraid he would miss the Tunnel Creek run. </p>
<p>But Rudolph sent a couple of people text messages at about 11:15. He apologized for running late, and said he would be out in about 10 minutes. </p>
<p>Brenan had time. He made a pact with Josie.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Josie, be ready at 2,&rdquo; Brenan said. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m going to come back and we&rsquo;ll go on a powder mission. Be here, because I&rsquo;ll be here.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Brenan strapped on his avalanche beacon, also called a transceiver, a device that emits a silent signal for others to detect your location in case of burial. A friend in the R.V. noted that its batteries were dead. Brenan replaced them with fresh ones.</p>
<p>&ldquo;What&rsquo;s that, Papa?&rdquo; Nina asked her father. </p>
<p>Brenan paused to show her how it worked.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He explained it,&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;It was understood that avalanche beacons were really for body recovery. Not many people survive avalanches. He would say that.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Brenan gathered his things and headed toward the fire pit to join his friends. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I said, &lsquo;Are you sure it&rsquo;s safe?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;He looked me right in the eye and said: &lsquo;Of course. I wouldn&rsquo;t be going if it weren&rsquo;t.&rsquo; I said O.K. because I knew that was true.&rdquo;</p>
<p>At about 11:30, Rudolph burst through the doors of the lodge at Stevens Pass. He was surprised by the size of the group waiting for him, but he barely broke stride.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Get me out of here before another spreadsheet finds me,&rdquo; he said.</p>
<p>The group, jolted into action, scattered to gather gear.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We all rallied up, jumped on the lifts,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I remember seeing some other buddies of mine later, like: &lsquo;Oh, I wanted to go out so bad with you guys that day. It looked like such a fun crew.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3>The Backcountry Beckons</h3>
<div class="nytmm_inline float phone-nofloat phone-photo-fullspan">
<div class="nytmm_slideshow_poster nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="stevenspass">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_StevensPass-slide-F161/AVIE_StevensPass-slide-F161-custom1-v2.jpg" width="640" height="425" />
<div class="nytmm_play"></div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Looking south across U.S. 2, where Stevens Pass is nestled between Big Chief Mountain, left, and Cowboy Mountain, right, in the Cascades. <span class="credit">Chase Jarvis</span></div>
</div>
<p>Stevens Pass opened in the winter of 1937-38 with a rope tow on Big Chief Mountain. A lodge and five new tows were added in the 1940s, including a mile-long T-bar that pulled people up the side of Cowboy Mountain. The ski area took shape in the bowl below the crescent-shape ridge that connects the two mountains. </p>
<p>Seventh Heaven, a two-person lift up a steep wall of Cowboy Mountain, changed the complexion of Stevens Pass when it was built in 1960. It opened a high swath of expert terrain, now marked as double diamond &mdash; experts only &mdash; on posted signs and the ski map. </p>
<p>It also provided easy access to the top of the high ridgeline. Back then, few people dared to remove their skis and hike the few hundred extra feet to the summit. &ldquo;When I was younger at Stevens, no one skied off Cowboy &mdash; maybe just a few locals,&rdquo; said Wangen, who has skied the area for nearly five decades. &ldquo;But the last 20 years, it&rsquo;s gone ballistic.&rdquo; </p>
<p>Now there is a steady procession of expert skiers and snowboarders through the boundary gate next to the top of the lift. Most drop off the left side of the ridge, back into the resort, through the rocky and narrow chutes. </p>
<p>Those who drop away from the ski area, toward Tunnel Creek, are simply following a much wider trend into &ldquo;sidecountry&rdquo; &mdash; backcountry slopes easily entered by lifts and, sometimes, a short hike. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t like the term &lsquo;sidecountry,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Moore, the avalanche forecaster, said. &ldquo;It makes it sound like &lsquo;backcountry light.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>The rise of backcountry skiing can be credited to a collision of factors. </p>
<p>Ski areas that once vigilantly policed their boundaries, from Jackson Hole, Wyo., to Squaw Valley, Calif., have gradually opened their gates to the territory surrounding them. While that has led to wrangling over liability issues and raised debate over search-and-rescue responsibilities, most areas note that they are carved out of public land. They really cannot keep people from going there.</p>
<p>But ski areas also see the potential to attract more ticket-buying customers, and more influential ones, by blurring the boundary lines. Many areas slyly promote not just the terrain inside their borders, but the wilder topography beyond, using the power of media and word of mouth &mdash; as Rudolph did for Stevens Pass. </p>
<p>Skiing adjacent to ski areas, however, can numb people to risk. Easy access, familiar terrain and a belief that help is just a short distance away may lead people to descend slopes they might avoid in deeper wilderness. </p>
<p>While most backcountry users would not consider entering known avalanche territory without a beacon, one study last winter at Loveland Ski Area in Colorado found that fewer than 40 percent of people who passed through a boundary gate wore one.</p>
<p>Equipment advances have emboldened people. Intermediate powder skiers have been turned into expert ones thanks to fatter skis and the &ldquo;rocker&rdquo; shape of their tips &mdash; design advances borrowed from snowboarding. Popular ski bindings now temporarily detach at the heel, allowing skiers to glide up rises like a cross-country skier, then reconnect so they can descend like a professional downhiller. </p>
<p>Snowboards have borrowed from skis, too. Some models can be quickly split into two pieces, allowing users to stride up short hills in pursuit of bigger descents.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>Similar advances in safety gear, such as easy-to-use digital beacons and <span class="nytmm_video_trigger graphic" data-trigger="airbag_graphic">air bags</span>, have helped make the backcountry feel less dangerous. Beacons help rescuers find people buried under the snow, while air bags deploy a large balloon meant to help keep the skier closer to the surface of an avalanche. A leading American manufacturer of safety gear is named, appropriately, Backcountry Access.</p>
<p>Companies, including Salomon and Flylow, have marketed heavily to ride the backcountry trend. They are keenly aware that many buyers will never ski the backcountry but want to dress the part.</p>
<p>Those marketing shifts have coincided with a generation raised on the glorification of risk. From X Games to YouTube videos, helmet cameras to social media, the culture rewards vicarious thrills and video one-upmanship. This generation no longer automatically adheres to the axiom of waiting a day for safer conditions. The relative placidness of inbounds skiing is no match for the greater adventure of untamed terrain.</p>
<p>Among avalanche forecasters and the growing cottage industry of safety instructors, there is pride in noting that the number of fatalities has risen at a slower rate than the number of backcountry users. But they see themselves as part of a difficult race between the coming hordes and the tools to protect them. </p>
<p>&ldquo;You could argue that skiers have never been this educated or safe,&rdquo; Stifter, the Powder magazine editor, said. &ldquo;There&rsquo;s been a huge emergence and emphasis on avalanche classes. Then you also have this lifesaving technology. But if you go to Jackson or Utah, you&rsquo;ll see people who are not educated, who are just going out there because they see it in the movies and they see it in magazines like Powder: there&rsquo;s fresh tracks and, man, it looks like fun.&rdquo;</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_airbag_top" style="display:none"></div>
<div class="nytmm_triggered_video nytmm_touch_triggered_video nytmm_airbag_graphic quick_video" data-trigger="airbag-graphic" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/airbag_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/airbag_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/airbag.jpg" data-touch-controls="false" data-touch-reset-video="false" data-width="200" data-height="313" data-loop="false"></div>
<div class="caption nytmm_airbag">Air bags are designed to keep a skier closer to the surface of an avalanche.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article //-->
<div class="nytmm_article last">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>At the top of Seventh Heaven, the members of the group took off their skis and snowboards. Directly to the right of the lift&rsquo;s unloading ramp was a narrow trail that disappeared up through a clog of trees.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float nytmm_photo_wide clearfix no_phone">
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_HikeUp-slide-15RB/AVIE_HikeUp-slide-15RB-custom2.jpg" width="365" height="256" />
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_HikeUp-slide-7BUB/AVIE_HikeUp-slide-7BUB-custom1.jpg" width="365" height="256" />
</div>
<div class="caption">Reaching Tunnel Creek from Stevens Pass ski area requires taking two lifts, slipping through the boundary gate, which was closed temporarily after the avalanche, then hiking to the top of Cowboy Mountain. <span class="credit">Left, Stevens Pass Ski Patrol; right, Chase Jarvis</span></div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;Read this,&rdquo; one sign read in all capital letters. &ldquo;Ski Area Boundary. Minimum of $1000.00 rescue fee! Do you have a partner, beacon, probe and shovel? Explosives may be used in this area at any time. Continue at your own risk.&rdquo;</p>
<p>A smaller sign read: &ldquo;Stop. Ski Area Boundary. No ski patrol or snow control beyond this point.&rdquo;</p>
<p>To the right was a gray steel box. It was labeled, &ldquo;Avalanche Transceiver Check Station.&rdquo;</p>
<p>&ldquo;You walk by and it goes beep, beep,&rdquo; Rob Castillo said. &ldquo;So as we were going through, you heard it going all the way, right on everyone. Beep. Beep. Beep.&rdquo;</p>
<p>While there are no laws dictating what equipment people carry into the backcountry, there is a code. Carry a beacon (for sending and receiving signals), a probe (for poking for victims in the snow) and a shovel (for digging them out).</p>
<p>&ldquo;When you go in the backcountry, you&rsquo;re trusting your life in the hands of everybody else and they&rsquo;re trusting their life in you,&rdquo; Michelson said. &ldquo;If I get buried and my ski partner doesn&rsquo;t have a beacon, shovel or probe, it&rsquo;s my life on the line.&rdquo;</p>
<p>One member of the party did not elicit a beep:  <span class="nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="dessert">Erin Dessert</span>, a 35-year-old snowboarder who was early for her afternoon shift as a Stevens Pass lift operator. Wesley invited her along. She thought everyone was riding off the front side of Cowboy Mountain, back into the ski area. </p>
<p>The group marched single file along the narrow ridge for a few minutes until it reached a wider area to convene. Tracks dropped back over a steep edge and into the ski area to the left. </p>
<p>To the right was nothing but deep powder, hidden by thick trees, like a curtain to the big attraction.</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_character_box clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="dessert">
<div class="profile_img dessert"></div>
<h4>Erin Dessert</h4>
<p>35, Snowboarder, Stevens Pass lift operator</p>
<p class="nytmm_view_ss">View Slideshow</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article //-->

					data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/hikein_final.webm"
					data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/hikein.jpg"
					data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/hikein.jpg"
					data-touch-media="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/hikein.mp4"
					data-loop="false">
</div>
