</div>
<!--end superpart //-->
<!--Section 3//-->
<div class="nytmm_section" name="descent-begins" data-label="Descent Begins">
<div class="nytmm_article grid_cover">
<div class="nytmm_chapter_head" id="nytmm_head_2">
<div class="nytmm_inner_head">
<span>Part Three</span>
<h2>The Descent Begins</h2>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_grid clearfix">
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img abrams"></div><span>Dan Abrams</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img brenan"></div><span>Johnny Brenan</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img carlsen"></div><span>Keith Carlsen</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img carlson"></div><span>Tim Carlson</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img castillo"></div><span>Rob Castillo</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img dessert"></div><span>Erin Dessert</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img hammond"></div><span>Joel Hammond</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img jack"></div><span>Jim Jack</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img michelson"></div><span>Megan Michelson</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img pankey"></div><span>Ron Pankey</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img peikert"></div><span>Wenzel Peikert</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img rudolph"></div><span>Chris Rudolph</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img saugstad"></div><span>Elyse Saugstad</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img stifter"></div><span>John Stifter</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img wangen"></div><span>Tim Wangen</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_grid_item"><div class="profile_img wesley"></div><span>Tim Wesley</span></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p><span class="dropcap">T</span>here were 16 people, although no one thought to count at the time. Their ages ranged from 29 to 53.</p>
<p>&ldquo;This was a crew that seemed like it was assembled by some higher force,&rdquo; Dessert said.</p>
<p>It was about 11:45. The storm had passed. A low, pewter sky hid the surrounding peaks. Castillo glanced around at the others, wearing helmets and rainbow hues, a kaleidoscope of color amid the gray surroundings, like sprinkles on vanilla ice cream.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was thinking, wow, what a bunch of heavies,&rdquo; he said.</p>
<p>There was loose banter and a few casual introductions. Not everyone met everyone else. Someone pulled out marijuana to smoke, and passed it.</p>
<p>Wesley, the snowboarder known as Tall Tim, saw the size of the assembled group. More than a dozen, he thought.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That never happens,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;And it&rsquo;s basically the legends of Stevens Pass standing up there.&rdquo;</p>
<p>There was little doubt that those with Tunnel Creek experience knew the way. About half the group had been down dozens of times each, if not hundreds. The others would follow.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float nytmm_photo_stack clearfix no_phone">
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/group_at_top.jpg" width="450" height="500" />
</div>
<div class="caption bottom_align"><div class="bottom">Among the 16 skiers and snowboarders who congregated at the top of Cowboy Mountain were, from left, Ron Pankey, Chris Rudolph, Rob Castillo, Joel Hammond and Wenzel Peikert. <span class="credit">Erin Dessert</span></div></div>
</div>
<p>There was no broad discussion of the route down. Pockets of the group talked about staying left, not being too greedy by going too far down the meadow before cutting across.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That run, it&rsquo;s not that it&rsquo;s supersteep, or there are cliffs, or that it&rsquo;s a really rowdy run,&rdquo; Carlson, one of the Stevens Pass regulars, said. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s that if anything goes wrong, it&rsquo;s a terrain trap. If somebody happens to set off even a slough slide and you&rsquo;re below them in Tunnel, it all bottlenecks and really adds up superfast. That&rsquo;s the reason that run is heavy. It&rsquo;s notorious.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Unspoken anxiety spread among those unfamiliar with the descent. The mere size of the group spooked some. Backcountry users of all types &mdash; skiers, snowboarders, snowmobilers and climbers &mdash; worry about how much of a load a slope can absorb before it gives way. They worry about people above them causing an avalanche. When it comes to the backcountry, there is usually not safety in large numbers. </p>
<p>That is not only because of the physical impact on the snow. It is because of the complicated dynamics that large groups create. Deadly avalanches are usually the product of bad decisions &mdash; human nature, not Mother Nature.</p>
<p>&ldquo;If it was up to me, I would never have gone backcountry skiing with 12 people,&rdquo; Michelson, the ESPN journalist, said. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s just way too many. But there were sort of the social dynamics of that &mdash; where I didn&rsquo;t want to be the one to say, you know, &lsquo;Hey, this is too big a group and we shouldn&rsquo;t be doing this.&rsquo; I was invited by someone else, so I didn&rsquo;t want to stand up and cause a fuss. And not to play the gender card, but there were 2 girls and 10 guys, and I didn&rsquo;t want to be the whiny female figure, you know? So I just followed along.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Others suppressed reservations, too. </p>
<p>&ldquo;The whole thing felt rushed to me, and it felt kind of like this covert operation,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;Which it kind of was, because you&rsquo;re going out of bounds. It&rsquo;s obviously acceptable, especially when you&rsquo;re going out there with all these locals and the director of marketing. It&rsquo;s not illegal or anything. It just had this rushed feeling from the time Chris walked out of the office, and he&rsquo;s like, &lsquo;All right, let&rsquo;s go.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>Carlsen, Stifter&rsquo;s Powder colleague, was uneasy. He tried to convince himself that it was a good idea. </p>
<p>&ldquo;There&rsquo;s no way this entire group can make a decision that isn&rsquo;t smart,&rdquo; he said to himself. &ldquo;Of course it&rsquo;s fine, if we&rsquo;re all going. It&rsquo;s got to be fine.&rdquo;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article reel_paths last">
<div class="nytmm_reel_sequence fs_reel" id="nytmm_paths_2" data-frames="719" data-start="51" data-path="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/AviePaths_12_6/AviePathsDec6_%ddd.png" data-speed="10" data-modreduce="7">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/AvalanchePathsBackground.jpg"
                         class="reel_bkg"/>
<div class="nytmm_reel_labels">
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label1" data-tag="hikein">Hike to Tunnel Creek</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label2" data-tag="firstpaths">Chris Rudolph</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label3" data-tag="firstpaths">Wesley, Pankey<br />and Carlson</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_rudolph" data-tag="rudolph">Chris Rudolph</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_saugstad" data-tag="saugstad">Elyse Saugstad</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_castillo" data-tag="castillo">Rob Castillo</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_brenan" data-tag="brenan">Johnny Brenan</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_wangen" data-tag="wangen">Tim Wangen</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_peikert" data-tag="peikert">Wenzel Peikert</div>
<div class="nytmm_reel_label nytmm_reel_tagged" id="nytmm_label_jack" data-tag="jack">Jim Jack</div>
</div>
<!--fallback for reel -->
<div class="nytmm_reel_fallback" style="display:none">
<div class="nytmm_fallback_ss">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_1" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Hike.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_2" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Figure8.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_3" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Rudolph.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_4" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Saugstad.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_5" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Castillo.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_6" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Brenan.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_7" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Wangen.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_8" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_Peikert.jpg">
<img id="ntmm_reel_static_9" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_JimJack.jpg">
<!--<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/web_PathsIE8_FullGroup.jpg">-->
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="51"></span>
<p><span class="nytmm_reel_tag" data-tag="hikein"></span>After a few minutes, the small talk faded. Worries went unexpressed.</p>
<p>&ldquo;When you&rsquo;re up on top of a peak like that, it&rsquo;s usually hang out for a second, and then it&rsquo;s momentum,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;You just kind of feel it. Everyone&rsquo;s like: &lsquo;O.K., we&rsquo;re not here to hang out. Let&rsquo;s start going.&rsquo; So I saw people starting to slide, get going, and I was like: &lsquo;Hey, Johnny, partner up. Buddy system. Let&rsquo;s go. Me and you.&rsquo; And at that point, it clicked. Everyone&rsquo;s like, yeah, partners, partners, partners.&rdquo;</p>
<p>It is a tenet of avalanche safety, and the command snapped the group to attention. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Someone said, &lsquo;Partner up &mdash; everyone should grab a partner,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Carlsen said. &ldquo;Immediately I thought, We&rsquo;re in a somewhat serious situation. It wasn&rsquo;t just grab a partner so you don&rsquo;t get lost. It was grab a partner so you. ...</p>
<p>&ldquo;It just felt bigger all of a sudden.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Rudolph, the Stevens Pass marketing director, teamed with Saugstad, the professional skier.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was really excited about that,&rdquo; Saugstad said, &ldquo;because he&rsquo;s just such a cool guy and I thought, wow, cool, he wants to be my partner. A very trustworthy guy that&rsquo;s an amazing skier.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Jack, on borrowed Salomon skis, paired with Joel Hammond, the Salomon representative. Carlson looked at Pankey, his childhood friend. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Dude, you&rsquo;re coming with me,&rdquo; he said. </p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="107"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="108"></span>
<p><span class="nytmm_reel_tag" data-tag="firstpaths"></span>Wesley gave a little whistle to Carlson and Pankey and nodded downhill. He wanted to be first. The conditions were too good to waste time, and he did not want to be slowed by the huge pack. </p>
<p>With little warning, Wesley dropped straight through the large cluster of trees, using firs as a slalom course. Pankey and Carlson followed.</p>
<p>Rudolph, always up for competition, sped around the trees, not through them. He curved around a banked C-shape turn that dropped him a couple hundred feet into the broad meadow below.</p>
<p>He arrived just in time to see Wesley, Pankey and Carlson burst from the trees into the open powder. Rudolph pointed his ski poles and playfully shouted invectives as their tracks crossed.</p>
<p>Wesley laughed, and his two friends followed him left and over a small rise. </p>
<p>Rudolph headed straight down the mountain. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I remember looking back at where he was going and being confused,&rdquo; Wesley said. &ldquo;Like, &lsquo;Where is he going?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>All the locals in the group presumed they knew what the others were thinking. They did not.</p>
<p>&ldquo;When you know an avalanche is not very likely, that&rsquo;s a great way to go,&rdquo; Wesley said of Rudolph&rsquo;s choice to ski straight down farther. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s three open glades of awesome powder.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Earlier that morning, Wesley and Carlson had skied the opposite side of Cowboy Mountain, in the ski area. It had been cleared of avalanches by the ski patrol at dawn, but the two still triggered several slough slides &mdash; small, shallow avalanches that washed at their feet and petered out before snagging victims.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That&rsquo;s why, when they said we&rsquo;re doing Tunnel, I was like, &lsquo;Ooh, dicey,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Wesley said. </p>
<p>Pankey and Carlson followed Wesley and looked back, too, wondering why Rudolph and the others were not following them toward relatively safer terrain. Within a minute, long enough to be well out of sight of the group they left behind, the three men found something that made them stop.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We were right on top of a knoll, a little rollover, where we were about to make some really fun turns, and <span class="nytmm_video_trigger">we saw that the face had already slid</span>,&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;It was pretty large.&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster" id="smallslides_video">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/video-avalanche-smallslides/video-avalanche-smallslides-custom1-v3.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">Signs of Trouble</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001956086" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19389_1_avalanche-smallslides_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/video-avalanche-smallslides/video-avalanche-smallslides-custom1-v3.jpg" data-width="348" data-height="196" data-touch-width="487" data-touch-height="275"></div>
</div>
<div class="caption">After breaking from the larger group, Ron Pankey and two others discover nearby avalanche activity.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Alarmed, the three decided to go farther left. They crossed through trees and avoided big meadows and steep pitches. They soon found evidence of another avalanche, this one cutting through the forest. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;d really never seen anything slide in the trees like that,&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;And that was definitely like: &lsquo;Holy cow, we shouldn&rsquo;t be back here, Ron. Let&rsquo;s go left. Let&rsquo;s go hard left.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>Wesley had disappeared in the pale light. He left nothing but a track through the deep snow that the others tried to follow.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I just went, and didn&rsquo;t really stop,&rdquo; Wesley said. &ldquo;I went all the way down. But I&rsquo;ve never taken a run where I looked uphill more times in fear.&rdquo;</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="180" data-tag=""></span>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3 class="nytmm_left_margin">&lsquo;I Got Eyes on You&rsquo;</h3>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="181"></span>
<p>Rudolph stopped on the left edge of the upper meadow, above a cluster of trees. Others filed behind him, spilling down the mountain in plumes of spraying snow. </p>
<p>Erin Dessert did not follow. She was confused. She was once a Tunnel Creek regular, until a nonfatal avalanche captured five friends in 2002 and scared her away.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Chris Rudolph&rsquo;s, like, totally all about safety protocol and mountain awareness and wisdom,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;That guy knows the conditions like an animal. He has instincts. It didn&rsquo;t register, even for a second, that he might be bringing this group to Tunnel Creek. It wasn&rsquo;t logical. I thought we were doing the front side.&rdquo;</p>
<p>She headed hard to the right, away from the others. The other snowboarders that she knew, Carlson and Wesley, were gone in the opposite direction. Some in the remaining group noticed Dessert heading away in the distance and dismissed her as an oblivious backcountry rookie. She dipped out of sight in a lonely panic.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;ve been riding Stevens Pass since I was 3 years old,&rdquo; Dessert said. &ldquo;I can tell circumstances, and I just felt like something besides myself was in charge. They&rsquo;re all so professional and intelligent and driven and powerful and riding with athletic prowess, yet everything in my mind was going off, wanting to tell them to stop.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Rudolph and the others, now a group of 12, were focused downhill. It was 11:52 a.m. Rudolph did not wait for the back of the pack to arrive before continuing to demonstrate the way.</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="239"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="240"></span>
<p>&ldquo;So <span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="rudolph">Chris Rudolph</span> went first, and then he pulled into the trees and we waited for a sec,&rdquo; said Castillo, who was near the front of the group, wearing a helmet camera. &ldquo;He goes out of sight and behind the trees. So I said, &lsquo;O.K., Megan, go ahead, spoon those tracks, and you&rsquo;ll see Chris on the left.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>It was not Megan Michelson. It was Elyse Saugstad.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I thought it was Megan,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I said, &lsquo;Are you Megan?&rsquo; She said, &lsquo;No, no, I&rsquo;m Elyse.&rsquo; That&rsquo;s when I met Elyse. It was right there. And she made these turns that were like: &lsquo;Aah, I think I know who that is. I&rsquo;ve seen her name. Those are pro turns.&rsquo; She ripped the hell out of it.&rdquo;</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="329"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="330"></span>
<p><span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="saugstad">Saugstad</span> traced through the knee-deep snow just to the right of Rudolph&rsquo;s elongated S-shape tracks. She dipped through trees at a pinch in the meadow and disappeared out of sight. <span class="nytmm_video_trigger">She crossed over Rudolph&rsquo;s tracks and giggled</span>. After about 30 seconds, she was back at Rudolph&rsquo;s side, having cut left into a notch of the trees again.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster" id="elysegopro_video">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/video-avalanche-elysegopro/video-avalanche-elysegopro-custom1.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">Skiing Down</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001956083" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19388_1_avalanche-elysegopro_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/video-avalanche-elysegopro/video-avalanche-elysegopro-custom1.jpg" data-width="348" data-height="196" data-touch-width="487" data-touch-height="275"></div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Elyse Saugstad, second in the group, skis Tunnel Creek.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;We skied to an area that was probably about 500 feet down or so from where we started,&rdquo; Saugstad said. &ldquo;And where we skied to was an area of old-growth trees. You know, several-hundred-year-old trees. A very good indication that this is a safe place. Things don&rsquo;t happen here.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Castillo and Brenan teased each other about who would go next. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Finally, he&rsquo;s like, &lsquo;Go ahead, I got eyes on you,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Castillo said.</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="390"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="391"></span>
<p>From where Rudolph and Saugstad stopped, they could not see the subsequent skiers approach. <span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="castillo">Castillo</span> went past and cut left. His camera recorded Rudolph and Saugstad whooping their approval as he stopped in a shower of powder, about 40 feet below them.</p>
<p>But just before he stopped, Castillo was jolted by a weird sensation.</p>
<p>&ldquo;A little pang, like, ooh, this is a pretty heavy day out here,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;Thing&rsquo;s holding, but I remember having a feeling.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Castillo stopped above two trees. He nestled close and pushed his right ski tight against them.</p>
<p>&ldquo;A lot of people think you should be below trees, but I stand above them,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m like, &lsquo;I&rsquo;d rather get pinned against this than taken through.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="450"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="451"></span>
<p>His helmet camera showed that 14 seconds after Castillo stopped, <span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="brenan">Brenan</span> appeared through the trees above Rudolph and Saugstad. Brenan had hugged the tree line on the left, avoiding the open meadow, then slalomed through the patch that the others used for protection. He stopped in a spray of snow a few feet from Rudolph and Saugstad.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That was sick!&rdquo; someone shouted.</p>
<p>Castillo silently took note of the terrain.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was downhill from them &mdash; skier&rsquo;s right from them,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;But the trees that they were behind, I didn&rsquo;t think it was a bad spot to stop. They were huge. Giant old-growths that three of us probably can&rsquo;t put our hands around.&rdquo;</p>
<p>But he knew the direction of the slope did not follow the meadow. It dipped harder left into the trees, down toward a gully. And there were still a lot of skiers above them.</p>
<p>Saugstad was next to Rudolph. Brenan was a few feet away.</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="540"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="541"></span>
<p>&ldquo;We weren&rsquo;t straight across from each other, in a perfect horizontal line on the slope,&rdquo; Saugstad said. &ldquo;We were peppered up and down, spread out.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Castillo kept his attention up the hill. Less than 30 seconds after Brenan stopped, he saw <span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="wangen">Tim Wangen</span> cut through the trees above the earlier arrivals, gliding horizontally through the forest. Wangen had been taught how to navigate Tunnel Creek by his father. He knew that the farther down the mountain he went, the harder it would be to cut over the ridge and into the next big meadow. He crossed the shallow gully and rose up the other side. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I could see the others when I cut over,&rdquo; Wangen said. &ldquo;I thought: Oh yeah, that&rsquo;s a bad place to be. That&rsquo;s a bad place to be with that many people. But I didn&rsquo;t say anything. I didn&rsquo;t want to be the jerk.&rdquo;</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="630"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="631"></span>
<p>Wangen had told Peikert to follow his tracks, and <span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="peikert">Peikert</span> was close behind. Castillo watched where they went. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Want to cut over?&rdquo; Castillo shouted to those above him.</p>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3>Sliding Snow</h3>
<p>The start of an avalanche is unlike any other force of nature.</p>
<p>A hurricane is foretold by wind and lashing waves. A tornado often is spotted before it strikes. Lightning is usually presaged by black clouds and rumbling thunder.</p>
<p>Avalanches rarely provide such a warning. Unlike waves or wind, tremors or storms, they are usually triggered by their own victims, sometimes unaware of what has been unleashed. </p>
<p>&ldquo;If you swim out in the ocean, the ocean&rsquo;s always alive,&rdquo; Saugstad said. &ldquo;You can feel it. But the mountains feel like they&rsquo;re asleep.&rdquo; </p>
<p>Back up the mountain, Jack never seemed worried. That was his nature. Here he was, a rare weekend off, skiing with some of his best friends from Leavenworth and people from Powder and ESPN and all over the industry, on an epic run on a perfect powder day. </p>
<p>Carlsen, the Powder photographer, had never been to Tunnel Creek. The first few easy turns gave way to a slope that fell steeply away, out of sight. He sidled up to Jack.</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="690"></span>
<span class="reel_tag" data-start="691"></span>
<p>&ldquo;I grabbed him, and I said, &lsquo;What is the move here?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Carlsen said. &ldquo;It was basically like, &lsquo;This is getting real, how do we handle it?&rsquo; He&rsquo;s like: &lsquo;Oh, no big deal. We go out here, swing out, make a few pow turns, and get back in the trees.&rsquo; I looked at him and said, &lsquo;Have a great run.&rsquo; Gave him a fist, a knuckle-to-knuckle high-five thing. And that was it. I watched him swing out, way out, skier&rsquo;s right, and then dive into his turn left.&rdquo;</p>
<p><span class="nytmm_reel_tag nytmm_character_tag nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="jack">Jack</span> flowed through the thick powder with his typical ease. He skied the way other people walked down a sidewalk, a friend had said. </p>
<p>Jack disappeared over the knoll, gliding through the trees in the middle of the meadow. Behind him, the five remaining skiers watched in silence.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He looked like he was having a great time, the run of his life, in fact,&rdquo; Michelson said. &ldquo;And he actually made, I remember, a little &lsquo;woo&rsquo; sound, as he dropped in on his first or second turn because the snow was really good. It was deep and light.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Then the snow changed without warning.</p>
<p>Across the meadow, above Jack, loose snow seemed to chase him down the hill and out of sight.</p>
<p>Not everyone saw it. A couple did. They caught it in their peripheral vision and were unsure what to make of it.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That was sketchy,&rdquo; Hammond said.</p>
<p>The five others listened. Not a sound. They stared for clues through the flat light below a murky sky. Nothing.</p>
<p>Silent seconds ticked. Finally, Hammond spotted the first sign of evidence. It came from a tree, one among thousands, far down the hill, almost out of sight. Only the top of it was visible, and it was covered in snow.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I saw it moving,&rdquo; Hammond said. &ldquo;Like something had hit the tree, and it shook. And I could see the powder falling off the tree.&rdquo;</p>
<span class="reel_tag" data-end="769"></span>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="rudolph">
<div class="profile_img rudolph"></div>

<p>30, Director of marketing at Stevens Pass</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="saugstad">
<div class="profile_img saugstad"></div>

<p>33, Professional freeskier</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="castillo">
<div class="profile_img castillo"></div>
<h4>Rob Castillo</h4>
<p>40, Former competitive skier, longtime friend of Jack and Brenan</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="brenan">
<div class="profile_img brenan"></div>

<p>41, Home builder, married father of two</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="wangen">
<div class="profile_img wangen"></div>

<p>53, Lifelong backcountry skier in Stevens Pass area</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="peikert">
<div class="profile_img peikert"></div>
