<p>29, Part-time ski instructor</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_character_box nytmm_reel_tagged clearfix nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="jack">
<div class="profile_img jack"></div>
<h4>Jim Jack</h4>
<p>46, Head judge of the Freeskiing World Tour</p>
<div class="rightArrow"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end superpart //-->
<!--section 4 //-->
<div class="nytmm_section" name="blur-of-white" data-label="Blur of White">
<div class="nytmm_article video_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_video nytmm_ie_static nytmm_touch_fs_blurphotoseq" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter4_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter4_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter4.jpg" data-loop="true"></div>
<div class="nytmm_chapter_head light" id="nytmm_head_3">
<div class="nytmm_inner_head">
<span>Part Four</span>
<h2>Blur of White</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article top">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p><span class="dropcap">A</span> few hundred yards down the mountain, a ghostly white fog rushed through the forest.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I saw it,&rdquo; Saugstad said. &ldquo;I saw it coming. But it was weird because it was coming through the trees. It was like snow billowing through the trees. Because it was such a treed area, I think for the first second I saw it I didn&rsquo;t believe it.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Wangen and Peikert had just traversed in front of its path. It did not miss them by much.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know if I&rsquo;d even come to a stop when I heard it,&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;It was almost like wind and pressure more than noise. It literally felt like a freight train went over my tails. It wasn&rsquo;t a deep rumble. I could feel this rush of air.&rdquo;</p>
<p>It was a blur of white, its shattered pieces moving about 50 m.p.h., a powder cloud two stories tall. </p>
<p>Rudolph was the only one to scream. </p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article last nytmm_colorchange" data-colorchrome="#9ea3ac" data-colorff="#9fa3ad" data-color="#999fa9">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>&ldquo;Avalanche! Elyse!&rdquo; Rudolph shouted. </p>
<p>Saugstad tried to stride right, hoping to escape. She barely moved before snow flowed through her legs, dragging her down like a riptide.</p>
<p>She pulled the cord on her air bag. She was overwhelmed so quickly by the rising snow that she did not know if it inflated. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I had no ability to control what was happening to me,&rdquo; Saugstad said. &ldquo;I was being tossed over and over and over. It was like being in a washing machine and all my body parts flailing every way. I didn&rsquo;t know which way was up. I didn&rsquo;t know which way was down. I couldn&rsquo;t see anything.&rdquo;</p>
<p>She is likely to have tumbled just past Castillo. He groaned and turned his face away. He stuck his head between two trees, like a prisoner in a stockade. </p>
<p>For 16 seconds, snow and ice pounded his back and washed over him. His shoulders were jammed against the trees. His face pushed into branches of pine needles. He could feel the heavy assault of snow lashing at his back.</p>
<p>Trees cracked around him. Some in the path were chopped in half &mdash; the stumps left in the soil, the rest carried away in the growing torrent. </p>
<p>The avalanche, a relatively small one, started with about 6,000 cubic meters of snow and collected 7,000 cubic meters more on the way down. It probably weighed about 11 million pounds. </p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article graphic_cover autoplay_top">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_video_graphic nytmm_ie_mp4" id="avalanche_sim_graphic" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/avalanche_sim_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/avalanche_sim_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/avalanche_sim.jpg" data-loop="false" data-touch-controls="true">
<div class="nytmm_graphiccover_label">
<div id="nytmm_sim_label1">
<span>The Tunnel Creek Avalanche</span><br />
In real time
</div>
<div id="nytmm_sim_label2">Based on a simulation from the Swiss Federal Institute of Snow and Avalanche Research</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_nondesktop credit">Based on a simulation from the Swiss Federal Institute of Snow and Avalanche Research</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>The trees Castillo hugged in each arm swayed but held. He told himself that when he felt the flow slow, he would pop a hand in the air so that it might stick out of the snow and make him easier to rescue. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Just as I had the thought about what I&rsquo;m going to do, wondering if it was going to bury me, that&rsquo;s right when I could feel it,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;It was like a wave. Like when you&rsquo;re in the ocean and the tide moves away from you. You&rsquo;re getting thrashed and you feel it pull out and you&rsquo;re like, O.K., I can stand up now.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Castillo saw daylight again. His camera captured snow sliding past his legs for another 13 seconds. The forest sounded as if it were full of sickly frogs. It was the trees, scrubbed of their fresh snow, still swaying and creaking around him.</p>
<p>Castillo turned to look back up the hill.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Where there were three people, there was nobody,&rdquo; Castillo said.</p>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3>A Ticking Clock</h3>
<p>He did not know who or what set off the avalanche. He did not know how far down the mountain it went. All he knew was that about a dozen people had been above him a minute earlier, and that the gully below him descended another 2,000 vertical feet to the valley floor. </p>
<p>And he was alone. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Johnny! Johnny Brenan!&rdquo; Castillo screamed into the stillness, his voice escalating with panic. The scope of the disaster was too much to comprehend. He wanted to find his partner. </p>
<p>&ldquo;So I&rsquo;m screaming his name,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m screaming and screaming. Silence.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Streams of snow still flowed downhill as he scooted toward the heart of the slide path. It flowed into a wide gully, maybe 100 feet across, that narrowed as it descended. Castillo turned his beacon to &ldquo;search&rdquo; mode, meaning he would receive signals of those buried, but would not emit signals himself.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float nytmm_photo_stack clearfix no_phone">
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/avalanche_crack.jpg" width="450" height="327" />
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_Path-slide-I9US/AVIE_Path-slide-I9US-custom1.jpg" width="450" height="337" />
</div>
<div class="caption">Left, the avalanche started with a large crack nearly 200 feet across and 3 feet deep that sent millions of pounds of snow down the mountain. (The Stevens Pass Ski Patrol, which investigated the avalanche the next day, drew the fault line on the picture.) Below, the path the avalanche took as it crashed through trees and headed into a gully. <span class="credit">Stevens Pass Ski Patrol</span></div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t want to be in this gully because I don&rsquo;t know what&rsquo;s coming down next,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t want to be the next guy taken out. Now I don&rsquo;t even have a beacon on because I&rsquo;m on search. They&rsquo;re not going to find me if anything happens to me.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Across the gully, unable to see anyone else, either, Peikert and Wangen had gone into search mode, too.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was like, if there&rsquo;s someone in that, the clock&rsquo;s ticking,&rdquo; Peikert said.</p>
<p> Chances of survival drop precipitously every minute. According to a recent study, the survival rate for individuals completely buried in an avalanche falls to about 40 percent after 15 minutes of burial and to 25 percent after 30 minutes. About 75 percent of avalanche victims die from asphyxia or suffocation. The other 25 percent of fatalities result from trauma.  </p>
<p>Castillo spotted Peikert and Wangen across the gully. They, too, were nervous about hangfire, the unstable snow left along the edges of an avalanche&rsquo;s path that can release at any moment. </p>
<p>The avalanche had turned the gully into an oversize bobsled run, with slick, high-banked walls. </p>
<p>&ldquo;This gully&rsquo;s hard-core!&rdquo; Castillo yelled. &ldquo;They&rsquo;re in it!&rdquo;</p>
<p>Wangen stayed mostly on the banks. Peikert and Castillo crossed the gully a couple of times, reluctantly and quickly. </p>
<p>&ldquo;What&rsquo;s your name again?&rdquo; Castillo shouted at Peikert. </p>
<p>It was soon apparent that the victims, however many there were, suffered one of two fates: they were hung up on the banks of the gully, snagged by a tree or buried in snow, or they had been flushed to the bottom, thousands of feet below.</p>
<p>If searchers spent too much time looking along the gully, they might squander a chance at rescuing someone at the bottom. If they rushed downhill, they might pass someone in need of saving. </p>
<p>&ldquo;We started to ski down, hoping to find him in a tree well or hanging on or something,&rdquo; said Castillo, his focus on Brenan. &ldquo;But I started to realize all the trees were bent over, and I started thinking, this is really fricking bad. And then I skied down to a point where I found Johnny&rsquo;s ski, probably three or four feet up in a tree. Stuck.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Castillo called 911. It was 12:02 p.m. The avalanche occurred seven minutes earlier.</p>
<div class="nytmm_audio">
<div class="nytmm_circleplayer" data-mp3="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/audio/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/castillo.mp3"></div>
<div class="caption"><span>Rob Castillo</span> 12:02 P.M.</div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;Hi, I&rsquo;m at Stevens Pass resort, on the backside of Tunnel Creek,&rdquo; Castillo told the King County Sheriff&rsquo;s Department dispatcher. He added, &ldquo;We had a major avalanche, and we might have three or four people missing, at least.&rdquo; </p>
<p>The dispatcher asked him to slow down. Castillo, occasionally shouting at others nearby, tried to explain where the avalanche occurred. He was asked how many people there were.</p>
<p>&ldquo;There&rsquo;s at least 10,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;Between 10 and 12.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The dispatcher asked if anybody was hurt.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We haven&rsquo;t found them,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;I found one ski. It rolled through pretty heavy, man. I had partners right next to me and they&rsquo;re missing. I just found a ski about 1,000 yards down. Or 1,000 feet down.&rdquo; </p>
<p>The call lasted four minutes. Castillo, carrying his friend&rsquo;s ski, turned down the mountain.</p>
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3 class="nytmm_left_margin">&lsquo;This Thing Ripped Big&rsquo;</h3>
<p>Near the top, the five skiers who planned to follow Jim Jack deciphered what happened through a series of increasingly blunt clues. Loose snow. A shaking tree. </p>
<p>Hammond was due to ski next. He took a couple of turns through the fine powder of the meadow and stopped. There was a sudden drop, nearly three feet deep. The fluffy snow was gone. A surface of bluish ice stretched down the hill, into the trees and out of sight.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-rescue/video-avalanche-rescue-custom1-v2.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">Into Search Mode</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001936104" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19226_1_avalanche-rescue_wg_16x9_xl_bb_mm.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-rescue/video-avalanche-rescue-custom1-v2.jpg" data-width="348" data-height="196"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;Once I had gotten to the edge, I was like, oh my gosh, this thing ripped big,&rdquo; Hammond said. &ldquo;I could see the scope of it.&rdquo;</p>
<p><span class="nytmm_video_trigger">He shouted for everyone to go into search mode</span>. The other four skiers moved quickly to see.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We all skied up to it and were like, holy smokes,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;From there all I remember was pulling out my phone. And I called Jim Jack.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Others started dialing numbers, too. They called Chris Rudolph and Elyse Saugstad. There were no answers. Hammond dropped onto the slick slide path. Another clue lay on the ice, pointing downhill.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I hopped out there and made one or two turns, and I saw one of Jim&rsquo;s skis,&rdquo; Hammond said. &ldquo;The only reason I recognized Jim&rsquo;s skis was that it was a pair of skis that he borrowed from me.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The realization that Jack had been carried away was a gut punch.</p>
<p>&ldquo;In one respect, you&rsquo;re like, oh no, a ski &mdash; where&rsquo;s Jim?&rdquo; Abrams said. &ldquo;On the other hand, you think, O.K., there&rsquo;s his ski. Let&rsquo;s find him.&rdquo; </p>
<p>Michelson called 911. According to sheriff&rsquo;s department records, it was 12:03 p.m.</p>
<div class="nytmm_audio">
<div class="nytmm_circleplayer" data-mp3="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/audio/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/michelson.mp3"></div>
<div class="caption"><span>Megan Michelson</span> 12:03 PM</div>
</div>
<p>Her voice was steady and sure. She patiently tried to explain where they were &mdash; &ldquo;The backside of the ski area in the backcountry,&rdquo; she explained. &ldquo;Tunnel Creek.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The dispatcher asked if people were buried.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I believe so, yes,&rdquo; Michelson replied. &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know how many. We have a large group.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Word was relayed to the ski area. Chris Brixey, manager of the Stevens Pass Ski Patrol, had 17 patrollers working on the mountain that day, two more in the aid room, and a dispatcher. Brixey is a regular at Johnny Brenan&rsquo;s Monday night poker parties. He did not know that a group of friends, including Rudolph, his Stevens Pass co-worker, had gone to Tunnel Creek.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I happened to be walking through the aid room,&rdquo; Brixey said. &ldquo;Our dispatcher handed me a note that said 10 people are buried in Tunnel Creek. I called the 911 operator and got Megan&rsquo;s information. I called Megan directly. She said there&rsquo;s about 12 people and they were looking for eight people. I didn&rsquo;t know Megan. My gut feeling was that this was a group of inexperienced people who are now dealing with tragedy.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Brixey called the area&rsquo;s most seasoned patroller and put him in charge of the four-member first-response unit, called the hasty team, to follow the group&rsquo;s trail. He also enlisted other patrollers and a pair of avalanche rescue dogs.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_ad">
<div class="inner_ad">
<h3>Advertisement</h3>
<iframe class="nytmm-enterprise-ads-bigad" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" border="0" src=""></iframe>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article last">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>Word of a large avalanche in Tunnel Creek soon echoed around Stevens Pass, from the patrol room to the R.V. lot, up the lifts and down the slopes. According to the Stevens Pass Ski Patrol log, the area closed public access to the boundary gate atop the Seventh Heaven lift at 12:19. </p>
<p>By then, the group that had started off together less than 30 minutes earlier was strewn up and down nearly 3,000 vertical feet. No one knew how many were missing.</p>
<p>Keith Carlsen was nearest the top, searching for Jack.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I thought someone has to make sure he&rsquo;s not still up here,&rdquo; Carlsen said. &ldquo;It wasn&rsquo;t likely, but his ski was there, and he got swept, and there&rsquo;s no sign of him, so maybe he got pummeled into the snow, into a hole, somewhere, right away.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The others headed down, scanning the path and its edges with their beacons. Carlsen methodically checked the upper meadow.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I thought I was going to be the one to find him, and I would find him alone,&rdquo; Carlsen said. &ldquo;And the bed surface at the top was rock hard. And I&rsquo;m thinking: I&rsquo;m going to get a signal, and this guy&rsquo;s going to be buried, and I&rsquo;m going to have to somehow dig him out. I&rsquo;m going to find Jim Jack.&rdquo; </p>
<p>Scared and alone, Carlsen&rsquo;s voice broke the silence.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float nytmm_photo_stack clearfix no_phone">
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_Path-slide-OYEX/AVIE_Path-slide-OYEX-custom1.jpg" width="450" height="527" />
</div>
<div class="caption">Photographs from the Stevens Pass Ski Patrol accident report, taken a day after the Tunnel Creek avalanche, showed its twisting path. After starting in a broad meadow, the avalanche funneled into a narrow ravine. <span class="credit">Stevens Pass Ski Patrol</span></div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m saying, and I remember repeating this in my head: &lsquo;Jim, am I about to find you? Jim, are you underneath me? Jim, where the hell are you? Is this possible? Is he really underneath here? Am I about to dig Jim out?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>Farther down, others followed the path into the gully. As it descends toward the valley floor, it carves deeper into the mountain. In some spots, canyon walls are 20 feet high. There were steep, icy drops that would become gushing waterfalls during the spring runoff.</p>
<p>&ldquo;There are places it&rsquo;s so tight that I would stop and my skis would straddle the middle,&rdquo; Hammond said. &ldquo;And I&rsquo;d be elevated, like being on springs.&rdquo;</p>
<p>It was still clogged with rocks and trees that had not been fully scoured away. Where the ravine bent, the avalanche rode high on the outside wall, like a child on a water slide, sometimes breaking over the top of the bank and unearthing trees on the ridges. </p>
<p>&ldquo;It was fear,&rdquo; Abrams said. &ldquo;Fear that you lost someone, and fear that you&rsquo;re standing in an avalanche path. You&rsquo;re thinking, Don&rsquo;t get caught up on trees, listen for the beacons, where&rsquo;s my fianc&eacute;e?&rdquo;</p>
<p>It became increasingly evident that whoever was caught in the avalanche would be found at the bottom.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I probably went down for one or two minutes and I got no signal,&rdquo; Michelson said. &ldquo;I shouted: &lsquo;They&rsquo;ve gone all the way down! The way this gully is, they&rsquo;ve been flushed.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article//-->
</div>
<!--end superpart //-->
<!--section 5 //-->
<div class="nytmm_section" name="discovery" data-label="Discovery">
<div class="nytmm_article video_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_staticimage nytmm_ie_static" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter5_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter5_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter5.jpg" data-loop="true"></div>
<div class="nytmm_chapter_head light" id="nytmm_head_4">
<div class="nytmm_inner_head">
<span>Part Five</span>
<h2>Discovery</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article top">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p><span class="dropcap">T</span>im Carlson and Ron Pankey, having split from the big group at the top, nervously negotiated the roundabout route to the bottom of Tunnel Creek. They could not catch up to Tim Wesley, but followed his snowboard track to the valley floor. It was 12:07 p.m. </p>
<p>They glided past the foot of a mound of chunky debris. One of the ravines had spewed a sizable avalanche, but there was no way to know it had occurred in the past few minutes. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I looked up and I saw a ski pole sticking up,&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;It looked like someone stuck it in there. It was sticking up right at the very end of the pile. Handle up.&rdquo;</p>
<p>He shouted to Pankey.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was like, &lsquo;Dude, you need to turn your transceiver on,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;<span class="nytmm_single_quote left">&lsquo;</span>There&rsquo;s people in here.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-skipole/video-avalanche-skipole-custom1.jpg" width="640" height="360" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">&lsquo;Is that a ski pole?&rsquo;</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001936110" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19228_1_avalanche-skipole_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-skipole/video-avalanche-skipole-custom1.jpg" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-touch-width="500" data-touch-height="281"></div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Just after the avalanche, Ron Pankey and Tim Carlson discover the debris pile.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Carlson clicked out of his snowboard bindings and climbed onto the pile. Pankey turned his beacon to search mode. It beeped immediately.</p>
<p>His skis off, Pankey climbed onto the debris pile, too. <span class="nytmm_video_trigger">He saw the ski pole and two gloves</span>. He was sucker-punched by dread. </p>
<p>&ldquo;You figure someone who is fighting is going to have his gloves on,&rdquo; Pankey said. &ldquo;If they&rsquo;re limp, yeah, their gloves are going to come off.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Then he noticed the brand.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That was my thought &mdash; Oh, God, those are Scott gloves. Jim Jack was wearing Scott gloves,&rdquo; Pankey said.</p>
<p>Their beacons shrieked.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I probably searched for maybe a minute before I was on top of a signal,&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;Your signal goes &lsquo;beepbeepbeepbeepbeep<span id="nytmm_beep" style="display:none"> - </span>BEEPBEEPBEEPBEEPBEEP,&rsquo; and it gets a little fainter, like oh, over here. I got a strong signal, traversed over, got a weak signal, went back, got a strong signal, went back and I was basically on top of a body. </p>
<p>&ldquo;And, uh, the first shovel I dug in, I hit Jim Jack&rsquo;s arm.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The two men dug frantically.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I saw Jim Jack&rsquo;s face,&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;Eyes open, just staring at me. We could see he wasn&rsquo;t breathing. Ron started giving him breaths and I was searching for his body, underneath his chest. I was like, &lsquo;What the hell is going on?&rsquo; There was no body where you&rsquo;d expect a body to be. And then I started digging around, and I could see he was folded up into this ball. His feet were above his head.&rdquo;</p>
<p>His body had been pummeled.</p>
<p>&ldquo;There was no blood, but he didn&rsquo;t have his helmet on, he didn&rsquo;t have his backpack on, his jacket was pulled over his head,&rdquo; Carlson said. &ldquo;He had some scrapes on his belly. And just pulling him out of the snow you could feel it and see it. Giving him a couple of breaths, it just came out so quick. And you push on his chest and it would just collapse. There was nothing there. And Jim Jack &mdash; we&rsquo;re all strong dudes, and there was just nothing left.&rdquo;</p>
<p>&ldquo;I pulled his arm upright, and it was just really soft,&rdquo; Carlson added. &ldquo;It was like pulling a wet towel. Pulled the other arm and it was the same feeling. And I pulled his legs out, and there was nothing connected to anything. It was completely crushed.&rdquo;</p>
<p>They turned off Jack&rsquo;s beacon and tried to lay him peacefully in the snow. Pankey pushed his eyelids closed.</p>
<div class="nytmm_audio">
<div class="nytmm_circleplayer" data-mp3="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/audio/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/pankey.mp3"></div>
<div class="caption"><span>Ron Pankey</span> 12:31 PM</div>
</div>
<p>He called 911 at 12:31 p.m. and told the dispatcher that he had &ldquo;recovered a body.&rdquo;</p><p>She asked him for his name.</p><p>&ldquo;Jim Jack,&rdquo; Pankey replied.</p>
<p>Jack&rsquo;s phone chirped. It had survived the avalanche, and Pankey reached into Jack&rsquo;s pocket and pulled it out. It was a text message from Jack&rsquo;s girlfriend, Tiffany Abraham. Rumors of a big avalanche in Tunnel Creek had reached the base area of Stevens Pass.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Where are you?&rdquo; it read. &ldquo;You OK?&rdquo;</p>
<p>Pankey looked over at the ski pole sticking straight out of the snow. It looked familiar. Pankey had noticed it on the hike up the ridge to Cowboy Mountain.</p>
<p>&ldquo;That&rsquo;s the guy&rsquo;s in front of me,&rdquo; Pankey said. &ldquo;He was hiking in front of me and Jim Jack was behind me, and he had these old Smith, corrective angle, curved poles. So I&rsquo;m like, &lsquo;That&rsquo;s Johnny&rsquo;s pole.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<h3 class="nytmm_left_margin">&lsquo;It Was Just a Bad Dream&rsquo;</h3>
<p>At the upper end of the meadow, more than 100 yards away and out of sight, Elyse Saugstad waited in the silence, unable to move.</p>
<p>She did not know how long she had been frozen there &mdash; head pointed downhill, hands sticking out of the snow, face poking through the ice just enough to breathe and see the breaking clouds trailing the weekend&rsquo;s storm.</p>
<p>Her hip ached. Her mind wandered. She wondered who else was caught in the avalanche. She wondered who was left to rescue them.</p>
<p>She felt herself getting colder. Her pink mittens, like those of a child&rsquo;s, had strings that attached them to her jacket. When she had come to a stop, one of the mittens was on her hand. The other was off, hanging from her wrist.</p>
<p>Saugstad could not claw the hard-packed snow with her mittens on. She took them off and picked at the ice until her fingers ached. She put her mittens on again until they warmed up. </p>
<p>She had not spoken since the avalanche stopped. It had not occurred to her to cry for help. Someone would come. She hoped. </p>
<p>Finally, for the first time, she shouted.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Help!&rdquo; she screamed.</p>
<p>The face of Wenzel Peikert startled her.</p>
<p>Among those who skied down the gully, Peikert arrived first to the avalanche&rsquo;s final resting place. The walls of the ravine slowly fell away and opened onto a wide, sloping meadow. It was covered by an enormous pile of chunky ice cubes, some fit for a cocktail glass, others the size of couches. The debris was filled with dirt, rocks and shredded tree parts.</p>
<p>It stretched about 150 yards down what remained of the slope. It was 10 or 20 feet tall, obstructing Peikert&rsquo;s view to the bottom. Peikert&rsquo;s beacon began its frantic chirping.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I started getting a signal,&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;I marked it with one of my poles. That&rsquo;s what they teach, to mark where you start picking up a signal and keep working to where it gets stronger. I took my skis off because it was so hard to ski on that stuff. And as I got close to that signal, I saw two pink gloves sticking out.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Saugstad was about 20 feet downhill. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Her feet were into the snow and her head was downhill, but I saw two pink gloves and her face,&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know if she uncovered her face or not, but it was just barely sticking out of the snow. And a little bit of orange from her backpack. I started digging her out, trying not to hurt her. I said, &lsquo;Are you O.K.?&rsquo; And she said: &lsquo;I think so. My leg&rsquo;s kind of hurt.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>Peikert pulled his shovel from his backpack and started to dig.</p>
<p>&ldquo;For a pause, really quickly, I thought to myself: she&rsquo;s alive, she&rsquo;s breathing, her face is out of the snow,&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;I thought, let&rsquo;s go find others. But then I realized that more snow could come down. I found someone alive, and I needed to get her out of here.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Saugstad sensed his urgency. </p>
<p>&ldquo;When he started unburying me, he flung his shovel and it went flying down the hill so far that he couldn&rsquo;t stop and go get it,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;And so then he had to start digging me out with his hands.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Peikert hurried, knowing that others were likely buried nearby.</p>
<p>&ldquo;She was actually really hard to get out,&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;One of her skis had stayed on, so it had kind of locked her into the snow. Even a ski boot gets locked in. I dug to get her ski off. It probably took five minutes of digging to get her out.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Finally, Michelson and Abrams arrived from above. They found Peikert and Saugstad on their feet.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It didn&rsquo;t dawn on me that she had been buried,&rdquo; Michelson said. &ldquo;I was relieved she was alive.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Over several minutes, others trickled down from above. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Once we got to the bottom, when we got through the ravine and got to the mouth, I just remember saying, &lsquo;Oh, my God,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;Snow chunks the size of boulders. That&rsquo;s when I realized the magnitude of everything. It looked like a war zone. It was chaos.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Michelson took charge as an impromptu site commander. No one was sure who was missing or how many victims there might be. Michelson used her beacon and pinpointed two spots for others to search, then continued sweeping the meadow to search for more.</p>
<p>&ldquo;My numbers and directions were bouncing all over the place,&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;But Megan comes up and hers was right on it. Mine is a little bit older, but I don&rsquo;t know why it was bouncing around. I started probing, and I hit a spot where there obviously was something other than snow.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Peikert and Rob Castillo dug through the ice. It had been more than 30 minutes since the avalanche.</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster" id="finding_video">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-recovery/video-avalanche-recovery-custom1.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">Finding Their Friends</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001936395" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19229_1_avalanche-recovery_wg_16x9_xl_bb_mm.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/multimedia/video-avalanche-recovery/video-avalanche-recovery-custom1.jpg" data-width="348" data-height="196"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><span class="nytmm_video_trigger">Johnny Brenan was discovered about three feet below the surface</span>. He had been buried a few feet from Saugstad all along.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I found his back first,&rdquo; Peikert said. &ldquo;His head was really bent under. I tried to dig a hole through his armpit, to his head, thinking I might be able to get his face turned to give him C.P.R. There was blood. His chin was split open. His helmet was pushed back onto the back of his head and was filled with snow. One leg was off in a weird position, like he had a broken femur or hip or something. I finally got him out. He was cold. Blue.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Castillo, Brenan&rsquo;s longtime friend and ski partner, worked side by side with Peikert, at last getting his legs out.</p>
<p>&ldquo;The muscles were just beat,&rdquo; Castillo said.</p>
<p>About 20 feet up the hill, Abrams, Wangen and Stifter zeroed in on a victim, too. It was the spot that Peikert had marked with his pole before he spotted Saugstad.</p>
<p>&ldquo;We were still searching for the lowest signal,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;And the lowest signal I got on the transceiver was 2.4, and it took me, like, half a second to realize, oh, that&rsquo;s six feet down because it&rsquo;s in meters. So I&rsquo;m like, all right, this is our lowest reading. And I think on our third probe we struck something. I told Dan and Tim, &lsquo;All right, get the shovels out,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span> and we started digging.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Digging was nothing like scooping snow from a driveway. It was more like shoveling the chunky piles that snowplows leave along the side of a cleared highway, full of large pieces seemingly glued together.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article last">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p>&ldquo;They&rsquo;re big mounds of snow and they&rsquo;re like concrete,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;So you dig and dig, and then that person would rotate to the back and take a break and the guy who was second would start clearing snow out for the guy who is digging.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Quickly exhausted, they rotated frequently.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It was just a bad dream,&rdquo; Abrams said. &ldquo;I was standing there holding my shovel that I never intended to use, except maybe to get my car out.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Finally, they reached a victim: Chris Rudolph.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He was lying facedown, so it was hard to get to his face,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;And it was hard because we couldn&rsquo;t move him because he was just encased in there. His feet were buried really deeply. Finally I was able to get to his face. His face was blue. And so finally I was like: &lsquo;We&rsquo;ve got to get his feet out! We&rsquo;ve got to get his feet out!&rsquo; That took another good couple of minutes to get his feet free. Then we gently pulled him out by his backpack.&rdquo;</p>
<p><span class="nytmm_video_trigger graphic" data-trigger="bodies_graphic">Stifter performed C.P.R. on Rudolph: 2 breaths, 30 compressions, to the point of exhaustion</span>. </p>
<p>Saugstad called 911. It was 12:40 p.m.</p>
<div class="nytmm_audio">
<div class="nytmm_circleplayer" data-mp3="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/audio/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/elyse.mp3"></div>
<div class="caption"><span>Elyse Saugstad</span> 12:40 PM</div>
</div>
<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m reporting an avalanche,&rdquo; she said, breathlessly. </p>
<p>Frantic voices behind her shouted encouragement.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Come on! You can do it! Come on, buddy! Take a breath!&rdquo; </p>
<p>The dispatcher said there were &ldquo;units on scene.&rdquo; Saugstad said they had not arrived and asked if they were coming by helicopter.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Uh, we do not have a helicopter yet in the area because of the avalanche risk,&rdquo; the dispatcher said.</p>
<p>Hammond was the last to arrive from above and took over trying to revive Rudolph.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I definitely believed that there was a chance,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;My hope dissipated certainly after Joel got there and I was sitting there. We knew. We looked at each other.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Twenty feet downhill, the huddle around Brenan slowly came to the same conclusion. Peikert had been performing C.P.R. for close to 30 minutes, with Castillo&rsquo;s help.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I was hoping for a miracle then,&rdquo; Castillo said. &ldquo;But I really kind of understood that he was probably dead.&rdquo;</p>
<p>An hour&rsquo;s worth of adrenaline dissolved to disheartened shock. A few other skiers had happened upon the scene, but no rescue help had arrived. </p>
<p>Saugstad walked around dazed, wearing her deflated air bag &ldquo;like dead angel wings,&rdquo; Carlsen said. Castillo made his way to the bottom of the hill to learn that Jim Jack was dead, too. Erin Dessert, the snowboarder who had veered away from the group at the top, frightened by the direction everyone was headed, had cautiously made her way down and rediscovered the group. She cradled Rudolph&rsquo;s head as others tried their last attempts to resuscitate him.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s Chris Rudolph,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;You know? He&rsquo;s the knight in shining armor of Stevens Pass.&rdquo;</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_triggered_video nytmm_touch_triggered_video nytmm_tofixie" id="bodies_graphic" data-trigger="bodies-graphic" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/debris_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/debris_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/debris.jpg" data-width="348" data-height="550" data-touch-width="300" data-touch-height="474" data-loop="false"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article//-->
</div>
<!--end superpart //-->
<!--section 6 //-->
<div class="nytmm_section" name="word-spreads" data-label="Word Spreads">
<div class="nytmm_article video_cover">
<div class="nytmm_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_video nytmm_touch_fs_staticimage nytmm_ie_static" data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter6_final.mp4" data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter6_final.webm" data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/chapter6.jpg" data-loop="true"></div>
<div class="nytmm_chapter_head light" id="nytmm_head_5">
<div class="nytmm_inner_head">
<span>Part Six</span>
<h2>Word Spreads</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article top">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<p><span class="dropcap">L</span>aurie Brenan and Tiffany Abraham, Jack&rsquo;s girlfriend, were both in the Bull&rsquo;s Tooth Pub and Eatery, on the second level of the Granite Peaks Lodge.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I saw Tiffany sitting at the bar, and I sat a few seats away,&rdquo; Brenan said. &ldquo;She says, &lsquo;I haven&rsquo;t seen Jim yet.&rsquo; And I said, &lsquo;Oh, he and Johnny did Tunnel Creek.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<p>The man next to Abraham, a neighbor from Leavenworth, overheard. There was an avalanche in Tunnel Creek, he said. Someone came into the restaurant a while ago and asked for volunteers to help search. </p>
<p>Abraham&rsquo;s heart sank. Normally a font of buoyant optimism, she had a sudden pang of dread. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I downed my cocktail because I knew I&rsquo;d need it,&rdquo; Abraham said. &ldquo;The bartender was telling a story, and I was trying to be polite and listen, but I knew I had to get out of there. I got my lunch boxed up and walked down to the ski patrol office. I took the elevator, and it was the slowest elevator in the world.&rdquo;</p>
<p>She could tell immediately that bad news was waiting. She spotted a friend who was on his way to the scene.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He grabs my hand and I screamed at him,&rdquo; Abraham said. &ldquo;<span class="nytmm_single_quote left">&lsquo;</span>What the hell is going on?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float nytmm_photo_stack clearfix no_phone">
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<div class="nytmm_slideshow_poster nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="hessburg">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_AHessburg-slide-LFXC/AVIE_AHessburg-slide-LFXC-custom2.jpg" width="450" height="300" />
<div class="nytmm_play"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Anne Hessburg at the house she shared with Chris Rudolph in Leavenworth, Wash. <span class="credit">Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<div class="nytmm_slideshow_poster nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="abraham">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_TAbraham-slide-P9RR/AVIE_TAbraham-slide-P9RR-custom2.jpg" width="450" height="300" />
<div class="nytmm_play"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Tiffany Abraham at the house she shared with Jim Jack in Leavenworth, Wash. Jack&rsquo;s camper is in the background. <span class="credit">Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></div>
<div class="nytmm_photo">
<div class="nytmm_slideshow_poster nytmm_lightboxer" data-tag="lbrenan">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_LBrenan-slide-A31H/AVIE_LBrenan-slide-A31H-custom2.jpg" width="450" height="300" />
<div class="nytmm_play"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="caption">Laurie Brenan at home in Peshastin, Wash., with Huckleberry, left, and Pablo. <span class="credit">Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></div>
</div>
<p>They went into the ski patrol room, on the ground level on the backside of the lodge. Inside is a first-aid room with beds for injured skiers. Beyond is a ski patrol break room, a couch against one wall.</p>
<p>Anne Hessburg, Rudolph&rsquo;s girlfriend, was sitting there, balled up in tears. She had skied all morning with a friend and taken an early lunch at the Iron Goat pizzeria. She walked up to the slope-side cabin that Rudolph had provided to the journalists from Powder magazine. Hessburg stored skis there. A friend received a call while she was there.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Someone told him there was an avalanche in Tunnel Creek,&rdquo; Hessburg said. &ldquo;He told me, and my stomach immediately dropped.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Hessburg rushed to the ski patrol room. She could tell by the way people were moving that it was something serious. She could hear the squawks on the walkie-talkies. Someone told her only that Rudolph was probably involved, as if to break the emotional fall.</p>
<p>Brixey, the ski patrol manager, confirmed it. Rudolph was dead. That was about when Abraham walked into the patrol room with her friend, noticing a broken Hessburg on the couch. </p>
<p>Abraham&rsquo;s friend turned to her, looked her in the eyes, and told her about Jack.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Baby girl, he&rsquo;s gone,&rdquo; he said.</p>
<p>&ldquo;I just lost my breath,&rdquo; Abraham said. &ldquo;I lost it. I couldn&rsquo;t even be in my skin.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Laurie Brenan had no premonition. She watched Abraham rush out of the restaurant at the news of an avalanche and casually followed a few minutes behind. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I thought everything was fine,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;But I&rsquo;m going over to ski patrol. I felt like Johnny was probably using his skills, digging somebody out.&rdquo;</p>
<p>She tried to stay out of the way as people hurried in and out of the patrol room. </p>
<p>&ldquo;Then I heard someone say something about Jim Jack, and I thought, oh my God, how can that be?&rdquo; Brenan said. &ldquo;I knew they were all in the same group. I start calling to see if I can get someone to get my kids safe, back to the R.V., and get them a snack and put on a movie or something.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Brenan spotted Brixey, the patrol manager and Monday night poker player, and waited for an opening to approach. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I said, &lsquo;So, Chris, there&rsquo;s been an avalanche in Tunnel Creek?<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Brenan said. &ldquo;And he said yes. Anyone hurt? He said yes. Is anyone dead? He said yes. And I said, &lsquo;Do I know these people?&rsquo; And he said yes. I said, &lsquo;Where&rsquo;s Johnny?&rsquo; And he said, &lsquo;I haven&rsquo;t heard.<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_audio">
<div class="nytmm_circleplayer" data-mp3="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/audio/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/skipatrol.mp3"></div>
<div class="caption"><span>Dispatcher to Ski Patrol</span> 1:01 PM</div>
</div>
<p>It was true. One 911 call from Tunnel Creek had reported the death of Jack. Another had reported the death of Rudolph. A third made mention of a third fatality, but the dispatcher never asked the name. Brixey did not learn about Brenan until his own patrol members reached the scene. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I went outside, totally shaking,&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;I kept dropping my water bottle, again and again, because I was shaking so much. Then Chris Brixey comes and gets me.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Brixey&rsquo;s outward calm belied the turmoil inside. As a paramedic, he had told a lot of strangers that a loved one had died. But never a close friend. </p>
<p>&ldquo;That was, by far, the biggest challenge for me, walking Laurie from outside back to my office,&rdquo; Brixey said. &ldquo;Not knowing what I was going to say, but knowing what I had to say.&rdquo;</p>
<p>They walked past the empty beds, past Hessburg on the couch, past Abraham. In the office, he turned to her.</p>
<p>&ldquo;He said Johnny was one of the people buried,&rdquo; Brenan said. &ldquo;<span class="nytmm_single_quote left">&lsquo;</span>He didn&rsquo;t make it.&rsquo; I didn&rsquo;t want to believe it. I said, &lsquo;Have you seen him?&rsquo; He said no. I said: &lsquo;Then you don&rsquo;t know. It&rsquo;s possible he&rsquo;s not there. You go back and get more information because that is wrong. Go. Go find him. You&rsquo;re wrong.&rsquo; I remember thinking: He&rsquo;s got two kids. This was for fun. Johnny doesn&rsquo;t leave his responsibilities. Ever.&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float small_video_section">
<div class="nytmm_media_section">
<div class="nytmm_video_player">
<div class="nytmm_video_poster" id="hardest_video">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/video-avalanche-laurie/video-avalanche-laurie-custom1.jpg" width="348" height="196" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay_title">The Hardest Thing</div>
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_proto_videoplayer" data-media="100000001956070" data-touch-media="http://video1.nytimes.com/video/2012/12/17/19390_1_avalanche-laurie_wg_16x9_xl_bb_art.mp4" data-touch-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/video-avalanche-laurie/video-avalanche-laurie-custom1.jpg" data-width="348" data-height="196"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Brixey left. Brenan melted into shock. Finally, a friend from Leavenworth came in. He had gone to Tunnel Creek about 20 minutes behind the large group and happened upon the scene. </p>
<p><span class="nytmm_video_trigger">&ldquo;He said, &lsquo;I can tell you it was him</span>,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Laurie Brenan said. &ldquo;<span class="nytmm_single_quote left">&lsquo;</span>I gave him C.P.R. We tried.&rsquo;</p>
<p>&ldquo;It really felt like I had died then,&rdquo; Brenan said. &ldquo;And that I was reborn into a nightmare.&rdquo;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_article">
<div class="inner_article clearfix">
<div class="left">
<!--SUB CHAPTER //-->
<h3>A Grim Vigil</h3>
<p>Back on the other side of Cowboy Mountain, and down a meadow that had been turned inside out, weary huddles surrounded three dead men. </p>
<p>Hope had surrendered. Rescues became grim vigils. The survivors did not know what to do other than wait. The bodies and faces of the victims were covered in jackets because it seemed the respectful thing to do. Survivors introduced themselves to those they had not met.</p>
<p>A group of 16 skiers and snowboarders, all of them experts, all of them unable to refuse the temptation of an hourlong excursion into steep powder, had been reduced by three lives. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m so done with it,&rdquo; Stifter thought to himself. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m so done with skiing.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The first ski patrollers, along with an avalanche dog named Cava, arrived at 1:05 p.m., 70 minutes after the mountain gave way. They had started at the top and combed the entire path, following the funnel from the wide upper meadow through the flumelike ravine, searching for victims along the way. By the time they spit out of the mouth at the bottom, there was no rescue to be done. </p>
<p>The patrollers recognized faces in the huddles. They realized then that they had been searching for friends, not strangers. They stopped to find Rudolph and Brenan. Another patroller headed farther down to learn about Jack. </p>
<p>More patrollers began to arrive from below, on snowmobiles brought from the highway. A scene of quiet contemplation buzzed with activity and a second wave of despair.</p>
<p>&ldquo;It just became this sea, getting merged into everybody else&rsquo;s shock,&rdquo; Dessert said. &ldquo;When it was just us out there working on them, it seemed beautiful and spiritual, almost like an Indian burial ground.&rdquo;</p>
<div class="nytmm_inline float no_phone">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/12/17/sports/AVIE_Debris-slide-GX8I/AVIE_Debris-slide-GX8I-custom1-v3.jpg" width="640" height="360" />
<div class="caption">Rescuers left their gear downhill as they prepared to take victims from the debris field to an awaiting Sno-Cat. The bodies were then transported about a half-mile to the highway. <span class="credit">Washington State Department of Transportation</span></div>
</div>
<p>The patrollers tried to revive the victims. It was useless.</p>
<p>A medical examiner determined that Jack&rsquo;s cause of death was &ldquo;subdural and subarachnoid hemorrhage&rdquo; &mdash; brain trauma. She also diagnosed a partially torn aorta; a broken neck, vertebrae, sternum and ribs; and lacerations of the liver, spleen and pancreas. She described &ldquo;blunt force injury of the head, neck, torso and extremities.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Rudolph, with a &ldquo;blunt force injury of the torso,&rdquo; sustained &ldquo;rib fractures with right hemothorax and probably compressional asphyxia.&rdquo; Brenan had &ldquo;blunt force injury and compression of the trunk,&rdquo; with &ldquo;multiple rib and vertebral fractures with probable compressional asphyxia.&rdquo;</p>
<p>They were probably dead by the time the avalanche stopped, or shortly after. </p>
<p>Brixey, working by radio over the mountain at Stevens Pass, told all rescue units to stand down. A second surge of patrollers would assist in taking the bodies off the mountain. </p>
<p>The survivors were encouraged to make their way to the highway, where ambulances awaited. Saugstad, missing a ski, used the one of Jack&rsquo;s that had been found. Hammond had been carrying it on his back. </p>
<p>Stifter and Carlsen sat on the meadow, unable to pull themselves away.</p>
<p>&ldquo;Everybody kind of skied down,&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;It seemed weird to me to leave the bodies.&rdquo;</p>
<p>As with other survivors, the quarrel with their own guilt began immediately, the first sign that avalanches swallow more lives than just the ones buried beneath the snow. </p>
<p>They wondered if their mere presence at Stevens Pass that weekend gave rise to the Tunnel Creek trip, a group of proud locals eager to show off for influential out-of-towners. They wondered why they recognized all of the danger signs, starting with the avalanche report that morning over coffee, but did not do enough to slow or stop the expedition. They wondered if they could have saved lives after the avalanche by speeding to the bottom rather than combing the path. </p>
<p>They wondered how so many smart, experienced people could make the types of decisions that turned complex, rich, enviable lives into a growing stack of statistics.</p>
<p>Activity disturbed the quiet again. A Sno-Cat, a large machine with treads to climb through snow-covered terrain, rumbled through the trees below and parked at the bottom of the debris pile. Ski patrollers solemnly marched up the hill, carrying gear to wrap the bodies. </p>
<p>It was one deadly avalanche accident among many, perhaps no more worthy of attention than any other. It was not the nation&rsquo;s deadliest avalanche of the season. And it was not at all like the one that killed 96 people near Tunnel Creek more than a century ago.</p>
<p>But some rituals do not change. The accidents end with an unrefined ceremony.</p>
<p>Some patrollers stopped at Jack and wrapped him in a crude bundle using red blankets and rope. Others hiked to where Stifter and Carlsen sat. They wrapped the bodies of Brenan and Rudolph, with quiet expediency and reverence. </p>
<p>&ldquo;I remember they said, &lsquo;There&rsquo;s no easy way to do this,<span class="nytmm_single_quote">&rsquo;</span>&rdquo; Stifter said. &ldquo;And they started slowly dragging them down the hill.&rdquo;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!--end article//-->
<div class="nytmm_article nytmm_bottom_promo">
<div class="inner_article">
<div class="nytmm_fullvideo_promo clearfix">
<div class="nytmm_fullvideo_text">
<span>Watch the Documentary</span>
<h3><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2012/snow-fall/video/" id="g-docvidlink">Avalanche at Tunnel Creek</a></h3>
<p>The story in the words of the survivors.</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_fullvideo_poster">
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2012/snow-fall/video/">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/documentary_poster.jpg" />
<div class="nytmm_overlay"></div>
</a>
</div>
</div>
<div class="left">
<div class="nytmm_credit_section"><p>Graphics and design by <span>Hannah Fairfield</span>, <span>Xaqu&iacute;n G.V.</span>, <span>Jon Huang</span>, <span>Wayne Kamidoi</span>, <span>Sam Manchester</span>, <span>Alan McLean</span>, <span>Jacky Myint</span>, <span>Graham Roberts</span>, <span>Joe Ward</span>, <span>Jeremy White</span> and <span>Josh Williams</span>. Photography by <span>Ruth Fremson</span>. Video by <span>Catherine Spangler</span>.</p>
<p>Additional video by <span>Eric Miller</span> and <span>Shane Wilder</span>.</p>
<p><span>Kristen Millares Young</span> contributed research.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="left">
<p>The reporting for this article on the Feb. 19 avalanche at Tunnel Creek was done over six months. It involved interviews with every survivor, the families of the deceased, first responders at Tunnel Creek, officials at Stevens Pass and snow-science experts. It also included the examination of reports by the police, the medical examiner and the Stevens Pass Ski Patrol, as well as 40 calls to 911 made in the aftermath of the avalanche. The Swiss Federal Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research provided a computer-generated simulation of the avalanche, based on data accumulated from the Stevens Pass accident report and witness accounts. Additional sources are: LIDAR data from King County GIS Center; Iowa Environmental Mesonet, Iowa State University; Mark Moore, U.S. Forest Service; National Avalanche Center.</p>
</div>
<div class="right">
<div class="nytmm_ebook">
<a href="http://byliner.com/originals/snow-fall" target="_blank"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/AvalancheDeploy/ebook.jpg" /></a>
<p>A version of this article, which includes an epilogue, is available as an e-book. Purchase at <a href="http://byliner.com/originals/snow-fall" target="_blank">byliner.com</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<article id="story" class="story theme-main">

        
    <header id="story-header" class="story-header">
        
                <div id="story-meta" class="story-meta ">
                            <div class="ad sponsortile-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
                    <div class="caption">Supported by</div>
                    <div id="sponsortile" class="ad sponsortile-ad-creative"></div>
                </div>
                                        <h3 class="kicker">
                        <span class="kicker-label"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/opinion/index.html">The Opinion Pages</a></span>                            <span class="pipe">|</span>                        Op-Ed Columnist                </h3>
                        	<h1 itemprop="headline" id="story-heading" class="story-heading">Don’t Harsh Our Mellow, Dude</h1>
                        <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">
                                    <div class="simple-extended-byline">
    <div class="simple-thumb">
        <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/opinion/editorialsandoped/oped/columnists/maureendowd/index.html">            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/11/01/opinion/dowd-circular/dowd-circular-thumbLarge-v4.png" title="Maureen Dowd" />
        </a>    </div>
        <p class="simple-byline-column has-single-author">
                    <a class="simple-byline-column-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/column/maureen-dowd">Maureen Dowd</a>
                <span class='simple-byline-date'>JUNE 3, 2014</span>
    </p>
</div>

                                <p class="byline-dateline">
<time class="dateline" datetime="2014-06-03" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-06-03">JUNE 3, 2014</time>
</p>

                                                    <div class="inside-story">
                        <span class="menu-label">Inside</span>
                        <ul class="inside-story-menu"></ul>
                    </div>

</button>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->
        </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </header>

    <div id="story-body" class="story-body">

        
        
        <div class="lede-container">
                        <div class="lede-container-ads">
                                                    <div id="lede-ad" class="ad lede-ad marginalia-anchor-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>

</div>

            <div class="extended-byline">
    <div class="thumb">
        <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/opinion/editorialsandoped/oped/columnists/maureendowd/index.html">            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/11/01/opinion/dowd-circular/dowd-circular-thumbLarge-v4.png" title="Maureen Dowd" />
        </a>    </div>
    <p class="byline">
        <span itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/opinion/editorialsandoped/oped/columnists/maureendowd/index.html">
            <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/opinion/editorialsandoped/oped/columnists/maureendowd/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by MAUREEN DOWD">                <span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="Maureen Dowd" itemprop="name">Maureen Dowd</span>
            </a>        </span>
    </p>
            <div class="follow-button-placeholder" data-collection-id="column.maureen-dowd"></div>
    </div>

                                        <div id="sharetools-story" aria-label="tools" role="group" class="sharetools theme-classic  sharetools-story  "
data-shares="email,facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet,save,show-all|more,ad"
data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/04/opinion/dowd-dont-harsh-our-mellow-dude.html"
data-title="Don’t Harsh Our Mellow, Dude"
data-author="By MAUREEN DOWD"
data-media=""
data-description="Colorado is finding out that it&#8217;s not so easy to unleash pot on hordes of tourists seeking a mellow buzz."
	data-publish-date="June 3, 2014"
>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
<span class="sharetools-label visually-hidden">Share This Page</span>
<div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
<div id="MiddleLeft" class="ad middle-left-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
</div><!-- close shareTools -->
                    </div>


                
        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="105" data-total-count="105" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1">The caramel-chocolate flavored candy bar looked so innocent, like the Sky Bars I used to love as a child.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="295" data-total-count="400" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">Sitting in my hotel room in Denver, I nibbled off the end and then, when nothing happened, nibbled some more. I figured if I was reporting on the social revolution rocking Colorado in January, the giddy culmination of pot Prohibition, I should try a taste of legal, edible pot from a local shop.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="39" data-total-count="439" itemprop="articleBody">What could go wrong with a bite or two?</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="29" data-total-count="468" itemprop="articleBody">Everything, as it turned out.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="178" data-total-count="646" itemprop="articleBody">Not at first. For an hour, I felt nothing. I figured I’d order dinner from room service and return to my more mundane drugs of choice, chardonnay and mediocre-movies-on-demand.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

                <header>
        <h2 class="module-heading">
                            Related in <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/opinion/index.html">Opinion</a>
                    </h2>
    </header>

            <ul>
                                                            <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2013/05/22/how-can-marijuana-be-sold-safely/">

        
        <h2 class="story-heading">
                                                    <span class="story-heading-text">Room for Debate: How Can Marijuana Be Sold Safely?</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2013-05-22" itemprop="datePublished" content="2013-05-22">MAY 22, 2013</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
</article>
</li>
                                                </ul>
        </div><!-- close nocontent -->
    </aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="434" data-total-count="1080" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">But then I felt a scary shudder go through my body and brain. I barely made it from the desk to the bed, where I lay curled up in a hallucinatory state for the next eight hours. I was thirsty but couldn’t move to get water. Or even turn off the lights. I was panting and paranoid, sure that when the room-service waiter knocked and I didn’t answer, he’d call the police and have me arrested for being unable to handle my candy.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="222" data-total-count="1302" itemprop="articleBody">I strained to remember where I was or even what I was wearing, touching my green corduroy jeans and staring at the exposed-brick wall. As my paranoia deepened, I became convinced that I had died and no one was telling me.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="298" data-total-count="1600" itemprop="articleBody">It took all night before it began to wear off, distressingly slowly. The next day, a medical consultant at an edibles plant where I was conducting an interview mentioned that candy bars like that are supposed to be cut into 16 pieces for novices; but that recommendation hadn’t been on the label.</p><aside class="marginalia collection-marginalia collection collection-type-column collection-tone-opinion collection-section-opinion collection-theme-latest-headlines nocontent robots-nocontent" role="complementary">
    <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
                <header>
                        <div class="thumb">
                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/11/01/opinion/dowd-circular/dowd-circular-blogSmallThumb-v2.png" alt="" />
            </div>
                        <div class="collection-meta">
                <div class="follow-button-placeholder" data-collection-id="column.maureen-dowd"></div>
                <h2 class="collection-marginalia-heading"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/column/maureen-dowd">Maureen Dowd</a></h2>
                <h3 class="collection-marginalia-subheading">American politics, popular culture and international affairs.</h3>
            </div>
        </header>
        <ul>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/29/opinion/king-kevin-versus-queen-cersei.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FMaureen Dowd">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                King Kevin Versus Queen Cersei            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-11-26">NOV 26</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/08/opinion/sunday/poppy-bush-finally-gives-junior-a-spanking.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FMaureen Dowd">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                Poppy Bush Finally Gives Junior a Spanking            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-11-07">NOV 7</time>

                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">

        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                Fall of the House of Bush            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-10-31">OCT 31</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/25/opinion/sunday/the-empire-strikes-back.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FMaureen Dowd">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                The Empire Strikes Back            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-10-24">OCT 24</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/18/opinion/sunday/will-hillary-clinton-be-pilloried-by-the-benghazi-committee.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FMaureen Dowd">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                Will Hillary Clinton Be Pilloried by the Benghazi Committee?            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-10-17">OCT 17</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                    </ul>
        <footer>
            <p class="user-action"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/column/maureen-dowd">See More &raquo;</a></p>
        </footer>
    </div><!-- close nocontent -->
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="254" data-total-count="1854" itemprop="articleBody">I reckoned that the fact that I was not a regular marijuana smoker made me more vulnerable, and that I should have known better. But it turns out, five months in, that some kinks need to be ironed out with the intoxicating open bar at the Mile High Club.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="445" data-total-count="2299" itemprop="articleBody">Colorado raked in about $12.6 million the first three months after pot was legalized for adults 21 and over. Pot party planners are dreaming up classy events: the Colorado Symphony just had its first “Classically Cannabis” fund-raiser with joints and Debussy. But the state is also coming to grips with the darker side of unleashing a drug as potent as marijuana on a horde of tourists of all ages and tolerance levels seeking a mellow buzz.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="387" data-total-count="2686" itemprop="articleBody">In March, a 19-year-old Wyoming college student jumped off a Denver hotel balcony after eating a pot cookie with 65 milligrams of THC. In April, a Denver man ate pot-infused Karma Kandy and began talking like it was the end of the world, scaring his wife and three kids. Then he retrieved a handgun from a safe and killed his wife while she was on the phone with an emergency dispatcher.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-4">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="232" data-total-count="2918" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">As <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/01/us/after-5-months-of-sales-colorado-sees-the-downside-of-a-legal-high.html">Jack Healy reported in The Times on Sunday</a>, Colorado hospital officials “are treating growing numbers of children and adults sickened by potent doses of edible marijuana” and neighboring states are seeing more stoned drivers.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-5">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="523" data-total-count="3441" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-5">“We realized there was a problem because we’re watching everything with the urgency of the first people to regulate in this area,” said Andrew Freedman, the state’s director of marijuana coordination. “There are way too many stories of people not understanding how much they’re eating. With liquor, people understand what they’re getting themselves into. But that doesn’t exist right now for edibles for new users in the market. It would behoove the industry to create a more pleasant experience for people.</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="228" data-total-count="3669" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-6">“The whole industry was set up for people who smoked frequently. It needs to learn how to educate new users in the market. We have to create a culture of responsibility around edibles, so people know what to expect to feel.”</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-7">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="493" data-total-count="4162" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-7">Gov. John Hickenlooper and the Legislature recently created a task force to come up with packaging that clearly differentiates pot cookies and candy and gummy bears from normal sweets — with an eye toward protecting children — and directed the Department of Revenue to restrict the amount of edibles that can be sold at one time to one person. The governor also signed legislation mandating that there be a stamp on edibles, possibly a marijuana leaf. (Or maybe a stoned skull and bones?)</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="338" data-total-count="4500" itemprop="articleBody">The state plans to start testing to make sure the weed is spread evenly throughout the product. The task force is discussing having budtenders give better warnings to customers and moving toward demarcating a single-serving size of 10 milligrams. (Industry representatives objected to the expense of wrapping bites of candy individually.)</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="264" data-total-count="4764" itemprop="articleBody">“My kids put rocks and batteries in their mouths,” said Bob Eschino, the owner of Incredibles, which makes candy and serves up chocolate and strawberry fountains. “If I put a marijuana leaf on a piece of chocolate, they’ll still put it in their mouths.”</p><button class="button comments-button  theme-speech-bubble" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-8">
</button>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="162" data-total-count="4926" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-8">He argues that, since pot goodies leave the dispensary in childproof packages, it is the parents’ responsibility to make sure their kids don’t get hold of it.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="229" data-total-count="5155" itemprop="articleBody">“Somebody suggested we just make everything look like a gray square so it doesn’t look appealing. Why should the whole industry suffer just because less than 5 percent of people are having problems with the correct dosing?”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="33" data-total-count="5188" itemprop="articleBody">Does he sound a little paranoid?</p>
        
                                        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
                        
        
        <p class="story-print-citation">A version of this op-ed appears in print on June 4, 2014, on page A23 of the <span itemprop="printEdition">New York edition</span> with the headline: Don’t Harsh Our Mellow, Dude. <span class="story-footer-links">  <span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/todayspaper/index.html" target="_blank">Today's Paper</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span><span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/subscriptions/Multiproduct/lp839RF.html?campaignId=48JQY" target="_blank">Subscribe</a></span>
</span>
</p>
    </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </footer>

        
                    <nav id="next-in"></nav><!-- close next-in -->
            </div><!-- close story-body -->
</article>
<aside class="marginalia most-emailed-marginalia hidden nocontent robots-nocontent" data-truncate-enabled="true"></aside>

require(['foundation/main'], function () {
    require(['article/main']);
    require(['jquery/nyt', 'foundation/views/page-manager'], function ($, pageManager) {
        if (window.location.search.indexOf('disable_tagx') > 0) {
            return;
        }
        $(document).ready(function () {
            require(['http://static01.nyt.com/bi/js/tagx/tagx.js'], function () {
                pageManager.trackingFireEventQueue();
            });
        });
    });
});
</script>

d)k.setAttribute(o,d[o]);c=j?h:c||f,k.onreadystatechange=k.onload=function(){!l&&g(k.readyState)&&(l=1,c(),k.onload=k.onreadystatechange=null)},m(function(){l||(l=1,c(1))},e),i?k.onload():n.parentNode.insertBefore(k,n)},a.yepnope.injectCss=function(a,c,d,e,g,i){var e=b.createElement("link"),j,c=i?h:c||f;e.href=a,e.rel="stylesheet",e.type="text/css";for(j in d)e.setAttribute(j,d[j]);g||(n.parentNode.insertBefore(e,n),m(c,0))}}(this,document),Modernizr.load=function(){yepnope.apply(window,[].slice.call(arguments,0))};
    // nytmm
    window.NYTD = window.NYTD || {};
    window.NYTD.NYTMM = window.NYTD.NYTMM || {};
    window.NYTD.NYTMM.Modernizr = window.Modernizr;
</script>

    _gaq.push(['_setAccount', 'UA-9262032-1']);
    _gaq.push(['_trackPageview']);

    window.NYTMM_IE = false;

	var bodyWrapper = document.getElementById("nytmm_wrapper");
	bodyWrapper.style.visibility = "hidden";
