								<h5>Dasani Recites &lsquo;Phenomenal Woman&rsquo;</h5>
							</div>
						</span>
					</div>

			</footer>
			<div class="nytmm_buildable nytmm_next" data-type="bottomprompt" data-id="prompt_slide_2" data-part="3" data-title="A Neighborhood&rsquo;s Profound Divide"></div>
		</div><!--END PART CONTENT-->
		</div>
	</section>


<!-- POVERTY PART 3 ****************************************************************** //-->

	<section class="poverty_section clearfix" id="poverty_part_3" data-title="3">

		<div class="nytmm_buildable section" 
			data-type="coverslide"
			data-id="cover_slide_3"
			data-part="3"
			data-title="A Neighborhood&rsquo;s Profound Divide"
			data-summary="">
		</div>

		<div class="nytmm_trigger clearfix" data-type="shownavbar" data-top="0">
		<div class="poverty_part_content">
			<div class="section column firstSection">
				<p class="pov_first_paragraph top"><span class="pov_first_letter">O</span>n the Brooklyn block that is Dasani&rsquo;s dominion, shoppers can buy a $3 malt liquor in an airless deli where food stamps are traded for cigarettes. Or they can cross the street for a $740 bottle of chardonnay at an industrial wine shop accented with modern art. </p>

				<p>It is a sign outside that locale, Gnarly Vines, that catches Dasani&rsquo;s notice one spring afternoon: &ldquo;Wine Tasting Tonight 5-8.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani is hardly conversant in the subject of libations, but this much she knows: A little drink will take off her mother&rsquo;s edge. Without further ado, Chanel heads into the wine shop on Myrtle Avenue, trailed by four of her eight children. They are lugging two greasy boxes of pizza and a jumbo pack of diapers from Target.</p>

				<p>The cashier pauses. The sommelier smiles.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Wanna try a little ros&eacute;?&rdquo; she asks brightly, pouring from a 2012 bottle of Mas de Gourgonnier. &ldquo;I would describe it as definitely fruit forward at the beginning.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Chanel polishes it.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;But really crisp, dry, refreshing &mdash;&mdash;&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Not refreshing,&rdquo; Chanel says. &ldquo;I just think dry.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;No, it&rsquo;s very dry,&rdquo; says the sommelier, a peppy blonde in wire-rim glasses. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s high acid, a little citrusy.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Chanel sticks out her tongue. She finds the woman&rsquo;s choice of words unappetizing. To the side of the wine display is a large, silver vase that recalls the family urn, prompting Chanel&rsquo;s son Khaliq to ask if it contains the ashes of a dead person.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Oh my gosh, for cremation?&rdquo; the sommelier asks, shaking her head. &ldquo;We just use it for spitting in.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;For spitting?&rdquo; Chanel says with horror.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Yeah, it&rsquo;s got rejected wine in it,&rdquo; the sommelier says.</p>

				<p>Chanel scoffs. She might not like the wine, but she sees no reason to spit it out. She moves on to a Tuscan sangiovese.</p>

				<p>Ignoring the spectacle, Dasani scans the room, frowning at a sign on the wall: Liqueur. &ldquo;They got liquor spelled wrong,&rdquo; she yelps victoriously.</p>

				<p>Actually, the sommelier interjects, that is the French word for the delicate, liquid spirits derived from fruits such as pomegranates and raspberries. &ldquo;But you&rsquo;re very right,&rdquo; she offers sweetly. &ldquo;That is not how you spell liquor.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Not the hood liquor,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">D</span>asani&rsquo;s neighborhood is one of the most unequal pockets of New York City, the most unequal metropolis in America.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Fort Greene occupies less than one square mile. On the map, its boundaries form the shape of a pitcher tilting at the northwestern edge of Brooklyn.</p>

				<p>Just north of Fort Greene Park are the projects and, among them, the homeless shelter where Dasani lives.</p>

				<p>Just south of the park are some of Brooklyn&rsquo;s finest townhouses and cultural gems, including the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where theatergoers were lining up to see &ldquo;Julius Caesar&rdquo; on the day that Dasani led her mother to the wine shop.</p>

				<p>If one thing distinguishes Dasani&rsquo;s New York from that of her antecedents, it is a striking proximity to the wealth that eludes her.</p>
			</div>

			<!--STREET VIEW GRAPHIC SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_3_slideshow_graphic">
                <!--3 slides-->
                <div id="part_3_sequence_fixie_slideshow_graphic" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<p>She routinely walks past a boho-chic boutique on Lafayette Avenue where calfskin boots command $845. Heading north, she passes French bulldogs on leashes and infants riding like elevated genies in Uppababy strollers with shock-absorbing wheels. Three blocks away is an ice cream parlor where $6 buys two salted-caramel scoops.</p>

				<p>Like most children, Dasani is oblivious to the precise cost of such extravagances. She only knows that they are beyond her reach.</p>

				<p>Nor can this 11-year-old girl be expected to grasp the subtle gradations of Fort Greene&rsquo;s elite, whose creative class feels pushed out of a neighborhood it once considered more gritty than tony.</p>

				<p>Dasani sees the chasms of Fort Greene more plainly, reasoning that wealth belongs to &ldquo;the whites&rdquo; because &ldquo;they save their money and don&rsquo;t spend it on drinking and smoking.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Such perceptions are fed by the contrasts of this neighborhood, where the top 5 percent of residents earn 76 times as much as the bottom quintile. Dasani spots addicts gathering outside a food pantry a block from $2 million brownstones. She notes that few people in the projects use the Citi Bikes stationed nearby. The celebrated bike sharing program, unveiled this year, requires a credit or debit card for a $101 security deposit.</p>

				<p>Dasani also knows that not everyone in the projects is poor. Her Uncle Waverly, who lives in the Walt Whitman Houses across from her shelter, the Auburn Family Residence, works as a supervisor for the parks department and has a Lexus S.U.V. When he drives past Dasani and her siblings, he pretends not to know them.</p>

				<p>Dasani charts the patterns of Fort Greene Park by skin color. The basketball courts are closest to the projects, drawing black children to that northwestern corner. On the rare occasion when Dasani ventures to the opposite quadrant, she sees white women sunbathing in bikinis or playing tennis near a water fountain outfitted for dogs.</p>

				<p>She never finds those women at the nearby Bravo Supermarket for Values, where thieves are photographed in Polaroids that fill the store&rsquo;s &ldquo;Wall of Shame.&rdquo; Wearing naked expressions, they are forced to pose with their stolen items &mdash; things like Goya beans and Kraft cheese. A woman named Mary holds a can of tuna in a photograph titled &ldquo;Catch of the Day.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani is more likely to encounter shoppers of another stratum at the local Target, where they can save on items that for her family represent a splurge.</p>

				<p>Fort Greene&rsquo;s two economies are an experiment born of meteoric gentrification. In the last decade, the neighborhood has been remade, with the portion of white residents jumping by 80 percent as real estate prices more than doubled despite the recession.</p>

				<p>Just the word &ldquo;gentrification&rdquo; is remarkably divisive.  It derives from the Middle English word &ldquo;gentrise,&rdquo; which means &ldquo;of noble descent.&rdquo; The word has become shorthand for an urban neighborhood where muggings are down and espresso is roasted &mdash; a place that has been &ldquo;discovered,&rdquo; as though no one had been living there.</p>
			</div>



            <!--VIDEO GRAPHIC OF NEW YORK -->
            <div class="section video_sequence nytmm_trigger" data-type="autoplay" id="part_3_videospriteshow" data-position="center">

                <div id="part_3_video_fixie">
                    <div class="nytmm_videoSprite nytmm_buildable"
                         data-type="videobox"
                         data-slug="incomemap"
                         data-videoslug="incomeBlocks_4" 
                         data-mp4="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/incomeBlocks_4_1400.mp4"
                         data-webm="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/incomeBlocks_4_1400.webm"
                         data-poster="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/incomeBlocks_4_1400.jpg">
                    </div>
                </div>

			</div>

			<div class="section column">
				<p>Dasani&rsquo;s Fort Greene reaches deep into the last century. Her grandmother Joanie grew up in the Raymond V. Ingersoll Houses, next to the Walt Whitman Houses. Both projects opened in 1944, an era of New Deal reforms that gave rise to white flight and urban decay. Fort Greene, like other black areas, was redlined, allowing banks to disinvest and property values to plummet.</p>

				<p>The neighborhood&rsquo;s prospects started to change in 1978, after the city declared part of Fort Greene a historic district. By the time Dasani was born there in 2001, a billionaire was preparing to run for mayor. A year after taking office, Michael R. Bloomberg announced an ambitious redevelopment plan for Downtown Brooklyn.</p>

				<p>Fort Greene&rsquo;s transformation came swiftly. Through aggressive rezoning and generous subsidies, the city drew developers who, in the span of three years, built 19 luxury buildings in the surrounding area that catered &mdash; across racial lines &mdash; to the educated elite.</p>

				<p>Dasani and her siblings routinely pass the Toren, a glistening, 38-story glass tower on Myrtle Avenue offering a 24-hour concierge, gymnasium, pool and movie theater. In June, a condominium there sold for $1.4 million.</p>

				<p>Just blocks away stand the Ingersoll and Whitman projects, which engulf Dasani&rsquo;s shelter and, like Auburn, have fallen into disrepair.</p>

				<p>It is the juxtaposition of these neglected time capsules to Fort Greene&rsquo;s luxury towers that seems to mock the neighborhood&rsquo;s effort at ascension. For the arriviste investor, the projects present a rude visual interruption, an inconvenient thing to walk around, but never through.</p>

				<p>For Dasani, these faded buildings hold a legacy so intricate and rich it could fill volumes were it ever told.</p>

				<p>The homeless shelter where she lives is the very building where Grandma Joanie had been born, back when it was Cumberland Hospital. Just across the way is the fifth-story apartment where Joanie grew up, helping her own mother raise seven other children in the clasp of poverty.</p>

				<p>Three generations later, little has changed. Even as the fortunes of this neighborhood rose, Dasani&rsquo;s matrilineal line, from her great-grandmother to her mother, has followed a trajectory of teenage pregnancy, addiction and violence.</p>

				<p>Fort Greene is now a marker. For one set of people, arriving signals triumph. For another, remaining means defeat.</p>

				<p>Dasani will do better, she tells herself. &ldquo;People don&rsquo;t go nowhere in Brooklyn,&rdquo; she says. Chanel promises they will move this spring, after the tax refunds arrive.</p>

				<p>Yet as Dasani walks through her grandmother&rsquo;s streets, it is not with the sense of imminent departure so much as melancholic return. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">C</span>hanel was 8 when she found her mother&rsquo;s crack pipe in a jewelry box. She held it up to the light and showed it to her brother.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;We gonna toss it, he said.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;They opened the window and watched as the brown glass vial soared through the air, crashing onto the sidewalk.</p>

				<p>It was the mid-1980s, and crack had swept the streets of Brownsville, Brooklyn, where Chanel&rsquo;s mother, Joanie, now lived. Chanel visited on weekends. The rest of the time, she stayed with her godmother, Sherry, who had been the common-law wife of Chanel&rsquo;s father. Chanel&rsquo;s mother was his lover.</p>

				<p>Stranger things had happened in Brownsville, and now that Chanel&rsquo;s father was dead, the two women made peace, despite their differences. Joanie relied on welfare to support her habit. Sherry ran a day care center and shunned drugs.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;It was like two different people trying to raise one kid,&rdquo; Chanel says. </p>

			<!--CHANEL AND JOANIE SEQUENCE / OLD MOVED INTO SINGLE PHOTOS-->
            <!-- <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_3_slideshow_1"> -->
                <!--2 slides-->
                <!-- <div id="part_3_sequence_fixie_slideshow_1" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div> -->

            	<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_3_single_1"></div>

				<p>At Sherry&rsquo;s rowhouse in East New York, Brooklyn, Chanel minded her chores and did her homework.</p>

				<p>At Joanie&rsquo;s, the child watched dance parties meld into a predawn haze. </p>

				<p>Worried that Joanie would unduly influence Chanel, Sherry sent the 10-year-old girl to live with a relative in Pittsburgh and attend Catholic school. But Chanel longed for her birth mother and began to act out. Within a few years, she returned to New York and moved in with Joanie. They soon wound up in a shelter in Queens, where both were exposed to tuberculosis.</p>

				<p>Over the next few years, they drifted apart.</p>

				<p>Joanie turned her life around after President Bill Clinton signed legislation in 1996 to end &ldquo;welfare as we know it,&rdquo; placing time limits and work restrictions on recipients of government aid. She got clean and joined a welfare-to-work program, landing a $22,000-a-year job cleaning subway cars for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. &ldquo;This is the happiest day of my life,&rdquo; she told Chanel.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_3_single_2"></div>

				<p>By then, Chanel had dropped out of high school and was addicted to crack. She had joined a sect of the violent Bloods gang, tattooing her street name, Lady Red, in curly letters across her right arm. She was a regular in the crack dens of Bedford-Stuyvesant.</p>

				<p>Chanel first noticed white people in &ldquo;the Stuy&rdquo; after a snowstorm swept Brooklyn in the late 1990s. Out of nowhere, two cross-country skiers appeared along Franklin Avenue like &ldquo;a pair of aliens.&rdquo; She watched as the skiers coasted by, carving a trail through virgin snow.</p>

				<p>She sensed that Brooklyn was on the cusp of change. But she could not have imagined that just five blocks from that spot, people would one day line up to buy blood orange and hibiscus doughnuts at an artisanal shop called Dough.</p>

				<p>The first commercial signs of Brooklyn&rsquo;s transition were simpler. In 2001, Chanel spotted a new brand of bottled water &mdash; Dasani &mdash; on the shelves of her corner store. She was pregnant again, but unlike the miscarriages of her teens, this baby was surviving. Chanel needed a name.</p>

				<p>For a 23-year-old Brooklyn native who had spent summers cooling in the gush of hydrants, the name &ldquo;Dasani&rdquo; held a certain appeal. It sounded as special as Chanel&rsquo;s name had sounded to her own mother, when she saw the perfume advertised in a magazine. It grasped at something better.</p>

				<p>Dasani was born on May 26 at Brooklyn Hospital Center in Fort Greene. The doll-faced infant weighed only 5 pounds 6 ounces. She was strikingly alert and had, the nurse noted, a &ldquo;vigorous cry.&rdquo; Three days later, Chanel left her with Joanie and took off.</p>

				<p>Even as a baby, Dasani was awake to the world. She leaned out of her stroller and stared at passers-by, who called her &ldquo;Batman eyes.&rdquo; She was tiny, but never frail, and began walking at only 8 months.</p>

				<p>Chanel would surface from time to time, but Dasani latched on to Joanie. A year later, Chanel had a second daughter by the same man, naming her Avianna, inspired by the more expensive brand of Evian water.</p>

				<p>Joanie had hit her limit, so Chanel turned to the city&rsquo;s shelter system. With both babies, she reported to the Department of Homeless Services intake office in the Bronx. They were sent to 30 Hamilton Place, a family shelter in Harlem.</p>

				<p>Down the hall, a single father had moved in with his own two children. He called himself Supreme. He had sad, knowing eyes that made him look older than his 26 years. He never talked about the past. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">S</span>upreme was born to heroin addicts in the Cypress Hills projects of East New York. By age 7, he knew how to shop with his mother&rsquo;s food stamps and cook grits for his four younger siblings. When the pantry was empty, he made sugar sandwiches. </p>

				<p>He was 9 when he came upon the lifeless body of his baby sister. She had been left near the entrance of the projects, wrapped in a blanket. Supreme stroked her head and kept saying her name, Precious. &ldquo;She didn&rsquo;t wake up,&rdquo; he says.</p>

				<p>Investigators for Child Protective Services thought the 2-year-old girl had swallowed sleeping pills, though the medical examiner concluded that she had died of sudden infant death syndrome. The father had left Precious alone when she died. When her mother found her, Supreme recalled, she panicked, leaving the girl&rsquo;s body outside as she ran for help.</p>

				<p>Later that day, the agency&rsquo;s workers removed Supreme and his siblings from the home. For the next three years, Supreme bounced from foster care to group homes. He soon dropped out of school and left for North Carolina to join the crack trade. By 17, Supreme had a felony drug conviction and was serving time at a maximum-security prison in Walpole, Mass.</p>

				<p>It was there that he discovered the Five Percent Nation, a growing movement whose followers believe they are the chosen &ldquo;5 percent&rdquo; of humanity. The Five Percenters were shaping urban culture and music, while spreading the word that the black man is God.</p>

				<p>That message &mdash; that God was within him &mdash; filled Supreme with a sense of power over his destiny, one that until now had been steered by outsiders.</p>

				<p>Supreme left prison in 1997 with a high school equivalency diploma. He married and moved to Washington, finding work as a barber. Six years later, his wife &mdash; pregnant with their third child &mdash; had a heart attack and fell down a flight of stairs to her death.</p>

				<p>Chanel took pity on this solemn widower, who came to the shelter a few months after his wife&rsquo;s passing. Dasani and Avianna were the exact same ages as his children. He seemed different from the other men. He was always reading, and had a way with words.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I fell in love with his brains,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p>Two incomplete families soon became one.</p>

				<p> Chanel embraced the Five Percent, wrapping her head in a scarf and vowing to stay off drugs. They married at the city clerk&rsquo;s office on Feb. 4, 2004.</p>

				<p>For Chanel, it was a moment of triumph. Women in her family almost never married.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;We were the product of split-up families,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;We always wanted a big family. One family. One full family.&rdquo;</p>
			</div>

            <!--CHANEL AND SUPREME SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_3_slideshow_2">
                <!--2 slides-->
                <div id="part_3_sequence_fixie_slideshow_2" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>But Supreme and Chanel had a temperamental love. Their biggest fights led to brief separations, even as three more children were born. </p>

				<p>Chanel could not stay off drugs for long. When she gave birth to Papa in 2007, the hospital detected marijuana in his blood. </p>
				</span>

				<p>In an instant, everything changed. </p>

				<p>Chanel and Supreme were summoned to the Administration for Children&rsquo;s Services office in Bedford-Stuyvesant &mdash; the same brick building where Supreme had been escorted as a child.</p>

				<p>Standing there, in the lobby, the memory came rushing back. Supreme was 9 again, losing his sister, then his parents, then his other siblings, all in the course of a day.</p>

				<p>Soon his own children became accustomed to knocks at the door as the agency&rsquo;s caseworkers, responding to a handful of complaints about possible neglect, began to monitor the family. They inspected the children from head to toe, searching for signs of abuse.</p>

				<p>Dasani learned to spot a social worker on the street by the person&rsquo;s bag (large enough to hold files). She became expert at the complex psychic task of managing strangers &mdash; of reading facial expressions and interpreting intonations, of knowing when to say the right thing or to avoid the wrong one.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;They can use that in a court of law against the parent,&rdquo; she says, back in the voice of &ldquo;Criminal Minds.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>She pauses.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I love my parents. They&rsquo;re tough, but I should not be taken away from them.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani remained tethered to Grandma Joanie, who had proudly kept her job as a sanitation worker. She now lived in a cozy apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant. On weekends, Joanie would fix the children B.L.T. sandwiches and meticulously braid their hair before snuggling up to watch Beyonc&eacute; videos.</p>

				<p>Dasani was Joanie&rsquo;s favorite. With this child, Joanie could finally be a mother. With Joanie, Dasani could be a child.</p>

				<p>A few months shy of Dasani&rsquo;s eighth birthday, Joanie fell gravely ill with leukemia.</p>

				<p>On March 7, 2008, she died in the same hospital where Dasani had been born. She was 55.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Why she had to go away so quickly?&rdquo; Dasani asks.</p>

				<p>At the funeral, mourners gasped as the tiny girl flung herself on the open coffin. Dasani kicked and wailed as Chanel tore her away. </p>

				<p>Joanie was cremated and her ashes placed in a black and silver urn that remained with Dasani&rsquo;s family, accompanying them like a talisman.</p>

				<p>Her death brought a rebirth. Chanel inherited $49,000 of Joanie&rsquo;s pension savings.</p>

				<p>At the time, the family had been renting a small apartment in East New York through a city program offering time-limited subsidies to the homeless.</p>

				<p>That month, the family&rsquo;s subsidy expired.</p>

				<p>Chanel&rsquo;s inheritance saved them from homelessness. Months later, the city began a new rent subsidy program called Advantage. With its help, Chanel leased a duplex on Staten Island, and in summer 2008, boarded the Staten Island Ferry with Supreme and the children. It was their first time on a boat. They raced to the back and leaned into the salty mist.</p>

				<p>Staten Island was quiet and green. In their new apartment on North Burgher Avenue, the children rolled around on the wall-to-wall carpet. There they lay, pressed together, that first night.</p>

				<p>It was their first real home. The children&rsquo;s euphoria steadily rose with that of their parents.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;When they&rsquo;re happy, I&rsquo;m happy,&rdquo; Dasani says. &ldquo;When they&rsquo;re sad, I&rsquo;m sad. It&rsquo;s like I have a connection, like I&rsquo;m stuck to them like glue.&rdquo;</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_3_single_3"></div>

				<p>Chanel and Supreme talked giddily of starting a youth center that would teach the Five Percent ethos known as the &ldquo;Five P&rsquo;s&rdquo;: proper planning prevents poor performance.</p>

				<p>Supreme landed a job at Heavenly Cuts, a barbershop a few blocks away. Chanel bought a used, cherry-red Dodge Durango and a rolling kitchen island at Home Depot. She decorated the girls&rsquo; room with pink Barbie curtains, sheets and matching TVs. The children ran barefoot in the backyard, racing across a Slip &rsquo;N Slide as Supreme grilled burgers. Joanie&rsquo;s urn occupied a place of honor in the living room.</p>

				<p>This was, without question, the high point of their collective life.</p>

				<p>It would take years for Chanel to understand why things so quickly fell apart. It was not obvious, in that blinding moment, that money could be useful only if they knew how to spend it. To think it would bring salvation was as quixotic as expecting a set of keys to drive a car.</p>

				<p>Money was not going to heal a father who had never been a child. When customers took a seat in Supreme&rsquo;s chair at the barbershop, they saw a pair of hands expertly at work. They did not see the boy who, at age 7, had learned that very skill by cutting his brothers&rsquo; hair while his parents were strung out on heroin.</p>

				<p>What money brought was a quick escape from all that. Over the next two years, Supreme and Chanel bobbed and wove through a fog of addiction. Supreme started doing heroin. Chanel became hooked on painkillers during an extended stay at Staten Island Hospital, where she was being treated for a recurrence of the tuberculosis she contracted in a shelter.</p>

				<p>Children&rsquo;s Services hovered over the family, ensuring that Chanel and Supreme submit to random drug tests. Eventually, Supreme and Chanel stopped working.</p>

				<p>By August 2010, bedbugs had infested the family&rsquo;s house, just as their rent subsidy once again expired.</p>

				<p>The city&rsquo;s shelters were filling with former Advantage recipients &mdash; families who had been homeless before taking the rent subsidy, only to become homeless again.</p>

				<p>On Aug. 20, Dasani&rsquo;s family boarded the ferry to Manhattan, where they headed to the Department of Homeless Services&rsquo;s intake office in the South Bronx.</p>

				<p>As Dasani&rsquo;s family approached the entrance, Chanel spotted two abandoned baby turtles in a cardboard box. She stuffed them in her pockets.</p>

				<p>Six days later, the family arrived at Auburn, along with its two forbidden pet turtles and Joanie&rsquo;s urn. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">C</span>hildren are said to be adaptable. On outward appearances, Dasani and her siblings became inured to the dehumanizing ways of Auburn &mdash; the security checks at the entrance, the grimy bathrooms, the long waits for rancid food. </p>

				<p>Yet nothing prepared them for what happened on Sept. 7, 2011, a year after they arrived.</p>

				<p>Chanel and the children had been &ldquo;logged out&rdquo; of Auburn, the official description of what happens when residents who have been absent for more than 48 hours are sent to the Bronx intake office to fill out forms and answer questions. The entire family must make this onerous trip, even on school days.</p>

				<!--PATH VISIT COLLAGE HERE-->
				<div class="pov_image_collage" id="part_3_collage_path"></div>

				<p>That evening, tired and hungry, they returned to their room. It looked ransacked. Almost everything was gone: their clothes, shoes, books, television, toys, Social Security cards, birth certificates, photographs, love letters &mdash; the traces of their existence.</p>

				<p>Joanie&rsquo;s urn had also vanished.</p>

				<p>Chanel raced down to the security guards, Dasani chasing after her.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Where are my mother&rsquo;s ashes?&rdquo; she screamed. The story soon emerged: An Auburn employee had paid a resident $10 to clean out the room, as other residents looted the family&rsquo;s valuables. Everything else was tossed in the garbage.</p>

				<p>Chanel bolted to the back of the shelter, where a large, metal incinerator holds Auburn&rsquo;s rotting trash. She waded in, the garbage reaching her waist. She searched frantically. This could not be Joanie&rsquo;s final resting place, she kept telling herself.</p>

				<p>She cursed. She wept aloud.</p>

				<p>Finally, she stopped. The truth was setting in. Fifty-seven years after Joanie had been born, here in this very building, her remains were dumped in the garbage.</p>

				<p>Upstairs, the room felt cursed.</p>

				<p>Joanie had always protected the children, in life and in death. Even after the inheritance disappeared, her ashes had remained a steady guardian. But now Joanie was gone. In her absence, a devastating chain of events unfolded.</p>

				<p>Chanel paced the room that evening, desperate and broke. Supreme was gone after another fight. She expected no help from Auburn. Still, she had gone to the <a href="#" class="nytmm_link_media nytmm_link_doc doc_complaint_chanel"><span class="document_icon"></span>trouble of filing a complaint</a>, writing in hurried print, &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know what to do my kid start school tomorrow and I have nothing.&rdquo;</p>

				<!--DOC DHS COMPLAINT FROM CHANEL -->
				<div class="nytmm_document_promo doc_complaint_chanel" id="doc_complaint_chanel_promo">
					<span class="nytmm-2013ChildPovertyDeploy-icons document_blue"></span> 
					<span class="doc-header">Document</span>
					<div class="nytmm_doc_summary">Complaint filed by Chanel.</div>
				</div>
				<div class="nytmm_buildable nytmm_document" data-type="document" data-trigger=".doc_complaint_chanel" data-doc="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/p3-chanel-complaint.jpg" data-slug="p1-complaint-chanel" data-format="jpg">
					<div class="nytmm_doc_container"></div>
				</div>

				<p>The next day, Chanel left the children alone in the room, defying the shelter&rsquo;s rules, and hit the streets in search of cash. A man approached her on Myrtle Avenue asking where he could buy drugs. He did not look like an undercover officer, so she steered him to the projects. She was arrested and later pleaded guilty to drug possession charges, though Chanel maintains she was innocent.</p>

				<p>When Chanel did not return that night, Dasani felt something in the air. There was a knock at the door. Dasani shushed the kids. They pretended to be asleep. Then the door opened as an Auburn supervisor and Homeless Services police told the children to get dressed.</p>

				<p>The Administration for Children&rsquo;s Services had known for months that Chanel was getting high on opiates, but had been trying to keep the family together. After her arrest, a family judge ordered new drug tests for both parents, revealing that Supreme had also been smoking marijuana.</p>

				<p>With that, the agency went to court to have the children removed. In a hearing on Sept. 20, the children&rsquo;s lawyer objected, arguing that to divide them among foster homes &ldquo;who knows where in the city&rdquo; would &ldquo;present a greater imminent risk to the children than remaining where they are.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The judge struck a compromise: Both parents needed to comply with a drug treatment program. The children were to remain with Supreme, but Chanel temporarily lost custody.</p>

				<p>She had suffered all kinds of losses, but nothing compared with this. Who was she if not a mother? She had always tried to be there, rarely missing a school play or a parent-teacher conference. On Sunday afternoons she would braid hair until her fingers turned numb. At bedtime each night, she flipped through the family dictionary to teach her children a new &ldquo;word of the day.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Now, Chanel would be living with Sherry, only seeing the children on supervised visits. She broke the news to the children on a park bench.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;Take care of your siblings,&rdquo; she instructed Dasani.</p>

				<p>Dasani was silent.</p>

				<p>Supreme ruled by fear. If the children laughed too loud, he only had to yell &ldquo;Shut up!&rdquo; and they froze, a silent dread passing among them. He had an old-fashioned approach to child rearing: Break the rules and you get the belt. Chanel&rsquo;s presence had tempered him.</p>

				<p>When she left, Supreme wrote two words on the wall in black marker: &ldquo;King Me!&rdquo; </p>
				
				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_3_single_4"></div>

				<p>Under the agency&rsquo;s supervision, both Chanel and Supreme made steady progress in a treatment program that required taking daily doses of methadone, a synthetic drug meant to control addiction.</p>

				<p>Nearly a year later, on Aug. 2, 2012, the judge allowed Chanel to return to her family at Auburn under supervision from the Administration for Children&rsquo;s Services. She came with a promise: They would save enough money to leave. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">C</span>hanel spreads the cash across her bed, all $2,800. The children stare in awe.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know why I feel so happy,&rdquo; Avianna says.</p>

				<p>Chanel quickly stashes it, announcing no intention of spending her long-awaited tax refund, which arrived Feb. 13.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Once you start to break them bills, that&rsquo;s it, they&rsquo;re gone,&rdquo; Chanel says the next morning. She is walking through the projects, the money bulging from her pocket. She does not know where to put it, so she holds onto it and, more than anything, the feeling of having it.</p>

				<p>She pushes Baby Lele&rsquo;s creaky stroller toward Downtown Brooklyn, whose street names mockingly suggest riches. Gold. Tillary. Bond. She takes an inventory of all the things she could &mdash; but won&rsquo;t &mdash; buy: a new stroller, sneakers, a hair-braiding session for the girls.</p>

				<p>Chanel knows that unless she finds a way to save her money, and persuades Supreme not to spend his own tax refund, they will never leave Auburn.</p>

				<p>And yet, planning has never been their way. &ldquo;To plan something is to plan to fail,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;My plan is to do some goddamn laundry.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Tax season brings a sudden reprieve for a family that, with food stamps, has about $75 a day to spend. This amounts to $7.50 per person in a city where three subway trips cost as much. They survive because they live rent-free and have access to three meals a day.</p>

				<p>Chanel is reminded of this when she stops to look at listings in the window of a real estate office near her methadone clinic. A one-bedroom in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is going for $1,300 a month.</p>

				<p>She sees no option but to leave New York. In a show of commitment, Chanel gives $800 of her tax refund to Grandma Sherry in exchange for a used Chevrolet minivan, which is sitting in the driveway with no permit.</p>

				<p>Now they must wait for Supreme&rsquo;s tax refund.</p>

				<p>If only life imitated Monopoly, Supreme&rsquo;s favorite board game, which he plays with the children on a mattress in their crowded room. &ldquo;I like building up property and collecting rent,&rdquo; he says.</p>

				<p>But becoming a real renter, he finds, is far more challenging than claiming Park Place on a cardboard square.</p>

				<p>Auburn no longer has a housing specialist on staff &mdash; the last one died four years ago and was never replaced. Supreme has learned to navigate the web on his prepaid Android from Boost Mobile, but the phone is often disconnected. Chanel feels like a fumbling fool on the shelter&rsquo;s computers.</p>

				<p>And then there is the problem of Baby Lele. Investigators have repeatedly cited Auburn for providing no on-site child care, which hinders residents from searching for jobs or housing. Chanel is reluctant to leave Lele with other mothers at Auburn, many of whom have their own Children&rsquo;s Services cases. If anything were to happen, Chanel&rsquo;s custody could be in jeopardy.</p>

				<p>Instead, Chanel begins leaving Lele under the watch of a friendly counselor at her methadone program, where children are not allowed. The counselor stands outside with Lele as Chanel darts in to swallow her orange liquid dose.</p>

				<p>When a clinic supervisor discovers the arrangement, Chanel is exposed. If she keeps leaving Lele with acquaintances on the street, Children&rsquo;s Services might find out. So Chanel stops going, and the clinic alerts the agency that she has fallen out of treatment. In March, the agency steps up its scrutiny, placing the family with a &ldquo;prevention worker&rdquo; who requires twice-weekly meetings.</p>

				<p>By now, Supreme has learned that his tax refund was seized by the government for child support owed to two other children he had before meeting Chanel.</p>

				<p>Dasani knows before her mother says a word.</p>

				<p>They will not be leaving.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">D</span>asani has learned to let disappointments pass in silence. Objecting does nothing to change the facts.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;But she reveals herself through the questions she asks.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Mommy, if these projects was your only choice, would you take it?&rdquo; she asks Chanel one day in March as they are out walking. Chanel nods reluctantly.</p>

				<p>Dasani lets it go. She knows not to push.</p>

				<p>Spring has brought a new set of worries. For the wealthier children in Fort Greene, it is a season to show off new wardrobes. For Dasani&rsquo;s family, it is a time of scrambling. Appearances are more easily kept when the same coat is all that people see. </p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_3_single_5"></div>

				<p>The project kids begin to ridicule Dasani&rsquo;s pink sweatsuit, calling it &ldquo;pajamas.&rdquo; On March 19, she agrees to fight a girl from school at nearby Commodore Barry Park. A crowd gathers as they establish the rules: No one can film it or tell a parent. They pull back their hair and Dasani punches her rival as they tumble to the ground. A man walking his dog pulls them apart.</p>

				<p>That evening, Chanel inspects the cut on Dasani&rsquo;s lip.</p>

				<p>Chanel may fail in all kinds of ways, but she holds Dasani&rsquo;s esteem in one powerful regard: The woman can fight. Dasani has grown up hearing her mother&rsquo;s stories of street-battle glory, and watching her in the throes of countless slug matches with anyone who crosses her, including the owner of a local laundromat.</p>

				<p>Chanel dismisses Dasani&rsquo;s tussles at school as &ldquo;kitty-cat fighting.&rdquo; Back in her day, girls cracked one another over the head with bottles. No one wasted time pulling back their hair.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You gotta keep your hood credit up,&rdquo; she tells Dasani. &ldquo;You take the biggest, baddest one down first and the rest of &rsquo;em will back up off of you. That&rsquo;s just how it works.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The next day, Chanel and Dasani wander up their favorite block of Myrtle Avenue, passing the Red Lantern, a bike repair shop that sells vegan cookies. They stop at a juice store that serves a hybrid clientele &mdash; Fort Greene&rsquo;s organic-forward newcomers and its health-conscious old-timers.</p>

				<p>There, Chanel spots an old flame. He wears a long leather jacket and dark shades. She wonders if he is still dealing.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Whassup, Red?&rdquo; he says.</p>

				<p>Dasani eyes him closely.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;That was her name from back when she was in the hood,&rdquo; she says, forever cataloging the details of her mother&rsquo;s past, even as Chanel tries to part with it.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m good now, see?&rdquo; Chanel crows, waving a hand over herself, as if motioning a transformation: clean, married, mother of eight. She nods proudly at her children.</p>

				<p>It is Dasani&rsquo;s belief that she and her siblings are the cause of her mother&rsquo;s ruin. It never occurs to her that, for Chanel, the children represent her only accomplishment.</p>

				<p>The next day, Chanel escorts Dasani to school. In the hallway, she spots the girl Dasani fought in the park. &ldquo;You can fight my kid,&rdquo; she says hotly, taking the girl by surprise. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m with that.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Minutes later, the principal, Paula Holmes, sits Dasani down. &ldquo;I believe you can change, but you&rsquo;re not showing me that,&rdquo; she says.</p>

				<p>Dasani returns to class feeling jaunty. The wrong message &mdash; Chanel&rsquo;s permission, rather than Miss Holmes&rsquo;s prohibition &mdash; has sunk in. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ma fight you,&rdquo; she tells another girl. &ldquo;My mother said she&rsquo;ll let me fight.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>With that, Dasani is suspended.</p>

				<p>Miss Holmes knows it is a risky move, but nothing else has worked. The girl needs to be shocked out of her behavior. The alternative is to fail in school and beyond.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Get your things and leave,&rdquo; Miss Holmes tells her.</p>

				<p>Dasani will be out of school for a whole week. She cannot speak.</p>

				<p>To be suspended is to be truly homeless. </p>

				<div class="nytmm_comments_container nytmm_buildable" data-type="commentcontainer"></div>

			</div>

			<footer class="clearfix">

				<div class="behind_the_scenes nytmm_buildable" data-type="reporternote"></div>

<!-- POVERTY PART 4 ****************************************************************** //-->
		
	<section class="poverty_section clearfix" id="poverty_part_4" data-title="4">

				<div class="nytmm_buildable section" 
					data-type="coverslide"
					data-id="cover_slide_4"
					data-part="4"
					data-title="Finding Strength in the Bonds of Her Siblings"
					data-summary="">
				</div>

		<div class="nytmm_trigger clearfix" data-type="shownavbar" data-top="0">
		<div class="poverty_part_content">
			<div class="section column firstSection">
				<p class="pov_first_paragraph top"><span class="pov_first_letter">C</span>hildren are not the face of New York&rsquo;s homeless. They rarely figure among the panhandlers and bag ladies, war vets and untreated schizophrenics who have long been stock characters in this city of contrasts.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Their homelessness is hidden. They spend their days in school, their nights in shelters. They are seen only in glimpses &mdash; pulling overstuffed suitcases in the shadow of a tired parent, passing for tourists rather than residents without a home.</p>

				<p>Their numbers have risen above anything in the city&rsquo;s modern history, to a staggering 22,091 this month. If all of the city&rsquo;s homeless children were to file into Madison Square Garden for a hockey game, more than 4,800 would not have a seat.</p>

				<p>Yet it is the adult population that drives debates on poverty and homelessness, with city officials and others citing &ldquo;personal responsibility&rdquo; as the central culprit. Children are bystanders in this discourse, no more to blame for their homelessness than for their existence.</p>

				<p>Dasani works to keep her homelessness hidden. She has spent years of her childhood in the punishing confines of the Auburn shelter in Brooklyn, where to be homeless is to be powerless. She and her seven siblings are at the mercy of forces beyond their control: parents who cannot provide, agencies that fall short, a metropolis rived by inequality and indifference.</p>

				<p>The experience has left Dasani internally adrift, for the losses of the homeless child only begin with the home itself. She has had to part with privacy and space &mdash; the kind of quiet that nurtures the mind. She has lost the dignity that comes with living free of vermin and chronic illness. She has fallen behind in school, despite her crackling intelligence.</p>

				<p>She has lost the simplest things that for other children are givens: the freedom of riding a bicycle, the safety of a bathroom not shared with strangers, the ease of being in school without stigma. And from all of these losses has come the departure of faith itself.</p>

				<p>God &ldquo;is somewhere around,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;We just can&rsquo;t find him.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>To trust is to be caught off guard.</p>

				<p>Dasani is unmoored by her recent suspension from the Susan S. McKinney Secondary School of the Arts. For months, this new school was her only haven. She had grown so attached to her principal, Paula Holmes, that she expected a measure of tolerance despite her outbursts, the kind of forgiveness she never gets at home.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_4_single_2"></div>

				<p>Her forced departure from school overlaps with spring break, plunging Dasani further into the morass of her family&rsquo;s troubles. Her parents&rsquo; resolve to leave Auburn has vanished now that their savings plan fell apart, yet the shelter is pressing the family to leave while offering no assistance in finding a home. Meanwhile, the Administration for Children&rsquo;s Services has stepped up its scrutiny of Dasani&rsquo;s parents, who are increasingly despondent.</p>

				<p>As pressure mounts from all sides, Dasani braces herself. She has seen this before &mdash; the storm of familial problems that suddenly gathers force.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s a tsunami, just spinning around, nothing going right,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;And I&rsquo;m like, &lsquo;Put my life back together!&rsquo; and it doesn&rsquo;t happen. Your life doesn&rsquo;t go the way you want it to go.&rdquo; </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">O</span>n April 3, Dasani climbs up the steps of McKinney wearing her best cardigan. She lingers in the hallway, keeping an eye on Principal Holmes&rsquo;s door. She is eager to try out the script her mother has drilled into her.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;How was your spring break, Miss Holmes?</p>

				<p>(Pause, wait for Miss Holmes to ask the same question.)</p>

				<p>Oh, it was good. I&rsquo;m staying out of trouble!</p>

				<p>(Wait for Miss Holmes to laugh and then head for the door, showing new determination.)</p>

				<p>Gotta get to class!</p>

				<p>Instead, Dasani hangs back. Too many other students are ahead of her, vying for the principal&rsquo;s attention. In class, she is quiet and focused. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a new Dasani,&rdquo; observes Officer Jamion Andrews, the security guard, his eyebrow dubiously cocked.</p>

				<p>If she can avoid fights, Dasani tells herself, the rest will fall into place. It is the taunts that she cannot resist. Her body gets &ldquo;hyped.&rdquo; She loses control. And that is precisely the behavior that Roxanne, her counselor at school, is trying to disrupt.</p>

				<p>In those moments, Dasani must learn to breathe in for 10 seconds through her nose and then breathe out for 10 seconds through her mouth. Roxanne demonstrates.</p>

				<p>Dasani practices on her walk home from school.</p>

				<p>The two blocks of sidewalk between McKinney and the shelter can be a minefield. This week, one of Dasani&rsquo;s classmates, Sunita, begins to stalk her along the way. Sunita is a foot taller than Dasani and easily twice her 70 pounds. Their rivalry dates back three years to fourth grade, when Sunita, who lives in the projects, began teasing Dasani about living at Auburn, prompting Dasani, then 9, to throw her first punch.</p>

				<p>For days, rumors have been flying that the two will fight again.</p>

				<p>As school lets out on April 9, Dasani steps onto the sidewalk and is surrounded by a sea of girls.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You gonna fight her?&rdquo; one of them asks breathlessly.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;No!&rdquo; Dasani yells loud enough for Sunita to hear. &ldquo;Miss Holmes says if I get in another fight I get suspended.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani&rsquo;s restraint only emboldens Sunita, who walks up and slaps Dasani hard across her left cheek.</p>

				<p>The crowd is hushed. Dasani tries to breathe.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You think that hurt? I eat those,&rdquo; Dasani says, using one of her mother&rsquo;s put-downs.</p>

				<p>The girl glares at Dasani.</p>

				<p class="lines nobotmarg">Breathe in 10 seconds.</p>

				<p>Suddenly, out of nowhere, Dasani&rsquo;s 10-year-old sister Avianna jumps between them. &ldquo;You better back up off my sister&rsquo;s face before I hurt you,&rdquo; Avianna yells.</p>

				<p>The girls might as well be twins. They share the same pillow, the same dresser, the same absent, biological father. It is usually Dasani who comes to Avianna&rsquo;s rescue, carrying her up four flights of stairs to their room when her asthma strikes.</p>

				<p>But today, Avianna rises to the occasion, mouthing off fiercely at Sunita as the crowd disperses.</p>

				<p>Dasani is soon surrounded by all of her siblings, a familial force field. Their bond presents itself physically. When they walk, ride the bus, switch trains, climb steps, jump puddles, cross highways and file into Auburn, they move as a single being. In all things, they are one.</p>

				<p>The sheer size of the family draws the notice of strangers, who shoot looks of recrimination at the mother, Chanel.</p>

				<p>Yet she sees fortitude in this small army of siblings, something she and her husband, Supreme, never had growing up. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s why the street became our family,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;I didn&rsquo;t want the street to become their family, too.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The children&rsquo;s solidarity is striking enough that social workers frequently make note of it. &ldquo;Family close knit,&rdquo; reads one social worker&rsquo;s report in March.</p>

				<p>They live in dread of the Administration for Children&rsquo;s Services. They survived their mother&rsquo;s absence for a year and take Supreme&rsquo;s periodic disappearances almost in stride, but they cannot imagine losing one another. They know the foster care system can split up siblings across the city&rsquo;s boroughs. </p>
			</div>

            <!--LELE SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_4_slideshow_3">
                <!--2 slides-->
                <div id="part_4_sequence_fixie_slideshow_3" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>Dasani is haunted by the thought of losing her baby sister, Lele, who just turned 1 and sometimes calls her Mommy. </p>

				<p>All the children dote on Lele, but Dasani speaks her language, discerning hunger or a wet diaper in the baby&rsquo;s cries. </p>
				</span>

				<p>The 11-year-old girl responds with the instinct of a mother but not the training. She pours artificially sweetened grape juice into Lele&rsquo;s bottle as if it were liquid gold.</p>

				<p>What would happen to Lele in the hands of strangers?</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Some people don&rsquo;t know how to take care of babies,&rdquo; she says.</p>

				<p>The children have heard their father&rsquo;s story &mdash; how Supreme was torn from his siblings and years passed before he was reunited with them in the Marcy projects, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Supreme soon left home to join the crack trade.</p>

				<p>By then, another child of the Marcy projects had also escaped. She chose an alternate path.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">&ldquo;I</span> was different, and I don&rsquo;t regret it,&rdquo; Faith Hester says, standing before her class in early May.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;She is not one to dwell on the past. But today, a student prompts Miss Hester to talk about her education. She was only 16 and living in the Marcy projects when she won a scholarship to SUNY Cortland.</p>

				<p>She packed a large orange suitcase. Her mother refused to take her to the train station. Girls married their way out of the projects. Going to college, the neighbors sneered, was trying to &ldquo;be white.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>So Miss Hester left alone that day, dragging her suitcase along Park Avenue. In college, she cleaned houses to help pay her way. Her mother did not speak to her for six months. &ldquo;Sometimes you have to be alone,&rdquo; she says, looking around the room.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t regret it for one second,&rdquo; she says, slamming her hand down on a desk. &ldquo;That was the path!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The class is motionless.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Do you understand what I&rsquo;m saying?&rdquo; Miss Hester continues, her voice trembling. &ldquo;There are going to be some places in your life where you feel bizarre. You feel outstanding. And remain that way. Stay just as you are.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani stares at her teacher, mesmerized.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;It takes a lot of courage to be different,&rdquo; Miss Hester says.</p>

				<p>When Dasani looks into the future, she sees who she won&rsquo;t be. She won&rsquo;t be a dropout. She won&rsquo;t do drugs or smoke or drink. She won&rsquo;t get married, unless she finds &ldquo;a gentle man, not a harsh man.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>She won&rsquo;t have children unless she can support them. She won&rsquo;t end up on the street.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Spare some change?&rdquo; she says, mocking a panhandler. &ldquo;Nuh-uh. Not me.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>It is harder for Dasani to imagine who she might become. She has been told she must reach for college if she wants a life of choices, but who will pay? Her mother is quick to ask that question whenever Grandma Sherry tries to encourage Dasani with the shining example of a niece who graduated from Bates College in Maine on scholarship.</p>

				<p>Other children talk of becoming rap stars or athletes, escaping their world with one good break. Dasani subscribes to the logic of those fantasies. Her life is defined by extremes. In order to transcend extreme poverty, it follows that she must become extremely rich or extremely something. What exactly she cannot see. To dream is, after all, an act of faith.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t dream at all,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;Even when I try.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>She believes in what she can see, and Miss Hester is real. Her lecture that day leaves Dasani feeling uplifted.</p>

				<p>As she walks home with a classmate later that afternoon, they talk about a coming history project on ancient Egypt. Dasani does not see Sunita coming.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m gonna fight you!&rdquo; Sunita calls out from the underpass, shedding her sweatshirt.</p>

				<p>Dasani pivots and starts walking against the traffic along Tillary Street. This time there are no siblings to come to her rescue.</p>

				<p>Get back on school property, she tells herself. She crosses over toward McKinney as Sunita charges up behind her.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Move before I punch you!&rdquo; Dasani says. But Sunita grabs Dasani&rsquo;s shirt and pulls as Dasani takes a roundhouse swing. They fall to the ground, biting and scratching.</p>
			</div>

            <!--FIGHTING SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_4_slideshow_1">
                <!--2 slides-->
                <div id="part_4_sequence_fixie_slideshow_1" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>Suddenly, another big girl piles on, kicking Dasani in the face and laughing while Sunita holds her down.</p>

				<p>Somehow Dasani manages to throw Sunita off balance, scrambling on top and pummeling her face before they pull apart, bleeding and crying. </p>
				</span>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m saying it right in front of your face,&rdquo; Dasani yells, her chest heaving. &ldquo;You wanna fight me some more &mdash;&mdash;&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m ready!&rdquo; Sunita yells.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I will jump you in your face!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I want you to! I want you to!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Sunita&rsquo;s brother orders her to retreat. &ldquo;Take your ass in the house!&rdquo; he yells.</p>

				<p>She turns obediently toward the Whitman projects as Dasani runs into Auburn.</p>

				<p>Minutes later, Dasani emerges with Chanel, who heads to the projects ready to go. She will wait for Sunita&rsquo;s mother all night if needed, and they can settle this themselves.</p>

				<p>But as Chanel presses for details, she learns that Dasani is hardly innocent: She had thrown Sunita&rsquo;s book bag on the floor earlier that day and commented unfavorably on her &ldquo;$2.99 sweater.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Chanel cools down and decides to handle the matter at school. The next morning, the two mothers and their daughters meet with Karen Best, an assistant principal who cuts to the chase.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Had Dasani been seriously injured, we wouldn&rsquo;t be sitting here having this conversation,&rdquo; Miss Best says. &ldquo;And that&rsquo;s what you need to understand: Children as young as you go to jail. O.K.? Real simple.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The mothers nod. The girls stare at the floor.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;She could have had a concussion,&rdquo; Miss Best says. &ldquo;You want to do something? Prove how smart you are.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;There you go,&rdquo; Chanel says approvingly.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Everyone knows the negativity,&rdquo; Miss Best says, looking at both girls. &ldquo;You got that down pat. Show the brains.&rdquo;</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">B</span>ack at Auburn, nothing is going well. The city&rsquo;s shelters are packed with families, whose average length of stay &mdash; 13.5 months &mdash; is longer than ever.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Dasani&rsquo;s family is among the outliers. It will soon be three years since they landed at Auburn. While the Department of Homeless Services cannot limit a family&rsquo;s time in the shelter system, the agency can resort to punitive measures when residents are found to be uncooperative.</p>

				<p>On May 14, Supreme and Chanel are called to a meeting at Auburn with two agency officials and the family&rsquo;s shelter caseworker.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m asking you: What have you been doing to move out?&rdquo; one of the officials asks Chanel and Supreme in a recording they made of the meeting.</p>

				<p>The official points at the family&rsquo;s independent living plan with the agency.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;You both signed it, O.K.?&rdquo; the official says. &ldquo;It says, &lsquo;This shelter is temporary housing.&rsquo; You must look for permanent housing for yourselves.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Violating the plan enough times means a family can be given an &ldquo;involuntary discharge,&rdquo; barring them from returning to the city&rsquo;s shelters for 30 days.</p>

				<p>During the meeting, Chanel and Supreme admit they have not searched for apartments. They say there is no point, since they cannot afford city rents without the kind of subsidy that the department once offered. They complain that their room is miserable and ask if they can be transferred to a better shelter.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s really hard,&rdquo; one of the officials says. &ldquo;Listen, you are not the only family in shelter.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I know that,&rdquo; Supreme says. &ldquo;Thousands.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Tens of thousands,&rdquo; the official says.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;Right, well, I have a different question,&rdquo; Supreme says. &ldquo;Do y&rsquo;all fall under the guidelines of the New York City Housing standards?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Excuse me?&rdquo; one of the officials says.</p>

				<p>A few weeks earlier, the family had been walking the elegant streets south of Fort Greene Park, searching &ldquo;white folks&rsquo; trash&rdquo; for discarded books and clothes. A thin, black volume caught Supreme&rsquo;s eye: &ldquo;McKinney&rsquo;s Consolidated Laws of New York &mdash; Book 52 A.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>He began leafing through hundreds of pages of laws, noting the violations that his living arrangement presents: the lack of hygienic conditions, dividers for privacy and sufficient living space.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I think it&rsquo;s inhumane,&rdquo; Supreme mumbles. &ldquo;I think one of you all need to try it. Your husband, eight children, all in one room. No bathroom. I want to see how you all manage that for three years.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>He might as well be talking to himself.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;With the documentation we can move forward, O.K.?&rdquo; one of the officials says.</p>

				<p>Supreme seems not to hear her either.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You never got no peace of mind. You and your husband can never have a moment because your children are always in your face. You&rsquo;d go crazy!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The meeting is wrapping up.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Even now, they got the bathrooms closed, so where you gotta go? All the way to the next floor,&rdquo; Supreme continues. &ldquo;I got a child who is legally blind. I gotta monitor her every time she go to the bathroom. It&rsquo;s, like, bananas. It&rsquo;s really bananas.&rdquo; </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">T</span>he children&rsquo;s birthdays come in a mad springtime rush: Lele&rsquo;s in March, Avianna&rsquo;s in April, the remaining six in the span of three and a half weeks.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Expectations are calibrated based on where a birthday falls in the monthly cash flow. Those at the start of the month bring hope, while those at the end of the month are luckless. So it goes for Avianna. </p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_4_single_4"></div>

				<p>Supreme hands her $11, one for each year of her life, but the next day, he asks for $5 back. She waits for a cake. Days pass. Finally, the children give up and light two small candles. Like carolers, they hold them beneath Avianna&rsquo;s face and sing.</p>

				<p>Avianna savors everything. While her siblings inhale their food, she will linger over each French fry.</p>

				<p>She spends her $6 slowly. A week later, she takes her last dollar bill and folds it delicately, like a Japanese fan. She then places it inside a homemade card that Chanel opens on Mother&rsquo;s Day.</p>

				<p>They pass that afternoon at the laundromat. There is only $190 left on Chanel&rsquo;s debit card, the balance of a tax refund that was supposed to rescue them from the shelter.</p>

				<p>In times like these, Chanel sees fit to steal groceries. She tells the children to wait for her at a store&rsquo;s entrance. She hides the habit from them. They hide their knowingness from her.</p>

				<p>Except for Papa, a gaptoothed 5-year-old buzzing with energy.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You stealin&rsquo;!&rdquo; he squeals one day as Chanel makes off with two prepackaged burgers from Target. &ldquo;You crazy!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Shut up, man!&rdquo; Chanel says, before composing herself.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Look,&rdquo; she tries more softly. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s not right to steal. But God knows when it&rsquo;s for a good reason.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>This year, birthday season has the misfortune of colliding with four of the children&rsquo;s grade-school graduations. They need new outfits, and money for class photos and parties. Chanel is accustomed to saying no when she has to, but she also recognizes the small luxuries that will separate her children from their peers.</p>

				<p>By the time Dasani&rsquo;s birthday arrives at the end of May, she knows better than to expect $1 for each of her 12 years.</p>

				<p>She has already pressed her mother too many times to pay for a school trip to Washington. Dasani has never been farther than Pennsylvania. She will hold out for that and let the birthday pass quietly.</p>

				<p>Chanel has no such intention. Dasani is her jewel.</p>

				<p>Over the weekend, the family retreats to the rowhouse in East New York belonging to Grandma Sherry. The mood is light. The children skip about as Supreme stands over the stove, tending to his honey-barbecue wings.</p>

				<p>The time has come to sing. Chanel gently lifts a vanilla sheet cake out of its plastic casing as Dasani stares in wonder. The top of the cake is still blank, awaiting inscription. Her mother covers it with candles and dims the lights.</p>

				<p>Dasani closes her eyes.</p>

				<p>If I could grant you three wishes, what would they be? her school counselor once asked her.</p>

				<p>A house of our own, a lot of money and three more wishes, was Dasani&rsquo;s answer.</p>
			</div>

            <!--BIRTHDAY SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence"  id="part_4_slideshow_2">
                <!--4 slides-->
                <div id="part_4_sequence_fixie_slideshow_2" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>She blows out the candles as the children clap. </p>

				<p>Chanel fetches a long, serrated knife. &ldquo;Let me show you how to cut a cake,&rdquo; she says, gingerly placing her hand over Dasani&rsquo;s. Together, they move the knife through the buttercream frosting. &ldquo;Doesn&rsquo;t have to be perfect,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p>Dasani bestows a sugar-flowered slice on each of her siblings, taking a plain piece for herself. </p>

				<p>They race to the basement, where their two uncles are blasting the Black Eyed Peas. </p>
				</span>

				<p>Screaming in delight, Dasani and her sisters leap onto a rickety, wooden platform and dance beneath a disco ball to &ldquo;I Gotta Feeling&rdquo; as Papa bounces around them.</p>

				<p>They barely register the hard-faced young men shuffling through the basement, exchanging elaborate handshakes, their heads hung low. Some play video games. Others mill about with girls in their teens wearing too much makeup and too little clothing.</p>

				<p>One of these girls, a baby-faced Dominican who works at the supermarket across the street, hangs on Uncle Josh, flashing braces when she smiles. To curry favor, she hands Dasani a $20 bill as a birthday present.</p>

				<p>Like other things in her life, Dasani could not have predicted such luck. She is still giddy, long after the girl has left in a huff, offended by Josh&rsquo;s waning interest.</p>

				<p>It is now late and the other children have collapsed on a sagging beige couch. Dasani is dancing to Alicia Keys.</p>

				<p class="lines">She&rsquo;s living in a world and it&rsquo;s on fire</p>
				<p class="lines">Filled with catastrophe</p>
				<p class="lines nobotmarg">But she knows she can fly away</p>

				<p>Dasani reaches up, her arms bathed in blinking lights, as if saluting an imaginary audience.</p>

				<p class="lines">Oh, she got her head in the clouds</p>
				<p class="lines">And she&rsquo;s not backing down</p>
				<p class="lines nobotmarg">This girl is on fire.</p>

				<p>Dasani has never had a better birthday. It feels like perfection.</p>

				<p>It hardly matters that the cake was stolen from Pathmark.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">T</span>hree days later, it is raining as the children spill down Sherry&rsquo;s steps. They are hungry and short on sleep.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;In theory, they are heading to the thing they most need &mdash; psychotherapy. Chanel signed them up after learning that she can reap $10 per child in carfare through Medicaid, at a clinic in the Kensington section of Brooklyn.</p>

				<p>Chanel needs the cash. She is still hoping to find a way to send Dasani on her school trip to Washington, and the $75 deposit is due tomorrow. So despite the pelting rain, Chanel instructs the children to meet her at a subway station.</p>

				<p>Only Hada is wearing a raincoat. Papa&rsquo;s hoodie slips off as he tips back to catch raindrops on his tongue. The children cross Lincoln Avenue holding hands.</p>

				<p>Dasani is in a foul mood. There is no telling how her anger will reveal itself today. Sometimes it comes as a quiet kind of rage. She will stare at an indefinite point, her eyes blinking, her mouth set. Other times, it bursts like thunder.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Move it!&rdquo; she screams.</p>

				<p>Nijai trails behind, her glasses fogging over. She has always been the odd orchid in this bunch of daisies, the most delicate and sensitive child, made more frail by her advancing blindness.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_4_single_5"></div>

				<p>She can make out only vague shapes and colors. Soon she will have to use a cane, but for now she often rests a hand on Lele&rsquo;s stroller to guide her. Today, Lele and the stroller have been left at Sherry&rsquo;s.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I said move it!&rdquo; Dasani yells at Nijai.</p>

				<p>She starts shoving Nijai, harder and harder, knocking her sister into a metal fence. Then she punches her in the arm. &ldquo;You stupid!&rdquo; Dasani screams. &ldquo;You think you smart, but you stupid! Now keep walking!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Nijai begins to sob as Khaliq yells, &ldquo;Double up!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>In pairs, they sprint across a six-lane highway and enter the Grant Avenue subway station, ducking under the turnstile to meet their mother. After they board the A train, she hands them a bag of lukewarm Popeyes chicken, furnished by a stranger.</p>

				<p>By the time they get off at Jay Street, their stomachs are full and the mood is lifted. Dasani spots an umbrella on the ground. It still works, opening to reveal an intricate pattern of white and black flecks. She twirls it around and, when the 103 bus pulls up, carefully closes it.</p>

				<p>Dasani and Nijai race to the back of the bus, where the motor keeps the seats warm. They sit pressed together, newly reconciled. Dasani is soon asleep. The little ones watch, thumbs in mouth, as their mother closes her eyes. Every time the bus slows, she snaps awake.</p>

				<p>At Church Avenue, the children and their mother pile off. The street looks familiar, but Chanel is unsure.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;We got off at the wrong stop,&rdquo; Dasani announces.</p>

				<p>Chanel fixes her gaze on Dasani.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Shut the fuck up,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;You know, that&rsquo;s one thing I don&rsquo;t like about you &mdash; your negativity. You always talkin&rsquo; about the problem. You got a solution?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani carries a singular burden among her siblings. Chanel has vested enormous authority in Dasani. Her competence, agility and strength &mdash; the attributes that could rescue Dasani from her life&rsquo;s miseries &mdash; also threaten to keep her mired in the problems that her mother cannot meet alone.</p>

				<p> At times, Chanel seems taunted by her dependence on her daughter, which reminds her of her own failings.</p>

				<p>They walk single file toward Coney Island Avenue.</p>

				<p>Dasani tries to recover.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s this way, Mommy,&rdquo; she says, gesturing hopefully toward a florist shop. They take a few steps before Chanel turns on her heel, remembering the way.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;If you want to go somewhere, don&rsquo;t listen to Dasani,&rdquo; she says.</p>

				<p>Dasani freezes under her new umbrella.</p>

				<p>Chanel unloads.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m sick of your attitude,&rdquo; she seethes. &ldquo;There&rsquo;s only like 15 kids going on this trip because people can&rsquo;t pay. And me, who got nothing, is trying to send you and you gonna give me attitude?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani keeps walking.</p>

				<p>Chanel&rsquo;s fury mounts. She reaches for the same words every time, the kind that echo for days in Dasani&rsquo;s head.</p>

				<p><em>Dasani always gotta have the answer.</em></p>

				<p><em>She think she special.</em></p>

				<p><em>She think she some-fucking-body.</em></p>

				<p><em>She nobody.</em></p>

				<p>Dasani&rsquo;s face remains frozen as the tears begin to fall, like rain on a statue.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_4_single_6"></div>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t give a shit if she&rsquo;s crying,&rdquo; Chanel says loudly as they approach a small green house, marked by a gold-embossed sign that reads &ldquo;Advanced Psychotherapy & Behavioral Health Services.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s only one goddamn chief,&rdquo; Chanel says. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m the only chief.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Inside, the children file into their fourth &ldquo;group therapy&rdquo; session with a woman who asks vague questions like, &ldquo;What are your hobbies?&rdquo; She sounds more like a distant aunt than a counselor.</p>

				<p>Khaliq knows the difference. Earlier in the year, a Children&rsquo;s Services caseworker had sent him to a therapist after he acted erratically in school. That therapist had asked questions like, &ldquo;Do you want to kill yourself?&rdquo; Those sessions felt like they never ended; these lasted only 20 minutes &mdash; roughly two and a half minutes per child.</p>

				<p>At the door, Chanel collects her $80 in carfare and the children head back into the rain. The cash instantly settles the family, leaving the children calm and Chanel introspective.</p>

				<p>By the time they reach the bus stop, Chanel&rsquo;s gray T-shirt is soaked through. She is thinking about Supreme, whom she could not rouse from bed this morning.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;What gets me down is the responsibility,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;They got shoes on but no socks. I come all this way, on the bus, in the rain, to get the money so she can go on her trip.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>She is shivering now.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Those are the things you are supposed to provide,&rdquo; she scolds her absent husband. &ldquo;You are the man. You made this family, but you don&rsquo;t provide.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani watches her mother silently. She wants to fix it.</p>

				<p>She can only feel empty. The day&rsquo;s weight has passed from her sister to herself and now to their mother, who is weeping in the rain.</p>
			
				<div class="nytmm_comments_container nytmm_buildable" data-type="commentcontainer"></div>

			</div>

			<footer class="clearfix">

				<div class="behind_the_scenes nytmm_buildable" data-type="reporternote"></div>

				<div class="behind_the_scenes video_clips">
					<h4>Videos: Behind the Reporting</h4>
					<p class="footer_summary">The Times used small video cameras as an additional reporting tool. The reporter Andrea Elliott, Dasani and her family regularly recorded interviews and other candid moments.</p>

			<div class="nytmm_buildable nytmm_next" data-type="bottomprompt" data-id="prompt_slide_4" data-part="5" data-title="Reasons to Dream"></div>
		</div><!--END PART CONTENT-->
