	</section>




<!-- POVERTY PART 5 ****************************************************************** //-->




	<section class="poverty_section clearfix" id="poverty_part_5" data-title="5">

		<div class="nytmm_buildable section" 
			data-type="coverslide"
			data-id="cover_slide_5"
			data-part="5"
			data-title="Reasons to Dream"
			data-summary="">
		</div>

		<div class="nytmm_trigger clearfix" data-type="shownavbar" data-top="0">
		<div class="poverty_part_content">
			<div class="section column firstSection">
				<p class="pov_first_paragraph top"><span class="pov_first_letter">A</span> mob of spectators presses in, trying to see the tiny girl. Rap stars circle. The cameras roll. The crowd chants her name.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;&ldquo;Da-Sa-Neee!&rdquo;&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Her heart is racing. She looks up at the sky and extends her fingers, but cannot reach high enough to grasp the metal bar. A powerful man hoists her up by the waist.</p>

				<p>In an instant, she is midair, pulling and twisting acrobatically as the audience gasps at the might of this 12-year-old girl.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;She&rsquo;s a giantess,&rdquo; the man had announced to the audience. &ldquo;She&rsquo;s tomorrow&rsquo;s success, I&rsquo;m telling you right now.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani blinks, looking out at the smiling faces. She cannot make sense of the serendipity that has brought her here to Harlem, on this sparkling July day, to make her debut as a member of an urban fitness group teamed up with Nike.</p>

				<p>But there is her beaming mother, Chanel; her father, Supreme; and all seven siblings. They are cheering and clapping as well.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I thought it was a dream &mdash; make believe &mdash; like this wasn&rsquo;t happening,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;You know, like in movies, people pinch themselves like this ain&rsquo;t real.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>It was only two months earlier that Dasani stood at the bus stop as her mother wept in the rain. Summer was fast approaching, a season that, in this family, always brings change.</p>

				<p>The markers of Dasani&rsquo;s life &mdash; her first months in the care of Grandma Joanie, the day her family moved into their first real home, the loss of that home two years later, when they landed in the Auburn shelter &mdash; these all came in summertime.</p>

				<p>There was no telling what this summer might bring. Dasani could no sooner predict landing a spot on the Harlem team than she could foretell the abrupt changes that still lay ahead.</p>

				<p>Already, the court-mandated supervision of the family by child protection workers had run its course. Chanel&rsquo;s nine-month trial period was suddenly over, leaving her custody secure, just as new problems came along.</p>

				<p>School was winding down when the children learned that their only other refuge &mdash; Grandma Sherry&rsquo;s rowhouse in East New York, Brooklyn &mdash; had gone into foreclosure. Sherry could end up homeless as well, at a time when New York&rsquo;s shelter population had surpassed a historic 50,000.</p>

				<p>As the days grew hotter, Dasani and her family remained stuck in the same miserable room at Auburn.</p>

				<p>And yet summer, no matter how stifling, also carried a certain promise, the kind that comes of chance encounters on the street.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">I</span>t is a muggy night in Harlem, but the children do not care. They savor any chance to visit.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;This is the place where, a decade earlier, Chanel and Supreme fell in love. They have returned over the years, pulled by the Five Percent Nation, the movement spawned 50 years ago by a contemporary of Malcolm X who broke from the Nation of Islam.</p>

				<p>Tonight, people swarm into the Harriet Tubman Learning Center on West 127th Street for the organization&rsquo;s annual gathering, pushing past security guards and a vendor with pins that declare, &ldquo;I &hearts; being God.&rdquo; Supreme mills about in the foyer, greeting old friends with tight hugs.</p>
			</div>

            <!--5 PERCENTER SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_5_slideshow_1">
                <!--2 slides-->
                <div id="part_5_sequence_fixie_slideshow_1" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>Chanel trails him, her chin high, her daughters&rsquo; hair freshly braided. </p>

				<p>It is a rare moment of belonging in a year of rootlessness. </p>
				</span>

				<p>As the sun sets, Dasani and her family step out for some air. A man brushes past them, walking along West 127th Street. His hooded sweatshirt is pulled low over his face, which is dusted by a salt-and-pepper beard. He moves with the purposeful air of a celebrity in hiding.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I seen your videos,&rdquo; Chanel says, stopping him in his tracks.</p>

				<p>For years, Dasani&rsquo;s family had been watching the DVDs of this former convict turned fitness guru who calls himself Giant. His team, Bartendaz, combines pull-up acrobatics on city playgrounds with a militaristic message of self-improvement, steering followers away from drugs and alcohol to &ldquo;the bars of health.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Giant looks Chanel up and down, noting the open beer she has sheathed in a brown paper bag.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Bud don&rsquo;t make you wiser,&rdquo; he observes, flashing a smile that reveals a perfect row of teeth.</p>

				<p>Chanel ignores the comment. She is already thinking through the possibilities presented by this accidental meeting. She steers Dasani to some empty pull-up bars at a nearby playground.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Show him what ya got!&rdquo; she calls out.</p>

				<p>Giant, whose name is Hassan Yasin-Bradley, accepts the impromptu audition the way a famous film director takes the waiter&rsquo;s latest screenplay. While Giant remains on the fringe of prime-time America, he has his share of acolytes in Harlem.</p>

				<p>Dasani springs to the bars and begins to knock out an impressive set of pull-ups, her shoulders popping with the muscles of an action figure.</p>

				<p>Giant is still chatting with Chanel when he looks over and pauses.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Whoa,&rdquo; he says.</p>

				<p>Chanel senses that she may be on to something. She explains that Dasani has been doing pull-ups in Fort Greene Park for years. She can also dance, do gymnastics, run track. All she lacks is training &mdash; of any kind.</p>

				<p>Now it is Giant&rsquo;s mind that races through the possibilities. The girl is uncommonly strong. She has a telegenic smile. She&rsquo;s spunky.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;She seems like just the kind of girl we could use on our team,&rdquo; he says, grinning at Dasani, who grins back.</p>

				<p>Giant quickly explains how his team works: It has a limited partnership with Nike that will hopefully lead to bigger things. In the meantime, the team earns modest pay in exchange for holding training clinics, and performing at concerts and other events.</p>

				<p>At the very least, he concludes, Dasani merits a proper tryout.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Meet me at the park next Saturday,&rdquo; he says, leaving his number before disappearing.</p>

				<p>Dasani lies awake that night.</p>

				<p>It is the first time in her life she can see a path to something else. What exactly, she is not sure. She has not even had her tryout. But for a girl who has spent her life tempering expectations, she cannot stop herself from dreaming just a little.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;ma save all my money so we can get a house,&rdquo; she tells her mother.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Use your money for you,&rdquo; Chanel says. &ldquo;We&rsquo;ll be O.K.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;No,&rdquo; Dasani insists. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ma save all my money.&rdquo; </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">M</span>oney is especially tight. This might explain why, in Dasani&rsquo;s words, Mommy goes &ldquo;loco&rdquo; during an inspection of the family&rsquo;s room at Auburn.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;There is a knock at the door. Chanel lets in the inspector, who promptly demands that she surrender the family&rsquo;s forbidden microwave oven.</p>

				<p>Chanel refuses. She cannot afford to buy a new one, nor can she fathom having to wait in line every night to reheat 10 dinner trays in one of the shelter&rsquo;s two microwaves. The inspector leaves, and by the time two security officers with the Department of Homeless Services arrive to confiscate the microwave, Chanel has hidden it in a friend&rsquo;s room.</p>

				<p>As for the inspector, Chanel offers to &ldquo;punch that bitch in the face.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani believes that her mother&rsquo;s biggest problem is her mouth.</p>

				<p>She reflects on this as her homeroom teacher, Faith Hester, delivers a lesson that week on personal responsibility.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t ever wanna hear, &lsquo;Well, my mother told me to do this,&rsquo; unless you know that that&rsquo;s the right thing,&rdquo; Miss Hester tells the class.</p>

				<p>The teacher has shimmied into an empty desk next to Dasani.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_5_single_1"></div>

				<p>&ldquo;I am telling you, as sure as I&rsquo;m sitting here,&rdquo; Miss Hester says, her arm resting across Dasani&rsquo;s desk, &ldquo;you&rsquo;re gonna be held responsible for the choices you make.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Hands shoot up in the air.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Yes, Miss Dasani?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani recounts how her longtime rival, Sunita, began following her after school, and slapped her. &ldquo;And so, my mom is a violent parent, so you can&rsquo;t tell her anything about fights because then she gonna want to get a stick and tell you to knock the chick out.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Miss Hester arches her brows.</p>

				<p> &ldquo;O.K.,&rdquo; Miss Hester says. &ldquo;Now, let me ask you: Do you think that was the right thing to do?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The class erupts in chaos.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;O.K., O.K.!&rdquo; Miss Hester yells. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ma tell you what I would have told my kid.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>They fall silent.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Not everybody has something to lose,&rdquo; Miss Hester says.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You care about your life,&rdquo; she continues. &ldquo;There are people out there who are so hurt they don&rsquo;t care about leaving here. They are looking for an opportunity to do something crazy and ridiculous. They have nothing to live for.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani ponders this.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I am telling you to listen to your internal barometer,&rdquo; Miss Hester says. &ldquo;Think about your next move before you make your next move.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani is still in bed the next morning when her mother rises from a fitful sleep and heads to the corner store with her sister Avianna. All around, men are leaving the projects to report to early work shifts. Chanel stands in the cold, watching them. &ldquo;Your father should be doing that,&rdquo; she says.</p>

				<p>Just that week she had stopped a flag waver at a construction site. It seemed like a job that Chanel could perform beautifully. The woman told her about an organization that helps people with G.E.D.&rsquo;s find work.</p>

				<p>For Chanel, words like &ldquo;G.E.D.&rdquo; end a conversation. It has been 20 years since she sat in a high school classroom. She can feel like a foreigner in her own country, unable to speak the language of bank accounts and loan applications. When filling out medical forms, she stops at the box requiring a work number, frozen by its blankness.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I want my kids to be able to come see me at my job, pick up my paycheck,&rdquo; she says that afternoon, standing with Dasani outside Au Bon Pain, where the day&rsquo;s pastries will soon sell at a discount. &ldquo;Just be reliant on my money, you know what I&rsquo;m sayin&rsquo;?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani stares at her mother anxiously.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;m tired of my kids seeing me dull,&rdquo; Chanel says. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s my time to shine.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t see you dull,&rdquo; Dasani says quietly. &ldquo;I see you shine.&rdquo; </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">D</span>asani spends the week before her tryout for Bartendaz in focused preparation, training on the fitness bars next to the basketball court in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn. At night, she replays the team&rsquo;s DVDs over and over, studying the members closely.</p>

				<p>At school, she tells no one.</p>

				<p>This new dream is carried on practical terms. It is less about helping herself than about making her parents whole. In the meantime, Dasani worries about the most immediate challenge, which is to get to Harlem on time. Punctuality is a miracle in her family.</p>

				<p>On Saturday morning, there is no sign of Dasani as the Bartendaz start to warm up at the playground at 144th Street and Lenox Avenue.</p>

				<p>Soon they are causing a commotion that slows the traffic. One after another, they fly onto the bars, whipping through moves that seem to defy gravity. Some of them wear black T-shirts with the logo of a man bending a bar, his brain lit by a bulb.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Salute that mind!&rdquo; Giant calls out to his followers.</p>

				<p>There is Cinderblock, Honey Bee, Sky, Earth, Water, Blaq Ninja, Salubrious and Mel Matrix. Giant&rsquo;s second in command is Dr. Good Body, a self-described athletic alchemist (&ldquo;the library is my alma mater&rdquo;) who transforms the &ldquo;base metal&rdquo; of a person&rsquo;s character into &ldquo;gold.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Giant orbits around his team, issuing commands in a lyrical code that is impenetrable to outsiders. He is especially fond of abbreviations. A favorite is &ldquo;C.A.P.&rdquo; &mdash; Character, Attitude and Personality. His nickname, Giant, stands for Growing Is a Noble Thing.</p>

				<p>It is a bold name for a man who stands just 5-foot-7. Born Warren Hassan Bradley, he grew up in the Baruch projects on the Lower East Side, where in his teens he became known as a D.J. and street fighter skilled at hiding razors in his mouth and spitting them out in combat. He started selling drugs, and was sent to prison in 1989 on two felony drug charges.</p>

				<p>Like Dasani&rsquo;s father, Giant left prison transformed. He had earned a high school equivalency diploma and devoted himself to Islam. (He looks askance at the teachings of the Five Percent.) He also found a way to capitalize on the pull-up bar routines that he taught himself in prison yards. By the time he started Bartendaz in 2003, he was already drawing crowds to Harlem&rsquo;s playgrounds.</p>

				<p>Dasani finally arrives, her mother and two siblings in tow, as the team&rsquo;s practice winds down. Dressed in bright-pink shorts and matching flip-flops, she is a dwarf among titans.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;What&rsquo;s your name again?&rdquo; Giant says.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Dasani.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Dasani with a D?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Like the water,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p>He turns to the group.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Everyone say, &lsquo;Peace, Queen.&rsquo;&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Peace, Queen!&rdquo; they shout.</p>

				<p>The tryout begins with a set of pull-ups, demonstrated by Blaq Ninja and Sky. Dasani coasts through the exercise.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Damn!&rdquo; a team member says as the others whistle. Giant remains cool to the newcomer, telling Dasani &ldquo;stay there, breathe&rdquo; as she pedals her feet in the air while holding her head level with the bar.</p>

				<p>Her next test comes on the parallel bars, where she knocks out a set of dips in good form, and then pedals again as Giant counts aloud, shaking his head incredulously. Next, they hit the floor for push-ups. </p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_5_single_2"></div>

				<p>&ldquo;Do some diamonds!&rdquo; Chanel calls out. Dasani connects her hands in the shape of a diamond as she dives into a set of flawless push-ups.</p>

				<p>Then she goes for broke, clapping her hands behind her back, mid-push-up. Honey Bee captures the image on the team&rsquo;s iPad before Dasani comes crashing to the ground, promptly dusting herself off.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Look at this! Look at this!&rdquo; Giant says, running over to show Dasani the iPad photo. &ldquo;You tellin&rsquo; me I can&rsquo;t sell this poster for $100?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>He turns to Chanel: &ldquo;She&rsquo;s in.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>A young boy sidles up. The team has drawn spectators who live as far away as Norway and Japan. This one is a local.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Excuse me,&rdquo; he says to Dasani. &ldquo;Can you do a pull-up again?&rdquo;</p>

				<p>She nods gamely as he calls out to his friends: &ldquo;Yo! Come here! She about to do it!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Giant smiles.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Wait till they see you in three weeks,&rdquo; he says.</p>

				<p>The family is ecstatic.</p>

				<p>Supreme runs to the corner store for a dozen roses. He hands them to Chanel.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Dag, I love it here,&rdquo; he says, looking at her tenderly. &ldquo;We should come back to Harlem.&rdquo;</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">C</span>hanel soon finds reason to be suspicious of Giant. He is charming, she thinks, but confusing on details like payment and a promised contract. Giant, too, can spot a hustler, and he seems wary of Chanel.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;On the day of the tryout, he treats her children to lunch at a local bodega, joined by Malcolm X&rsquo;s grandson Malik, a friend of the team. Malik congratulates Dasani, handing her a bottle of peach-flavored Snapple. She carries the bottle with both hands, later writing &ldquo;Malcolm X grandson&rdquo; on the label before stashing it in her dresser at Auburn.</p>

				<p>The next day, when Dasani&rsquo;s siblings tag along to practice again, Giant senses that Chanel expects him to repeat the invitation.</p>

				<p>He skips the meal, but reassures Chanel that her daughter, like his other team members, will be compensated for events. The first one is a training clinic this Thursday. All Chanel needs to do is bring Dasani. The rest is Dasani&rsquo;s job.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;That&rsquo;s why we got the word &lsquo;responsibility,&rsquo;&rdquo; Giant tells Dasani in front of Chanel. &ldquo;Response&rdquo; &mdash; he holds up his right hand &mdash; &ldquo;Ability&rdquo; &mdash; then his left hand. &ldquo;So respond to what? Your ability. Not your mom&rsquo;s ability.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>On Thursday afternoon, Dasani asks if her mother has heard from Giant. Chanel is tired after a long day and cannot imagine taking Dasani all the way to Harlem.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;He never called,&rdquo; Chanel tells Dasani.</p>

				<p>Up in Harlem, Giant had been calling repeatedly. He checks his phone, looking for a response. He shakes his head.</p>

				<p> Dasani goes to sleep feeling crushed.</p>

				<p>She wakes at 5 a.m. for the long-awaited school trip to Washington. Still feeling glum, she boards the bus on an empty stomach, sitting alone with a thin blue blanket laid carefully across her legs. Five hours later, as they approach the Capitol, Dasani presses her face to the window.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_5_single_5"></div>

				<p>It looks different here. People walk slower. There is space everywhere &mdash; trees, monuments, water. She can see off into the distance, her view unobstructed by skyscrapers.</p>

				<p>She is paying special attention, trying to record what she sees so she can describe it later to her sister Nijai.</p>

				<p>Remember every single detail, Nijai had implored. It is not just that her blindness prevents her from seeing it herself. It is that Washington represents Nijai&rsquo;s roots, the city where she was born and last saw her mother alive.</p>

				<p>Every detail.</p>

				<p>After a tour of the memorials, the bus stops near the White House. Dasani runs to the tall, wrought-iron gate and looks between the bars. On the sidewalk, a group of protesters wearing orange suits and black hoods are chanting foreign-sounding names.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Obama, close Guant&aacute;namo!&rdquo; they yell.</p>

				<p>Dasani has never heard of Guant&aacute;namo. But she knows what a jail uniform looks like from visiting her Uncle Carnell. These people, she concludes, are supposed to be prisoners, and they want President Obama to close their jail. She shakes her head.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know why they protesting in front of Obama&rsquo;s house like he gonna be in here,&rdquo; she says.</p>

				<p>There is hardly a trace of the child who had once scoured Gracie Mansion for a glimpse of the mayor. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">A</span> week has passed with no word from Giant. Dasani keeps doing her pull-ups. Tucked in the top drawer of her dresser is the empty Snapple bottle given to her by Malcolm X&rsquo;s grandson.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;&ldquo;It&rsquo;s all right,&rdquo; Dasani tells her mother. &ldquo;I didn&rsquo;t get attached.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Detachment is as much a rite of Dasani&rsquo;s summers as sunbaked afternoons in the park. She bids farewell to Miss Hester and the principal, Paula Holmes, bracing herself for a 10-week absence from the Susan S. McKinney Secondary School of the Arts.</p>

				<p>Summers also bring more regular visits to Grandma Sherry&rsquo;s, where the children can ride up and down Lincoln Avenue on rusted bikes. But this year, Sherry has bad news. The bank is coming for her house. In another month, a court marshal will see her out the door if she is not gone.</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_5_single_3"></div>

				<p>Sherry has two bad choices: She can enter the shelter system or she can leave her children and grandchildren behind in New York and move in with her sister in Pittsburgh. If Sherry leaves, Chanel will have lost her only support, the woman who partly raised her.</p>

				<p>Chanel copes in a way that puzzles Sherry: She stops taking Sherry&rsquo;s calls. It is Chanel&rsquo;s way of detaching, of leaving a relationship before it leaves her. Sherry finally decides to go to Pittsburgh. When she does get the children on the phone, she tells them that she is not sure when she is leaving, but that &ldquo;the Lord will take care of you.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>In the midst of this, Dasani finds herself thinking about Bartendaz. A month after her tryout, she resolves to give it another chance: She will report to practice by herself, as if nothing has changed. But as she announces her departure one morning, Supreme stops her at the door.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Not before this place is straightened up,&rdquo; he says. By the time Dasani finishes, practice is over.</p>

				<p>The next morning, she gets up feeling defiant. She looks at Supreme, who is still asleep. <em>How you gonna take my destiny away from me?</em> she thinks. Dasani turns to her mother, and Chanel waves at her to leave before he wakes.</p>

				<p>Accompanied by her siblings Khaliq and Avianna, she jumps the train to Harlem.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Long time no see,&rdquo; Giant says by way of a greeting. He gives Dasani a stern lecture: &ldquo;If you know you&rsquo;re not gonna be consistent, then I need to know so I can invest in someone else.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani is confused. Her parents say that he never called. His version of events is quite the opposite, but he thinks it best to simply say that &ldquo;there must have been a miscommunication.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Dasani does not know what to believe, but she begins training with Giant every weekend, accompanied by her twin in all things, Avianna.</p>

				<p>They are in Harlem on the day a moving truck pulls up to Sherry&rsquo;s house. Alerted by phone, Chanel arrives moments before Sherry&rsquo;s departure.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;ma hide in the truck,&rdquo; 8-year-old Maya says.</p>

				<p>Chanel walks through the house she has known since she was born. She pauses at the bathroom&rsquo;s worn wooden door, which reminds her of her father.</p>

				<p>He is there at that door, some flicker of a memory. Those are the things one loses with a house, not the shelter itself but the irretrievable belonging it brings.</p>

				<p>On the stoop, Sherry and Chanel hold each other for a long time.</p>

				<p>Dasani does not get to say goodbye. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">T</span>he sadness of Sherry&rsquo;s departure is eclipsed a week later when Dasani makes her big Bartendaz debut. Her routine is captured on video for the opening sequence of Giant&rsquo;s forthcoming DVD, and Dasani receives her first earnings: $70.</p>

				<p>She is too excited to think twice when Supreme asks if he can borrow some of it. He buys pizza for the children and keeps the rest. Dasani is distracted by the day&rsquo;s other gifts &mdash; the cheering crowd, the chance to pose with the rappers Jadakiss and Styles P.</p>

				<p>She is still floating two days later, when Giant summons her to a basketball clinic for boys. He wants her to &ldquo;mentor&rdquo; them. It seems like an odd request for a girl who was recently suspended from school. But that is Giant&rsquo;s point: She needs to act like a mentor before she can feel like one.</p>

				<p>She soon takes to the task, guiding boys several inches taller as they struggle into feeble pull-ups. When Dasani orders them to line up, one of the boys smirks, saying, &ldquo;You not staff.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Oh yes I am,&rdquo; Dasani shoots back.</p>

				<p>She is bonding with her team &mdash; most of all with Sky, a nursing student, and Earth, who just got her bachelor&rsquo;s degree in psychology at Queens College.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I&rsquo;ma take all of Sky&rsquo;s moves,&rdquo; Dasani says jauntily as she hits the low bars. They laugh and laugh, never ceasing to delight in their youngest member. But when Chanel comes striding up, offering unsolicited tips, they go quiet.</p>

				<p>Later that afternoon, Dasani tells Giant about her loan to Supreme. Long after she leaves practice, he is still livid. Can this even work, he wonders. &ldquo;You&rsquo;re fixing a child to send back to broken parents.&rdquo; </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">S</span>ummer&rsquo;s end marks the third anniversary of Dasani&rsquo;s arrival at Auburn, on Aug. 26, 2010.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Three years &mdash; a quarter of her life &mdash; most of it spent in one room. She has gotten so used to the smallness of it that she can scarcely recall how to live with more space.</p>

				<p>To Dasani, sometimes it seems like only tragedy brings change.</p>

				<p>The next morning, on Aug. 27, she wakes to a high-pitched scream. It is her neighbor in Room 445, a single mother named Aisha. Her 3-month-old daughter, Casshanae, has turned blue.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;My baby&rsquo;s not breathing!&rdquo; she wails.</p>

				<p>A petite 27-year-old from Pennsylvania, Aisha had come to Auburn in early May, seven months pregnant with Casshanae. She was born premature with respiratory distress syndrome and developed feeding problems, all of which was noted in the records that Auburn received.</p>

				<p>The infant&rsquo;s problems were serious enough that a hospital social worker asked the Department of Homeless Services to transfer the baby, Aisha and her 1-year-old son to another shelter equipped to handle medical needs.</p>

				<p>The agency declined to do so, even after Aisha filed a complaint that a male resident had sexually assaulted her in her room at Auburn on June 18.</p>

				<p>Nor did the shelter&rsquo;s staff members heed Aisha&rsquo;s repeated complaints when they gave her a damaged metal crib for the infant, with a loosefitting sheet and a mattress permanently stuck in the lowest position.</p>

				<p>But now she is screaming, and everyone hears her.</p>

				<p>A security guard calls 911. None of the staff members try to resuscitate the baby, even though they are certified in CPR. Aisha fumbles to breathe air into her baby&rsquo;s lungs as paramedics rush into the lobby.</p>

				<p>They race to Brooklyn Hospital Center, where a doctor pronounces Casshanae dead at 8:10 a.m.</p>

				<p>Later that morning, Aisha returns to the fourth floor to pack her things. Her screams rattle the shelter again.</p>

				<p>As she leaves, Dasani lingers by the door. She hears a security guard telling a superior that Aisha left the children alone the previous night. The official asks the guard to file a report. Dasani shudders and closes the door. That will never happen to Baby Lele, she tells herself.</p>

				<p>The next day, the Administration for Children&rsquo;s Services takes custody of Aisha&rsquo;s son pending the results of an investigation into the baby&rsquo;s death. Soon after, Dasani sees inspectors walking through the shelter as new cribs are delivered to residents and crib-safety posters are slipped under doors.</p>

				<p>Aisha is summoned back to Auburn by investigators from the medical examiner&rsquo;s office. At their request, she re-enacts the morning of her baby&rsquo;s death, when she says she found Casshanae lifeless in the crib. They take pictures of the crib, its sheet still crumpled. An autopsy was unable to determine the cause of death. </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">D</span>asani tries not to think about the dead baby.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Her room is sweltering. The children want nothing more than to get out and cool off. They put on their bathing suits. They have gone swimming only once this summer.</p>

				<p>First, they stop into Chanel&rsquo;s methadone clinic in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a dim brick building sandwiched between a highway overpass and a garbage dump. Chanel waves at Dasani to come inside.</p>

				<p>She has been bragging to the staff about Giant, who continues to work with Dasani on the condition that she is paid in kind, not cash. &ldquo;No one can take a pair of sneakers,&rdquo; he reasons. &ldquo;He just stingy,&rdquo; Chanel says. But she has gone along with it, proud as a stage mother.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;So look out for Dasani, man,&rdquo; Chanel tells a woman behind the desk. &ldquo;She gonna be out soon.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I believe I am already out,&rdquo; Dasani says.</p>
			</div>

            <!--RED HOOK POOL SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_5_slideshow_3">
                <!--4 slides-->
                <div id="part_5_sequence_fixie_slideshow_3" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>Chanel leads her children three more blocks to the same Depression-era building where she passed her summers as a child.</p>

				<p>They carry one thin towel to share. </p>

				<p>Dasani squints at the Olympic-size pool, a turquoise expanse that glistens in the sun. She dives in first. All is cool and silent. </p>

				<p>She comes up for air, releasing a rapturous cry.</p>
				</span>

				<p>The uncertainty of Dasani&rsquo;s life is deepening. Supreme is now gone, having checked into a residential treatment program to try to get off methadone.</p>

				<p>Right before school starts in September, Chanel uproots Dasani from McKinney, reasoning that she will be less likely to fight in the company of Avianna and Nijai at a neighboring school.</p>

				<p>Dasani is unsettled. Every afternoon, the three sisters turn up at McKinney like stray puppies, passing the time with Miss Holmes and Miss Hester. The principal offers to enroll all of them. Finally, on Sept. 25, Chanel relents.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Oh my gooney goo hoo,&rdquo; Miss Hester squeals as Dasani, Avianna and Nijai skip up the hallway. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ve been praying on this.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Back at Auburn, residents begin to notice small changes. In the wake of Casshanae&rsquo;s death, the shelter is providing a steadier supply of formula, diapers and other items to mothers, and the cafeteria has a few more items on its menu.</p>

				<p>These fixes hardly address the systemic breakdown that state inspectors are uncovering. On Oct. 1, they inform the Department of Homeless Services of a <a href="#" class="nytmm_link_media nytmm_link_doc doc_inspection_letter"><span class="document_icon"></span>devastating litany of violations</a>.</p>

				<!--STATE INSPECTION LETTER -->
				<div class="nytmm_document_promo doc_inspection_letter" id="doc_inspection_letter_promo">
					<span class="nytmm-2013ChildPovertyDeploy-icons document_blue"></span> 
					<span class="doc-header">Document</span>
					<div class="nytmm_doc_summary">State letter to Department of Homeless Services.</div>
				</div>
				<div class="nytmm_buildable nytmm_document" data-type="document" data-trigger=".doc_inspection_letter" data-doc="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/p5-inspection-letter.jpg" data-slug="p5-inspection-letter" data-format="jpg">
					<div class="nytmm_doc_container"></div>
				</div>

				<p>The fire safety system is virtually inoperable. The shelter has no certificate of occupancy. Its record-keeping is a mess. The registration cards of 25 of its security guards are expired or missing. Black mold is spreading in the shelter&rsquo;s bathrooms, many of which spew exhaust thick with dust and debris.</p>

				<p>During one visit, inspectors see an asthmatic 3-year-old child coughing and vomiting so much that 911 is called. With no air-conditioning, the rooms reach dangerously high temperatures. A month before she died, Casshanae was living in a room where temperatures reached 102 degrees.</p>

				<p> <a href="#" class="nytmm_link_media nytmm_link_doc doc_inspection_findings"><span class="document_icon"></span>The state&rsquo;s conclusion:</a> No child with chronic breathing problems should be at the shelter, and no children under age 2 should live there at all &ldquo;due to the lack of amenities for this young and vulnerable population.&rdquo;</p>

				<!--STATE INSPECTION FINDINGS -->
				<div class="nytmm_document_promo doc_inspection_findings" id="doc_inspection_findings_promo">
					<span class="nytmm-2013ChildPovertyDeploy-icons document_blue"></span> 
					<span class="doc-header">Document</span>
					<div class="nytmm_doc_summary">State inspection of Auburn.</div>
				</div>
				<div class="nytmm_buildable nytmm_document" data-type="document" data-trigger=".doc_inspection_findings" data-doc="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/p5-inspection-1.jpg" data-slug="p5-inspection-1" data-format="jpg">
					<div class="nytmm_doc_container"></div>
				</div>

				<p>In other words, Dasani&rsquo;s family &mdash; with a 1-year-old, two asthmatic children and another who is legally blind &mdash; should never have been living at Auburn in the first place.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">I</span>n the early afternoon of Oct. 17, Chanel is summoned to the office of the shelter&rsquo;s administrators.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;They have stunning news: The family can finally leave Auburn. A space has opened at another shelter &mdash; an apartment with a kitchen. But they must go today. They have a few hours to pack. Other families are also moving, and the Department of Homeless Services has arranged for vans.</p>

				<p>Chanel has longed for this moment. But now that it is here, she feels wholly unprepared.</p>

				<p>Supreme is still in rehab. Her food stamps have been stolen. She has $9 in cash. How will she instantly produce three meals a day for eight children? She has no frying pans, dishes, utensils or toilet paper. She does not even have the address of this new shelter.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know what to do,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p>She returns to Room 449 and tells the children.</p>

				<p>Dasani is in shock. Chanel rushes them off to therapy. Whatever happens, she needs the cash.</p>

				<p>It is drizzling out, and Dasani&rsquo;s head is spinning. All she can think about is her school. Just after willing her way back to McKinney, she is poised to lose it again.</p>

				<p>It is strange, this feeling of heading toward an address they don&rsquo;t yet have, while having to say goodbye &mdash; in the span of a few hours &mdash; to the place where they have lived for years.</p>

				<p>After therapy, it is getting dark. The shelter&rsquo;s lights blaze from within. Chanel orders the children to pack only the most essential things. Auburn has given them 20 clear plastic bags. That is the limit. They will have to come back for Turtle.</p>

				<p>At 9:26 p.m., Chanel and her children board the last van just before it pulls away. An hour later, the van approaches their new residence.</p>

				<p>They are in Harlem.</p>

				<p>Of the 152 shelters where Dasani&rsquo;s family could have landed, they have somehow wound up at a six-story brick building on West 145th Street.</p>

				<p>It is one block from the Bartendaz base.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I am right next to the park,&rdquo; Dasani tells Giant on the phone, enunciating each word. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m here! I&rsquo;m in Harlem!&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Chanel grabs the phone, eager to hear his reaction.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You see?&rdquo; Giant tells Chanel. &ldquo;The Lord sent you right here next to me.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The children wait on the front steps as Chanel fills out paperwork in the office.</p>

				<p>It feels different here. The block is awash in streetlights and teeming with pedestrians. There are fewer trees. But in other ways, Harlem is like Fort Greene. Nearby is a new bistro called Mountain Bird that offers a foie gras soup and a shrimp-bisque mac and cheese.</p>

				<p>One by one, the children peek in on their mother, anxious for updates.</p>
			</div>

            <!--NEW APARTMENT SEQUENCE-->
            <div class="section image_sequence" id="part_5_slideshow_4">
                <!--4 slides-->
                <div id="part_5_sequence_fixie_slideshow_4" class="sequence_slide_container"></div>
            </div>

			<div class="section column">
				<span class="story_text_hide">
				<p>They will be living on the third floor, Avianna announces. She locates the silver button on the intercom, gently running her finger over it.</p>

				<p>Finally, Chanel appears with the keys. They climb three flights and step inside. </p>

				<p>It is a real apartment, with clean, beige walls and hardwood floors. </p>
				</span>

				<p>There are two bedrooms, a full bathroom and a kitchen joined to a living room. Metal blinds hang from the windows, and clean sheets are folded on the bunk beds.</p>

				<p>Fresh, home-cooked meals again, Dasani thinks to herself as the children race about maniacally. Hada opens a closet to find a diaper on the floor. Chanel smells it, declares it clean and stashes it for Lele.</p>

				<p>She inspects the mattresses, which are in good condition. She opens the refrigerator, looks at the stove and sink, and then turns toward the living room. She clasps her hands in front of her face, as if in prayer.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Oh, man, I&rsquo;m happy!&rdquo; she says, her eyes shining. &ldquo;I thank God for this. Thank you.&rdquo; </p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">C</span>hanel cannot sleep that first night.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;She keeps checking the locks as her children lie deep in slumber. The five older girls share two bunk beds alongside Lele&rsquo;s crib. The boys sleep in the living room. Chanel reserves one bedroom for herself and Supreme. It will be their first privacy in years, whenever he comes back.</p>

				<p>Chanel is feeling more panicked than celebratory.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;I got to make sure I provide,&rdquo; she says.</p>

				<p>The move has plunged Chanel into the ice-cold waters of independence.</p>

				<p>She now has $39, counting the money gleaned from therapy. It will be more than two weeks before her next food-stamp allotment arrives.</p>

				<p>When the children wake, Chanel drags a rolling cart onto the subway and returns to Auburn to retrieve more of their belongings. Thankfully, the room has still not been cleared. Chanel leaves with Turtle hidden in an empty baby-wipes container.</p>

				<p>By the next morning, Supreme has left rehab and rejoined the family. Now they are almost broke. Chanel can think of only one solution. She heads downtown to Macy&rsquo;s, where she tries to steal a stack of men&rsquo;s Polo briefs and undershirts, planning to sell them on the street for quick cash.</p>

				<p>A security guard intervenes, leading Chanel to the store&rsquo;s private jail, along with Nijai, Avianna and Baby Lele, who toddles about the small, enclosed cell saying, &ldquo;Out, out.&rdquo; After Supreme collects the children, Chanel is arrested by the police and spends the night in jail.</p>

				<p>When she comes home, Supreme declares that the stealing is over. If they have to, they can beg.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Better to ask than take,&rdquo; he says.</p>

				<p>It doesn&rsquo;t quite feel like &ldquo;begging&rdquo; to Dasani, the way she has seen it in the movies, with peasants holding out hands for coins. It is a little more dignified, how Supreme stands outside the local Pathmark, his children silently lined up next to him.</p>

				<p>As shoppers enter the store, he asks them to buy a few extra groceries &ldquo;so I can feed my babies.&rdquo; Dasani runs in with a woman who pays for Froot Loops and Corn Flakes. And so it goes, until a particularly generous man tells them to just &ldquo;get what you need,&rdquo; and they fill up the cart.</p>

				<p>Back in the apartment, the family&rsquo;s spirits begin to lift. It is easy to forget they are still homeless as Supreme hovers at the stove, making corn bread from scratch, popcorn shrimp, honey-barbecue wings and glazed turkey bacon. He has joined a new methadone program in Harlem.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;They happier now,&rdquo; Dasani says of her parents, who are fighting less now that they have more space.</p>

				<p class="pov_first_paragraph"><span class="pov_first_letter">M</span>iss Holmes is worried.&nbsp;<span class="paragraph_break">&#9632;</span>&nbsp;Dasani and her sisters have been absent for days. Under federal legislation, homeless children are granted the right to stay in one school even as their families move around. But in practice, there are no guarantees.</p>

				<p>Even if the girls were old enough to ride the subway alone, the trek from Dasani&rsquo;s new shelter to McKinney takes at least an hour. When Chanel requests a bus pickup, only Nijai is approved because of her blindness.</p>

				<p>Chanel has already found new schools for four of her other children. She thinks it best that Dasani and her sisters switch to a Harlem school.</p>

				<p>If this happens, Dasani will be starting her third school in six weeks.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;No, Mommy,&rdquo; she protests.</p>

				<p>Her sisters also plead. They are learning to play an instrument at McKinney. If they make enough progress, Avianna can keep her trombone, and Nijai, her clarinet. She shows her mother the march she is learning for the school band, holding her invisible clarinet aloft as she stomps her feet.</p>

				<p>Chanel is persuaded when she hears that Miss Holmes and Joshua Goldfein, a lawyer for Legal Aid, are pressing the Education Department to approve a bus for all three sisters.</p>

				<p> In the meantime, Chanel decides that she will take the girls herself.</p>

				<p>Early on Nov. 4, they board the No. 2 train, hurtling back to Brooklyn. In Fort Greene, the children walk along North Portland Avenue, passing Auburn and the projects, where they used to be called &ldquo;shelter boogies.&rdquo;</p>

				<p><em>See?</em> Dasani thinks to herself. <em>I&rsquo;m gone and you are still in the projects.</em></p>

				<p> Minutes later, they enter the warm corridors of McKinney.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Hi, Miss Holmes,&rdquo; Chanel squeaks to the woman who always makes her feel like a schoolgirl again, back in the principal&rsquo;s office.</p>

				<p>Dasani flies into Miss Holmes&rsquo;s arms. She feels safe again, &ldquo;like I was made to be there.&rdquo;</p>

				<div class="pov_single_image" id="part_5_single_4"></div>

				<p>The principal is shocked to see them. She did not think it would happen without the bus. As the girls are handed new backpacks and sent to class, Miss Holmes makes Chanel an offer: She can volunteer at the school during the day, whenever she needs shelter. She can even bring Baby Lele.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;We always need plenty of help,&rdquo; Miss Holmes says.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;That will work out nice,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;But you can&rsquo;t make a whole lot of noise,&rdquo; Miss Holmes warns, back in the posture of principal.</p>

				<p>At the end of the day, the girls gather in Miss Holmes&rsquo;s office to wait for their mother.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;You have come home,&rdquo; Miss Holmes says. &ldquo;Everybody here is fighting to get you girls back here. There are certain things you have to do. Homework.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>Soon, Chanel has arrived and is chiming in with the principal. No more bad behavior, she tells her daughters.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;We not gonna have that, you understand?&rdquo; Chanel says. &ldquo;Because soon I&rsquo;m about to be volunteering here.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>The girls are silent.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;So it&rsquo;s gonna be a totally different song this year,&rdquo; Chanel says.</p>

				<p>As they leave, Dasani turns and races back into Miss Holmes&rsquo;s office. She leans in for another hug before darting out.</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Goodbye, Dasani,&rdquo; Miss Holmes calls after her. &ldquo;And do your homework.&rdquo;</p>

				<p>&ldquo;Yes!&rdquo; Dasani shouts over her shoulder.</p>

				<p>The child skips down the hallway toward her mother and sisters. The front door swings open, bringing a rush of air. Together, they step out into the cold.</p>
			
				<div class="nytmm_comments_container nytmm_buildable" data-type="commentcontainer"></div>

			</div>

			<footer class="clearfix">

				<div class="behind_the_scenes nytmm_buildable" data-type="reporternote"></div>

				<div class="behind_the_scenes video_clips">
					<h4>Videos: Behind the Reporting</h4>
					<p class="footer_summary">The Times used small video cameras as an additional reporting tool. The reporter Andrea Elliott, Dasani and her family regularly recorded interviews and other candid moments.</p>


					<!--VIDEO BOX HIDDEN-->

						<span class="nytmm_videoBoxLink nytmm_videoNoteTrigger clearfix" id="nytmm_videoNoteTrigger_bartendaz"

			</footer>

			<!-- TODO END CREIDTS FOOTER -->
			<div id="nytmm_endCredits">
				<div class="endCredits_wrapper clearfix">
					<div class="behind_the_scenes video_clips">
				<h4>Summary of Reporting</h4>
				<div class="reporting_col left">
					<p>Andrea Elliott, an investigative reporter with The New York Times, began following Dasani and her family in September 2012. The series is written in the present tense, based on real-time reporting by Ms. Elliott and Ruth Fremson, a photographer with The Times, both of whom used audio and video tools.</p>
					<p>Throughout the year, Dasani&rsquo;s family also documented their lives in video dispatches from the Auburn Family Residence, which does not allow visitors beyond the lobby. Ms. Elliott and Ms. Fremson gained access to the shelter to record conditions there.</p>
				</div>
				<div class="reporting_col right">
					<p>The reporting also drew from court documents, city and state inspection reports, police records, the family&rsquo;s case files at city agencies and dozens of interviews with shelter residents. Most scenes were reported firsthand; others were reconstructed based on interviews and video and audio recordings.</p>
					<p>The Times is withholding the last names of Dasani and her siblings to protect their identities. The nicknames of some of Dasani&rsquo;s siblings are used in place of their birth names.</p> 
				</div>
					</div>
					<div class="behind_the_scenes">
						<h4>Credits</h4>
						<p>By <span>Andrea Elliott</span>
						<br/>Photographs by <span>Ruth Fremson</span></p>
						<p>Design, graphics and production by <span>Troy Griggs,</span> <span>Jon Huang,</span> <span>Meghan Louttit,</span> <span>Jacky Myint,</span> <span>John Niedermeyer,</span> <span>David Nolen,</span> <span>Graham Roberts,</span> <span>Mark Suppes,</span> <span>Archie Tse,</span> <span>Tim Wallace</span> and <span>Josh Williams.</span></p>
						<p>Reporting was contributed by <span>Rebecca R. Ruiz,</span> <span>Joseph Goldstein</span> and <span>Ruth Fremson,</span> and research by <span>Ms. Ruiz,</span> <span>Joseph Burgess,</span> <span>Alain Delaqu&eacute;ri&egrave;re</span> and <span>Ramsey Merritt</span>.</p>
					</div>
				</div>

				<!-- CODE FOR CORRECTIONS IF WE HAVE ANY

					<div class="correction_box">
						<h4></h4>
						<p></p>

<script>
    // NYTD namespace/IE bugfix
    window.NYTD_BACKUP = NYTD;
    // load gateway except in in-app webkit view
    var isIPhoneWebView = /(iPhone|iPod|iPad).*AppleWebKit(?!.*Safari)/i.test(navigator.userAgent);
</script>

<script>
    if (isIPhoneWebView) {
        document.write('<script src="//graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/js/multimedia/libs/jquery-1.7.1.min.js"><\/script>');
    } else {
        document.write('<script src="//graphics8.nytimes.com/js/common.js"><\/script>');
    }
</script>
<script>
    // straighten out jquery and NYTD/common.js jq locations
    window.jQuery = jQuery || NYTD.jQuery;
    NYTD.jQuery = NYTD.jQuery || window.jQuery;
</script>
<script src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/js/multimedia/libs/jquery-ui-1.9.2.min.js"></script>

<NYT_TRACKING_CODE SECTION="NY/REGION" SUBSECTION=""/>
<!-- load tracking js if context include fails -->
<script>NYTD.Analytics || document.write('<script src="//graphics8.nytimes.com/js/app/analytics/trackingTags_v1.1.js"><\/script>')</script>


<script>
    var development = false;


    // NYTD Namespace/IE bugfix
    if (!NYTD || !NYTD.NYTMM) {
        NYTD = jQuery.extend(NYTD_BACKUP, NYTD);
    }

    (function($,NS,undefined){
        var modernizr = NS.Modernizr;
        var $html = $('html');


        (function(){
            NYTD.NYTMM.iOS = false;
            NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo = {
                userAgent: null,
                version: null, // major versions of iOS: 4,5,6
                minor: null, // minor versions: 1, for 5.1
                update: null, // optional minor version update: 2, for 5.1.2
                device: null, // iPhone, iPod, iPad
                phone: false, // treat iPhone and iPods both as phones
                tablet: false, // iPad and maybe rumored iPad mini
                pixelRatio: 1, // 1 is standard dpi. 2 is retina
                retina: false
            };

            if(/(iPhone|iPod|iPad)/i.test(navigator.userAgent)) {

                NYTD.NYTMM.iOS = true;
                NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.userAgent = navigator.userAgent;

                // iOS version
                if (/CPU like Mac OS X/i.test(navigator.userAgent)) {
                    NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.version = 1;
                } else if (/OS [2-6]_\d(_\d)? like Mac OS X/i.test(navigator.userAgent)){
                    // [0] = source, [1] major version, [2] minor version, [3] optional minor version update
                    var parts = /OS ([2-6])_(\d)(?:_(\d))? like Mac OS X/i.exec(navigator.userAgent);
                    NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.version = parts[1];
                    NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.minor = parts[2];
                    NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.update = parts[3];
                }

                // device
                var device = /(iPhone|iPod|iPad)/i.exec(navigator.userAgent);
                NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.device = device[0];

                NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.tablet = (NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.device === "iPad");
                NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.phone = (NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.tablet) ? false : true;
                NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.pixelRatio = !!window.devicePixelRatio ? window.devicePixelRatio : 1;
                NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.retina = NYTD.NYTMM.iOSInfo.pixelRatio > 1;
            }
        })();



        NS.projectMeta = {
            photoPath: 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/',
            // photoPath: 'http://mmstorage.nyhq.nytint.com/meghan/POVERTY/web/',
            videoPath: 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/video/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPoverty/',

            // update
            url: 'http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2013/invisible-child/',
            commentsUrl: 'http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2013/invisible-child/comments/',
            notesUrl: 'http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2013/invisible-child/notes/',
            documentsUrl: 'http://www.nytimes.com/projects/2013/invisible-child/documents/',
            
            projectTitle: 'Invisible Child: Dasani’s Homeless Life',
            projectDescription: 'There are more than 22,000 homeless children in New York, the highest number since the Great Depression. This is one of their stories.',

            viewport: document.documentElement.clientWidth,
            legacyDesktop: window.NYTMM_IE,
            imageSizes: [280, 320, 480, 670, 768, 1024, 1200, 1400, 1900],
            streetViewImageSizes: [320, 480, 768, 970, 1024, 1400, 1900],
            blankImage: 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/greyC.png'
        }

        // agent detection from MediaElement.js
        var ua = navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase();
        NS.projectMeta.browser = {
            isAndroid: (ua.match(/android/i) !== null),
            isBustedAndroid: (ua.match(/android 2\.[12]/) !== null),
            isChrome: (ua.match(/chrome/gi) !== null),
            isFirefox: (ua.match(/firefox/gi) !== null),
            isWebkit: (ua.match(/webkit/gi) !== null),
            isOpera: (ua.match(/opera/gi) !== null)
        };
        window.__nytg_project_meta = NS.projectMeta.browser;
        NS.projectMeta.browser.isGecko = (ua.match(/gecko/gi) !== null) && !NS.projectMeta.browser.isWebkit;
        NS.projectMeta.isTablet = NS.iOSInfo.tablet || NS.projectMeta.browser.isAndroid && modernizr.touch && NS.projectMeta.viewport >= 768;
        NS.projectMeta.isPhone = NS.projectMeta.browser.isBustedAndroid || modernizr.touch && NS.projectMeta.viewport < 768;


        NS.loadMobileVersion = NS.projectMeta.isTablet || NS.projectMeta.isPhone || NS.projectMeta.legacyDesktop;
        //NS.loadMobileVersion = NS.projectMeta.isPhone;


        if (NS.loadMobileVersion) {
            $html.addClass('nytmm_mobile');
        }


        if (NS.projectMeta.legacyDesktop) {
            NS.projectMeta.presentationType = 'legacyDesktop';
            $html.addClass('nytmm_legacyDesktop');
        } else if (NS.projectMeta.isPhone) {
            NS.projectMeta.presentationType = 'phone';
            $html.addClass('nytmm_phone');
        } else if (NS.projectMeta.isTablet){
            NS.projectMeta.presentationType = 'tablet';
            $html.addClass('nytmm_tablet');
        } else {
            NS.projectMeta.presentationType = 'desktop';
            $html.addClass('nytmm_desktop');
        }

        if (window.NYTMM_IE9) {
            $html.addClass('nytmm_ie9');
        }


        var assetsPath = {
            mobileJs: (development) ? '/bundler/?action=bundle&staging=true&files=projects/2013/ChildPovertyMobile/ChildPovertyMobile.js' : 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/js/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPovertyMobile.js',
            mobileCss: (development) ? '/bundler/?action=bundle&staging=true&files=projects/2013/ChildPovertyMobile/ChildPovertyMobile.css' : 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPovertyMobile.css',
            desktopJs: (development) ? '/bundler/?action=bundle&staging=true&files=projects/2013/ChildPovertyTest3/ChildPovertyTest3.js' : 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/js/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPovertyTest3.js',
            desktopCss: (development) ? '/bundler/?action=bundle&staging=true&files=projects/2013/ChildPovertyTest3/ChildPovertyTest3.css' : 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/projects/2013/ChildPovertyTest3.css'
        };


        modernizr.load({
            test : NS.loadMobileVersion,

            // phone
            yep: [
                assetsPath.mobileCss,
                assetsPath.mobileJs
            ],

            // Desktop stuff
            nope : [
                'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/css/0.1/screen/common/modules/sharetools/common.css',
                'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/js/common/sharetools/2.0/shareTools.js',
                'http://int.nyt.com/applications/lasso/assets/chapter_comment_rotators/viewer-1ca75e1a1bb3cf03b5ec95188eb970c2.css',
                'http://int.nyt.com/applications/lasso/assets/chapter_comment_rotators/viewer-acae085852368339fc2863eac6fdbaf3.js',
                'http://int.nyt.com/applications/lasso/data/52a4fd6305fbb54071000002.js',
                assetsPath.desktopCss,
                assetsPath.desktopJs
            ],
            complete: function(){
                // NYTD Namespace/IE bugfix
                if (!NYTD || !NYTD.NYTMM) {
                    NYTD = jQuery.extend(NYTD_BACKUP, NYTD);
                }
            },
            callback: function(url, result, key){

            }
        });

    })(jQuery,NYTD.NYTMM);
</script>

    <div class="message-bed">
        <div class="message-container last-message-container">

    <header class="story-header interactive-header">
                        <div class="story-meta">
                                                                            <h1 class="story-heading interactive-headline" itemprop="headline">Camp X-Ray: A Ghost Prison</h1>
            
            <div class="story-meta-footer interactive-meta-footer">
                                 <p class="interactive-leadin summary">
    
        			        	<time class="dateline" datetime="2014-08-31" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-08-31">AUG. 31, 2014</time>
	    	                                </p>
            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->

        </div><!-- close story-meta -->
        </header>
    <div id="guantanamo-camp-x-ray-ghost-prison-photographs" class="interactive-graphic">

				<h1>Camp X-Ray: A Ghost Prison</h1>
				<p class="g-leadin"></p>
				<p class="g-byline">Photographs by Damon Winter; Text by Charlie Savage</p>
			</div>
		</div>

				<div class="caption caption-style-long caption-type-fullViewport">
					<span class="caption-text">A public affairs representative opens the front gate to Camp X-Ray for a tour of the defunct facility last month during a news media visit to Joint Task Force Guantánamo at the United States Naval Station Guantánamo Bay.</span>
					<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">Damon Winter/The New York Times</span>
				</div>
			</div>
		
		<div class="item-multiCaptionContainer">
			<div class="caption caption-style-fullViewport">
				<span class="caption-text"></span>
				<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="item-textContainer">
			<h2></h2>
			<div class="item-text"><p>Wearing shackles, orange prison garb, face masks and gear to block their eyes and ears, the first prisoners from the Afghanistan war were deposited in January 2002 at a prison consisting of cages, roughly 8-foot-square, made of concrete and wire. This was Camp X-Ray. Guantánamo was never meant to be a permanent prison, and X-Ray was even more makeshift. It was open just a few months, allowing the military time to build a more sophisticated prison complex. But a Navy petty officer took pictures from Camp X-Ray, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2014/09/01/us/GITMO-23.html">showing rows of the arriving prisoners kneeling next to fences</a>, and those images would leave a lasting impression around the world. This photo series shows Camp X-Ray today, a ghost prison overtaken by vines and scrub.</p></div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>
		
			<div id="item-1"
	data-presentation-type="multi"
	 data-multi-length=2 
	class="item photoslide row-1 presentation-multi  horizontal horizontal presentation-multi-2 no-title has-text">
	<div class="item-container">
		
			<div class="media-outerContainer">
				<div class="media-innerContainer">
					<div class="media">

							data-presentation-type="multi"

						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
				<div class="caption caption-style-short caption-type-multi">
					<span class="caption-text">Piles of small animal bones on the floor in the former administration shack.</span>
					<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
				</div>
			</div>
		
		<div class="item-multiCaptionContainer">
			<div class="caption caption-style-multi">
				<span class="caption-text">Left, guard towers and razor wire-lined fences as seen from inside an administration shack at Guantánamo. Right, piles of small animal bones on the floor in the former administration shack.</span>
				<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="item-textContainer">
			<h2></h2>
			<div class="item-text"><p>Three months after the Sept. 11 attacks, Donald H. Rumsfeld, then the secretary of defense, called the remote Guantánamo naval base “the least-worst place we could have selected” to detain the men that Americans were capturing in Afghanistan, believed to be fighters from Al Qaeda and the Taliban. Some of the infrastructure was already in place. In the mid-1990s, during a migrant crisis, the United States had brought Haitian and Cuban rafters to Guantánamo while it sorted out their requests for asylum, and it had built a crude prison of open-air cages to house troublemakers. For the new prisoners, the military had hastily reopened the site, building more cages of chain-link fencing on concrete slabs. Guard towers of plywood were hammered together to watch over the growing warren. Sections of the base were named after the military’s phonetic alphabet, and this site happened to be located in the “X” sector, so it was called Camp X-Ray. In the months that followed, hundreds more prisoners from Al Qaeda and the Taliban, who the Bush administration claimed were not protected by the Geneva Conventions, arrived at Guantánamo.</p></div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>
		
			<div id="item-2"
	data-presentation-type="wide"
	 
	class="item photoslide row-2 presentation-wide  horizontal no-title has-text">
	<div class="item-container">
		
			<div class="media-outerContainer">
				<div class="media-innerContainer">
					<div class="media">
						<div class="g-lazy-media"
							data-type="image"
							data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/08/30/us/GITMOxray-ss-slide-B56M/GITMOxray-ss-slide-B56M-{{size}}.jpg"
							data-ratio="0.6666666666666666"
							data-slug="GITMOxray-ss-slide-B56M"
							data-item-id=""
							data-widths=[{"slug":"master180","size":180},{"slug":"blog225","size":225},{"slug":"tmagSF","size":362},{"slug":"blog427","size":427},{"slug":"blog480","size":480},{"slug":"master495","size":495},{"slug":"blog533","size":533},{"slug":"tmagArticle","size":592},{"slug":"slide","size":600},{"slug":"articleLarge","size":600},{"slug":"popup","size":650},{"slug":"master675","size":675},{"slug":"jumbo","size":1024},{"slug":"master1050","size":1050},{"slug":"superJumbo","size":2048}]
							data-posterPath=""
							data-presentation-type="wide"
						>
						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
				<div class="caption caption-style-short caption-type-wide">
					<span class="caption-text">The caged entrance to one of the cellblocks.</span>
					<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">Damon Winter/The New York Times</span>
				</div>
			</div>
		
		<div class="item-multiCaptionContainer">
			<div class="caption caption-style-wide">
				<span class="caption-text"></span>
				<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="item-textContainer">
			<h2></h2>
			<div class="item-text"><p>By April 2002, four months after it opened, Camp X-Ray was mostly abandoned when detainees were transferred to Camp Delta, a more permanent facility. But later that year, one detainee, believed to have been an intended hijacker for the Sept. 11 attacks, was taken back for a 49-day, 20-hour-a-day interrogation session, according to a leaked interrogation log. The session, the log said, included forced nudity in cold rooms, shackling in stress positions, forcing the detainee to stay awake with loud music and making him bark and obey dog commands like “stay” and “come.” Later, other detainees began to file habeas corpus lawsuits asking judges to order the military to free them, claiming they were victims of a mistake or had made false statements under torture. They also obtained court orders to preserve any evidence of their treatment, which the military interpreted as barring it from razing the area. So Camp X-Ray was left to rot in the harsh climate. Its guard towers are buckling, and the cages — their doors left open — are filled with droppings from banana rats, tropical rodents the size of opossums. Troops who escort visiting reporters through the site say they have seen boa constrictors lying in the overgrown grass. In one guard shack, bones from dead animals were strewn across the floor.</p></div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>
		
			<div id="item-3"
	data-presentation-type="multi"
	 data-multi-length=2 
	class="item photoslide row-3 presentation-multi  horizontal horizontal presentation-multi-2 no-title no-text">
	<div class="item-container">

						</div>

					<span class="caption-text">A makeshift gravity-fed urinal system in a cell.</span>
					<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
				</div>

		<div class="item-multiCaptionContainer">
			<div class="caption caption-style-multi">
				<span class="caption-text">Left, a gap for passing food into a cell. Right, a makeshift gravity-fed urinal system in a cell.</span>
				<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="item-textContainer">
			<h2></h2>
			<div class="item-text"></div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>
		
			<div id="item-4"
	data-presentation-type="wide"
	 
	class="item photoslide row-4 presentation-wide  horizontal no-title has-text">
	<div class="item-container">
		
			<div class="media-outerContainer">
				<div class="media-innerContainer">
					<div class="media">
						<div class="g-lazy-media"
							data-type="image"
							data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/08/30/us/GITMOxray-ss-slide-ZMII/GITMOxray-ss-slide-ZMII-{{size}}.jpg"
							data-ratio="0.6666666666666666"
							data-slug="GITMOxray-ss-slide-ZMII"
							data-item-id=""
							data-widths=[{"slug":"master180","size":180},{"slug":"blog225","size":225},{"slug":"tmagSF","size":362},{"slug":"blog427","size":427},{"slug":"blog480","size":480},{"slug":"master495","size":495},{"slug":"blog533","size":533},{"slug":"tmagArticle","size":592},{"slug":"slide","size":600},{"slug":"articleLarge","size":600},{"slug":"popup","size":650},{"slug":"master675","size":675},{"slug":"jumbo","size":1024},{"slug":"master1050","size":1050},{"slug":"superJumbo","size":2048}]
							data-posterPath=""
							data-presentation-type="wide"
						>
						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
				<div class="caption caption-style-short caption-type-wide">
					<span class="caption-text">A shack that housed the dogs from the K-9 unit.</span>
					<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">Damon Winter/The New York Times</span>
				</div>
			</div>
		
		<div class="item-multiCaptionContainer">
			<div class="caption caption-style-wide">
				<span class="caption-text"></span>
				<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="item-textContainer">
			<h2></h2>
			<div class="item-text"><p>Camp Delta, too, is empty now. Most of the remaining 149 prisoners at Guantánamo, from the 779 who were brought here, live in concrete-walled prisons called Camps 5 and 6. A handful of higher-level detainees live in Camp 7, an intelligence operations center hidden in the hills; reporters are not permitted to visit.</p>
<p>Toward the end of his presidency, George W. Bush said he wanted to close Guantánamo, which had become a poisonous symbol for anti-American propaganda in the Muslim world. Two days after taking office, President Obama ordered it closed within a year, but Congress blocked his plan to bring some of the remaining prisoners into the United States. Year after year, the official policy states that it is closing, but <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/01/us/politics/decaying-guantanamo-defies-closing-plans.html">it stays open</a>. The detainees are now guarded by young enlisted soldiers who were in elementary school when their predecessors arrived here to build Camp X-Ray.</p></div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>
		
			<div id="item-5"
	data-presentation-type="wide"
	 
	class="item photoslide row-5 presentation-wide  horizontal no-title no-text">
	<div class="item-container">
		
			<div class="media-outerContainer">
				<div class="media-innerContainer">
					<div class="media">
						<div class="g-lazy-media"
							data-type="image"
							data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/08/30/us/GITMOxray-ss-slide-TRI5/GITMOxray-ss-slide-TRI5-{{size}}.jpg"
							data-ratio="0.6666666666666666"
							data-slug="GITMOxray-ss-slide-TRI5"
							data-item-id=""
							data-widths=[{"slug":"master180","size":180},{"slug":"blog225","size":225},{"slug":"tmagSF","size":362},{"slug":"blog427","size":427},{"slug":"blog480","size":480},{"slug":"master495","size":495},{"slug":"blog533","size":533},{"slug":"tmagArticle","size":592},{"slug":"slide","size":600},{"slug":"articleLarge","size":600},{"slug":"popup","size":650},{"slug":"master675","size":675},{"slug":"jumbo","size":1024},{"slug":"master1050","size":1050},{"slug":"superJumbo","size":2048}]
							data-posterPath=""
							data-presentation-type="wide"
						>
						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
				<div class="caption caption-style-short caption-type-wide">
					<span class="caption-text">A cellblock consisting of steel-fenced cages on a concrete foundation.</span>
					<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">Damon Winter/The New York Times</span>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="caption caption-style-wide">
				<span class="caption-text"></span>
				<span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"></span>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="item-textContainer">

googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

                                        <h3 class="kicker">
                        <span class="kicker-label"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/business/index.html">Business Day</a></span>                                                                </h3>
                        	<h1 itemprop="headline" id="story-heading" class="story-heading">Inside Amazon: Wrestling Big Ideas in a Bruising Workplace</h1>
                        <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">
                                                                                    

<p class="byline-dateline"><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/jodi_kantor/index.html">By <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/jodi_kantor/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by JODI KANTOR"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="JODI KANTOR" itemprop="name" data-twitter-handle="jodikantor">JODI KANTOR</span></a> and </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/david_streitfeld/index.html"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/david_streitfeld/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by DAVID STREITFELD"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="DAVID STREITFELD" itemprop="name">DAVID STREITFELD</span></a></span><time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-15" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-08-15">AUG. 15, 2015</time>
</p>

data-author="By JODI KANTOR and DAVID STREITFELD"

        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="140" data-total-count="140" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1">SEATTLE — On Monday mornings, fresh recruits line up for an orientation intended to catapult them into Amazon’s singular way of working.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="536" data-total-count="676" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">They are told to forget the “poor habits” they learned at previous jobs, one employee recalled. When they “hit the wall” from the unrelenting pace, there is only one solution: “Climb the wall,” others reported. To be the best Amazonians they can be, they should be guided by <a title="The Amazon principles. " href="http://www.amazon.jobs/principles">the leadership principles</a>, 14 rules inscribed on handy laminated cards. When quizzed days later, those with perfect scores earn a virtual award proclaiming, “I’m Peculiar” — the company’s proud phrase for overturning workplace conventions.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

                <header>
        <h2 class="module-heading">
                            Related Coverage
                    </h2>
    </header>

        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">A Writerly Chill at Jeff Bezos’ Campfire</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2014-09-20" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-09-20">SEPT. 20, 2014</time>
        </h2>
